notes.title: (Virtualized) I/O Security
notes.body:
#virtualization #security In

## Threats

### DMA attacks

Most devices are capable performing DMA, which may be used to corrupt kernel
memory if the device is buggy or controlled by attackers.

### Malicious peripherals

Certain devices are more easily corruptible than than others. For example, it is
unlikely for PCI-e devices to be corrupted, but USB/bluetooth devices are easily
plugged into the system, and can be easily manufactured.

However, in confidential computing scenario, devices are provided by the
untrusted hypervisor, which must be assume to be unsafe.

### Virtualized IO

Virtualized I/O adds more complexity to I/O security. For confidential VMs,
access control of hardware devices becomes more complicated. There is now a
three-way concerns. Aside from isolation of VM from host, cross VM, now the host
must also be prevented from accessing devices assigned to a CVM.

Virtualized I/O faces a fundamental challenge between performance and security.
That is, allowing the VM to directly access to the hardware device (i.e., the
I/O memory regions) enables great performances. However, the devices might be
programmed to perform malicious accesses. It may use DMA to illegally access
host memory and also memory of other VMs.

## Isolation for security

The IOMMU and related hardware allows the hypervisor to isolate device's DMA
accesses [[hxm4jt6e]].

RISC-V have a potentially more scalable protection model with a PKU-like domains
[@feng2024siopmp].

Related:

- [[8qvweuj8]]
- [[hxm4jt6e]]

## Filtering for security

Even with IOMMU isolation, devices can still attack the kernel through malicious
packets (more of an interface attack [[yef2w9yc]]). This is more concerning for
bluetooth and USB devices that are easily pluggable. Another approach for
security to install packet filters to check for malformed packets
[@tian2019lbm].

I don't know where to put this question so I'm gonna put it here. I am trying to
make a page fault handler that serves physical memory from a pre-allocated
physical memory region. To do that, I allocate memory at boot time using
`pt->fa->falloc()` and store the physical address. I then extended `ukvmem` to
introduce a custom VMA type to register my page fault handler. E.g.,

```c
static int vma_op_custom_fault(__unused struct uk_vma *vma,
                                     struct uk_vm_fault *fault)
{
  __paddr_t paddr = get_allocated_paddr();
  /* initialize memory  */
 fault->paddr = paddr;
  return 0;
}
```

However, for some reason, memory write does not go through, and I got junk data
when reading from the mapped address. Here is a simple test case:

```c
 va = __VADDR_ANY;
 uk_vma_map_custom(vas, &va, 0x10000, PROT_RW, UK_VMA_MAP_UNINITIALIZED,
    NULL);
```

#daily

# Message to unikraft

Regarding page table isolation. I plan to first implement the features we
discussed earlier, randomization and page table unmapping/sealing.

Randomization

- Currently the page table's virtual addresses are direct-mapped by
  `pgarch_pt_map` and `pgarch_pt_unmap`. We probably only need to provide an
  alternative implementation that map to a random address.
- To support this, we may use a secondary direct-mapped area address that is
  randomized at boot time.
- Another approach is to use the heap memory space to map the page table
  addresses. The addresses are naturally randomized by the heap allocator.

Page-table unmapping/sealing

- We need to keep track of the virtual addresses of the page table, then unmap
  them when the page table update is finished, then re-map them on page faults
  or page table updates.
- I guess we can insert a hook in `pg_pt_alloc` used to allocate the page table
  to collect the page table virtual addresses in a list. We can then insert the
  code to unmap/remap these pages where the page table is accessed.
  - I see only 4 main entry points of the page table: `pg_page_mapx`,
    `pg_page_split`, `pg_page_setattr`, and `pg_page_unmmap`.
- How are the direct-mapped pages mapped? I don't see the direct-mapped pages
  being mapped in the source.

#daily

# Outline

Today I asked Hajeong to give his feedbacks on the document for positioning my
paper [this](https://ssnote.skku.edu/C8eOyrK1Q9K4Rog0uXldbw?both). Mainly, the
content can be summarized in a this table:

| Approaches                                                   | Works                        | Overheads                                                | Non-Intrusive\* | Kernel & User | Unmodified binaries | Leverage CVM opportunities | Paging SC | Ciphertext SC             | cache SC                       |
| ------------------------------------------------------------ | ---------------------------- | -------------------------------------------------------- | --------------- | ------------- | ------------------- | -------------------------- | --------- | ------------------------- | ------------------------------ |
| Hardware paging isolation                                    | (Invisipage, Sanctum,...)    | Low                                                      | No              | Yes           | No                  | No                         | Yes       | Yes                       | No                             |
| Security monitor                                             | (eOPF)                       | Medium?                                                  | No              | Yes           | Yes                 | No                         | Yes       | Yes (theoretically, eOPF) | Yes (eOPF)                     |
| Compiler-based obfuscation                                   | (Obfuscuro, Klotski, Obelix) | Very High                                                | Yes             | No            | No                  | No                         | Yes       | Yes (Obelix)              | Yes (Obfuscuro)                |
| Dynamic + static binary instrumentation                      | (Cipherfix)                  | High                                                     | Yes             | No            | Yes                 | No                         | No        | Yes                       | No                             |
| IngonitOS: OS-level design leveraging direct hardware access | **IngonitOS**                | Low ~ High (Reasonable baseline + Configurable security) | Yes             | Yes           | Yes                 | Yes                        | Yes       | Yes\*                     | Yes\* (Based on configuration) |

He then changed it to something more simple (and maybe more clear). Main
feedbacks was:

- Use of ambiguous words (full-system, intrusive)
- "Leverage CVM opportunities" is unclear
- Why do we need to compare against hardware-based approaches?
- Put what is the most important upfront. E.g., people would care about security
  first.

More lessons:

- Respect the reader. Don't assume they will read the explanation, table should
  be self-explanatory.
- Beautify it. Find ways to beautify, even when it is a draft. Advisor is also a
  reader.
- Comparison target: choose reasonable ones. E.g., directly relevant works.

notes.title: AMD Secure Encrypted Virtualization (SEV)
notes.body:
#sev #virtualization #tee #amd

AMD's Secure Encrypted Virtualization (SEV) enables TEEs at the granularity of
virtual machines.

# Memory encryption

The CPU employs a secure processor (SP) that transparently encrypts/decrypts
data when they are written into the memory pages of the encrypted VMs.

Encryption is performed with a per-cVM key maintained by the CPU,c called the VM
encryption key (VEK). It is indexed by the ASID of the VM.

A flag called the c-bit indicates whether a page should be encrypted or not. The
location of the c-bit may be different depending on the platform. The Linux's
support for SEV check for the c-bit location using `CPUID 8000_001F[EBX]`.
(`get_sev_encryption_bit` in `x86/boot/compressed/mem_encrypt.S`).

## Behavior

AMD manual, volume 2, 15.34.5:

> Memory access on behalf of instruction fetches and guest page table walks are
> always treated as private, regardless of the software value of the C-bit.

In other words, implicit memory accesses performed by the hardware are always
private (maybe prefetching is an exception). Making instruction fetches private
prevents the host from injecting code into the virtual machine. Making the page
table walk private prevents the host from tampering with the Guest mapping.
However, this is insufficient, due to the unprotected gPA->hPA mapping, as shown
in some papers (@morbitzer2018severed). SEV-SNP remedied this issue by
protecting this mapping.

This may have two implications in implementing kernel:

- Before the software writes into the code page, (e. Howeverg., before
  relocation), the c-bit of those pages must be set (#need-verifivation),
- Software operations on the page table must be careful, since sometimes c-bit
  may consume physical address bits.

## Interaction between host and guest PTEs

The c-bit is stored in _both_ the host PTEs and the guest PTEs. Its effect is
determined from the combination of the two c-bit in gPT and NPT.

|               | host c-bit                 |                            |
| ------------- | -------------------------- | -------------------------- |
| guest c-bit   | 0                          | 1                          |
| ------------- | -------------------------- | -------------------------- |
| 0             | not encrypted              | encrypted with host key    |
| 1             | encrypted with guest key   | encrypted with guest key   |

29/03/96

5:6:7

## SEV-ES

The original design of SEV does not encrypt the VM states upon VM exit. This
leads to attacks that can extract information from the VM based on the register
state.

SEV-Encrypted State (ES) solve this issue by also encrypting the VM states upon
VMEXIT. It splits the virtual machine control block (VMCB) into two areas, a
control area and a save area (VMSA). The VMSA is encrypted with the VEK upon
VMEXIT.

## Automatic and non-automatic exits

Now, every exit from the guest into the hypervisor (`VMEXIT`) is categorized
into Automatic Exit (AE) and Non-automatic Exit (NAE).

AE consists of basically all interrupts that are trigger by the hypervisor.
Since these interrupt does not require knowledge of VM register state, all of VM
registers will be encrypted and stored into the VMSA.

NAE are the remaining exits, i.e., faults triggered by the VM. Faults can be
triggered by the hardware exception such as page fault, or executing a privilege
instruction (e.g., write into CR3). In this case, the guest might want to share
some register states with the hypervisor.

Hence, a `VC` exception (VMM Communication Exception) is generated by the CPU,
with the cauuse of exception. The VM then invoke the handler to handle the
fault. The handler can copy the selected VM registers into a shared page, called
the Guest Hypervisor Communication Block (GHCB), which is non-encrypted. It then
triggers an AE with a call to `VMGEXIT`, so that the host can serve the fault.

# SEV-SNP

## Mapping integrity protection

SEV-Secure Nested Paging (SNP) adds integrity protection to SEV, that protect
the encrypted pages from replaying (replaced with an old page), being mapped to
two regions, and being remapped.

It uses an Reseve Page Mapping (RMP), which is a table maintained by the
hardware to keep the mapping metatada for each physical pages. All memory write
accesses look up the RMP to verify the mapping correctness.

Even with the RMP mapping protection, a malicious VMM could still tammper with
the permission flags in the page table entries @qin2023protecting. For instance,
a malicious hypervisor can overwrite the present bit in the NPT, that indicate
wheter the page is inside memory. When the VM access the page, a nested page
fault will be trigger.

## VMPL

SEV-SNP also includes the Virtual Machine Privilege Level (VMPL) security
mechanism. It adds privilege levels within the encrypted VM.

Hecate @ge2022hecate uses this feature to implement an in-VM hypervisor that
handle the VM-VMM interactions for an unmodified, un-enlighteneda OS. It puts
the hypervisor in VMPL layer 0, and the guest VM in VMPL level 4, then have the
VMM forwards all faults into the in-VM VMM for handling.

# I/O operations in SEV

See [[zmt276jl]].

# Related notes

- [[d3nt6uix]]
- [[s16ct1rj]]

# Memory encryption

The CPU employs a secure processor (SP) that transparently encrypts/decrypts
data when they are written into the memory pages of the encrypted VMs.

Encryption is performed with a per-cVM key maintained by the CPU,c called the VM
encryption key (VEK). It is indexed by the ASID of the VM.

A flag called the c-bit indicates whether a page should be encrypted or not. The
location of the c-bit may be different depending on the platform. The Linux's
support for SEV check for the c-bit location using `CPUID 8000_001F[EBX]`.
(`get_sev_encryption_bit` in `x86/boot/compressed/mem_encrypt.S`).

## Behavior

AMD manual, volume 2, 15.34.5:

> Memory access on behalf of instruction fetches and guest page table walks are
> always treated as private, regardless of the software value of the C-bit.

In other words, implicit memory accesses performed by the hardware are always
private (maybe prefetching is an exception). Making instruction fetches private
prevents the host from injecting code into the virtual machine. Making the page
table walk private prevents the host from tampering with the Guest mapping.
However, this is insufficient, due to the unprotected gPA->hPA mapping, as shown
in some papers (@morbitzer2018severed). SEV-SNP remedied this issue by
protecting this mapping.

This may have two implications in implementing kernel:

- Before the software writes into the code page, (e. Howeverg., before
  relocation), the c-bit of those pages must be set (#need-verifivation),
- Software operations on the page table must be careful, since sometimes c-bit
  may consume physical address bits.

## Interaction between host and guest PTEs

The c-bit is stored in _both_ the host PTEs and the guest PTEs. Its effect is
determined from the combination of the two c-bit in gPT and NPT.

|               | host c-bit                 |                            |
| ------------- | -------------------------- | -------------------------- |
| guest c-bit   | 0                          | 1                          |
| ------------- | -------------------------- | -------------------------- |
| 0             | not encrypted              | encrypted with host key    |
| 1             | encrypted with guest key   | encrypted with guest key   |

29/03/96

5:6:7

## SEV-ES

The original design of SEV does not encrypt the VM states upon VM exit. This
leads to attacks that can extract information from the VM based on the register
state.

SEV-Encrypted State (ES) solve this issue by also encrypting the VM states upon
VMEXIT. It splits the virtual machine control block (VMCB) into two areas, a
control area and a save area (VMSA). The VMSA is encrypted with the VEK upon
VMEXIT.

## Automatic and non-automatic exits

Now, every exit from the guest into the hypervisor (`VMEXIT`) is categorized
into Automatic Exit (AE) and Non-automatic Exit (NAE).

AE consists of basically all interrupts that are trigger by the hypervisor.
Since these interrupt does not require knowledge of VM register state, all of VM
registers will be encrypted and stored into the VMSA.

NAE are the remaining exits, i.e., faults triggered by the VM. Faults can be
triggered by the hardware exception such as page fault, or executing a privilege
instruction (e.g., write into CR3). In this case, the guest might want to share
some register states with the hypervisor.

Hence, a `VC` exception (VMM Communication Exception) is generated by the CPU,
with the cauuse of exception. The VM then invoke the handler to handle the
fault. The handler can copy the selected VM registers into a shared page, called
the Guest Hypervisor Communication Block (GHCB), which is non-encrypted. It then
triggers an AE with a call to `VMGEXIT`, so that the host can serve the fault.

# SEV-SNP

## Mapping integrity protection

SEV-Secure Nested Paging (SNP) adds integrity protection to SEV, that protect
the encrypted pages from replaying (replaced with an old page), being mapped to
two regions, and being remapped.

It uses an Reseve Page Mapping (RMP), which is a table maintained by the
hardware to keep the mapping metatada for each physical pages. All memory write
accesses look up the RMP to verify the mapping correctness.

Even with the RMP mapping protection, a malicious VMM could still tammper with
the permission flags in the page table entries @qin2023protecting. For instance,
a malicious hypervisor can overwrite the present bit in the NPT, that indicate
wheter the page is inside memory. When the VM access the page, a nested page
fault will be trigger.

## VMPL

SEV-SNP also includes the Virtual Machine Privilege Level (VMPL) security
mechanism. It adds privilege levels within the encrypted VM.

Hecate @ge2022hecate uses this feature to implement an in-VM hypervisor that
handle the VM-VMM interactions for an unmodified, un-enlighteneda OS. It puts
the hypervisor in VMPL layer 0, and the guest VM in VMPL level 4, then have the
VMM forwards all faults into the in-VM VMM for handling.

# I/O operations in SEV

See [[zmt276jl]].

notes.title: Accessing user memory from Kernel
notes.body:
#linux

Linux provides `__user` annotation to mark userspace pointers. _Transfer
functions_ such as `copy_from_user` can only operate on those pointers. User
pointers are always compared against userspace address space to avoid kernel
pointers. An example of `get_user`:

```assembly
.text
ENTRY(__get_user_1)
    mov PER_CPU_VAR(current_task), %_ASM_DX
    cmp TASK_addr_limit(%_ASM_DX),%_ASM_AX
    jae bad_get_user
    ASM_STAC
1:  movzbl (%_ASM_AX),%edx
    xor %eax,%eax
    ASM_CLAC
    ret
ENDPROC(__get_user_1)

bad_get_user:
    xor %edx,%edx
    mov $(-EFAULT),%_ASM_AX
    ASM_CLAC
    ret
END(bad_get_user)

_ASM_EXTABLE(1b,bad_get_user)
```

The first two instructions check the pointer against the process descriptor to
make sure it's not pointer from usersapce. Then it disable SMAP (ASM_STAC) and
access userspace memory (at 1: block)

notes.title: Address translation / virtual memory overheads
notes.body:
#os #architecture

Virtual memory abstraction [[eqbigndi]] enable easy programming model through
MMU support and address translation.

HOwever, Address address translation creates non-trivials overheads
[@yan2019translation] that came from two main sources:

- The OS needs to handle page faults in the software.
- The CPU's MMU needs to walk the page table, which requires multiple memory
  accesses (in case of TLB miss) of up to 5 page table levels.

## Increasing TLB size

Modern architectures cope with this overhead by increasing the TLB size.
However, this approach is not be scalable. Even with thousands of entries, they
are still three magnitude less than required [@gupta2021rebooting].

## Huge pages

Using huge pages copes with address translation is by increasing memory ranges
covered by the TLB entries.

- Using huge pages requires continuous physical memory that requires the OS to
  spend significant effort to defragment.
- Huge page are difficult to use without internal fragmentation
  [@gupta2021rebooting].
- Is a leaky abstraction. It is costly / difficult to provide huge page
  transparently so program is required to explicitly request them .

## Hardware changes

Changes in hardware are proposed to reduce address translation overheads
[@gupta2021rebooting, @yan2019translation].

## Software Replacement

CARAT [@suchy2022carat] proposed using compiler-inserted checks to replace the
MMU-provided access control.

notes.title: Adrenaline helps remembering
notes.body:
#cognitive

Emotionally significants experiences tend to be remembered well.

Studies [@mcintyre2007adrenal] has shown hormones (epinephrine, glucocorticoids)
released by the adrenal gland enhance memory consodilation and object
recognition training (rats and human). However, it is not only the hormones by
themself causing this effect, but there have to be emotional arousal
[@mcintyre2007adrenal].

Because of this, it might be a good advice to spike your adrenaline after
learning something to boost long-term retention. This can be achieved through
cold shock or exercises.

notes.title: Asynchronous vs synchronous IPC
notes.lead:
Commonly Inter Process Communication primitives comes in the form of synchronous
and asynchronous.
notes.body:
Commonly Inter Process Communication primitives comes in the form of synchronous
and asynchronous.

In Linux, IPC primitives allows implementing both, with blocking and
non-blocking FD operations. When you call `read` on a file descriptor that is
blocking (`O_NONBLOCKING` not set), the the calling thread will be blocked (the
thread is de-scheduled) until there is data inside the FD. For non-blocking
calls, `read` will simply return `EAGAIN`.

## In Microkernels

On IPC-heavy system like microkenrels, the choice matters a lot. An IPC in the
microkernel require a synchronous system call to switch to the microkernel,
where the microkernel can schedule the target service [[i2blyo37]].

Synchronous IPC are also better for the security, they may be made resistant to
DOS attacks.

However, the costs of synchronous IPC becomes a bottleneck in modern computing
with emphasis multiprocessing, which motivates modern optimization techniques
[[i2blyo37]].

notes.title: Autarky: Closing controlled channels with self-paging enclaves
notes.body:
#literature #sgx #controlled-channel

@orenbach2020autarky

# Positioning

The paper's main argument against the previous work is that a _practical_
solution for the control channels for SGX must be backward compatible with
existing x86 software, and also the OS. Hence, solutions that employ two
separate page tables, such as [@aga2019invisipage], and [@costan2016sanctum] are
not practical as they require changes to even the host OS. On the other hand,
other software-only defenses (at the time of the paper, there are @shih2017tsgx,
and [@oleksenko2018varys]) restrict the usability as forbid demand paging, have
huge overheads, and are also susceptible to non-page-fault attacks that use the
dirty bits [[1yhmh234]].

## Non-intrusive hardware changes

While introducing hardware changes, the work aims to do it in the least
intrusive manner. It tries to _change only the same path that SGX's mechanisms
change in x86 architectures_. This includes (1) SGX-specific checks that are
performed after PTE checks during enclave mode, and (2) AEX page fault procedure
([[taztx2mo]]).

For the above reason, the paper also argues against using separated enclave page
tables, as used in many clean-slate designs for TEEs ([@costan2016sanctum]).
Such mechanisms (1) require complex collaborative page management between the
host OS and the enclave ([@aga2019invisipage]), (2) requires new protection to
prevent the enclave from mapping arbitrary host memory, and (3) require
significant changes to the performance-critical portions of the MMU (e.g., the
MMU need to be changed to differentiate between normal state and enclave states,
and use different page tables).

The paper suggests three small changes to the current SGX scheme. First, instead
of just masking the page offset in AEX page faults, the entire address is masked
so that it is invisible to the host.

Second, an additional flag is introduced in the TCS called the _pending
exception flag_. The bit is set when there is a page fault occurs. `ERESUME`
will fail when this flag is set, and `EENTER` clears the flag. Hence, the OS is
forced to use `EENTER` as a trusted enclave entry point that handles page
faults. This handler can use the SSA frame to determine if an exception has
occurred, and take appropriate actions defined by the software, such as
ORAM-based paging. After, `EEXIT` passes the control back the the OS page fault
handler, which can now use `ERESUME`, since the pending exception flag is
cleared. On the OS side, the EPC paging ISA (`EWB`, `ELDU`) can be used to
perform enclave paging as normal.

```
   
   Set pending exception flag   Check SSA frame to detect fault 
   
                                             
                                             
Enclave      Page fault      Self-paging Runtime        Fault handled
                   AEX     EENTER           Paging syscalls              
                                                             EEXIT       ERESUME
OS      Page fault handler       Autarky-aware syscalls        Page fault handler
                               
                  
                   Unset pending exception 
                  

```

The paper also suggested a _fast path_ to omit the expensive context switching
between enclave and OS (that includes TLB flushing): on a page fault, the CPU
saves the context to the SSA, increments the SSA stack, and automatically
performs enclave entry to the entry point.

Third, to prevent the OS from using the dirty bit to infer page accesses, by
adding a security check to _SGX-specific checks_ the PTE is fetched. The check
simply enforces that the access and dirty bit must be already set. This
essentially renders these bits useless.

_SUMMARY_: Together, these changes enable three properties: first, with the
faulting address hidden, all-natural page faults are hidden from the host.
Second, with the pending exception flag, all paging-related events must be
notified to the enclave, so that there are no unexpected page faults. Third, the
dirty/access bit in the PTE is irrelevant to an enclave's memory access pattern.

## Software components

With the above changes, page faults on the EPC pages are hidden from the host.
However, it renders demand-paging impossible, since the host does not know about
faulting address. Autarky implements a _self-paging_ runtime on top of the
Graphine-SGX library OS so that the enclave can directly request the host OS for
paging operations.

First, Autarky split pages into OS-managed pages and enclave-managed pages.

For the first type, the access patterns are not considered sensitive, so the
management of these pages is up to the OS. While it is not specified in the
paper, maybe the paging runtime just forwards the faulting addresses of those
pages to the OS's page fault handler, so that the OS can use `EWB`/`ELDU` to
swap these pages in/out.

For the second type, page faults on these pages are considered hostile (except
for the clustering and bounded leakage policiese), and the enclave may terminate
the execution when there are faults. Hence, the OS must make sure that these
pages are _memory-resident while the enclave is executing_. To reclaim these
pages, the only option for the OS is to _swap the entire enclave out_.

On enclave-managed pages, the enclave may perform _self-paging_ with the added
system called `ay_fetch_pages` and `ay_evict_pages` that require the OS to
fetch/evict a list of pages from/to the EPC memory.

Three different policies are introduced that make use of the self-paging.

### ORAM

ORAM policy enhanced the ORAM instrumentations used in [@orenbach2019cosmix]. In
the original, ever memory instruction is instrumented to perform an ORAM access.
Since enclave-managed pages are protected from the host, the paper uses those
pages as a cache for ORAM. Hence, the new instrumentation looks for the page in
the cache first, before requesting expensive ORAM accesses.

This policy requires program instrumentations on memory access to perform ORAM
accesses.

### Clustering

The second policy clusters pages together so that a group of pages is always
fetched and evicted together. On a fault, the runtime requests all pages in a
cluster together. Clustering a group of pages hides the access pattern within a
cluster.

This policy requires changes to the application to identify code/data pages that
belong to a cluster.

### Rate-limiting

The final policy aims to support unmodified applications. It clusters the code
pages and introduces a page fault rate. Since there is no trusted clock inside
the enclave, the rate is calculated using other events instead. The authors
suggest using different rate metrics for each application; for example, page

notes.rawContent:
# Autarky: Closing controlled channels with self-paging enclaves

#literature #sgx #controlled-channel

@orenbach2020autarky

# Positioning

The paper's main argument against the previous work is that a _practical_
solution for the control channels for SGX must be backward compatible with
existing x86 software, and also the OS. Hence, solutions that employ two
separate page tables, such as [@aga2019invisipage], and [@costan2016sanctum] are
not practical as they require changes to even the host OS. On the other hand,
other software-only defenses (at the time of the paper, there are @shih2017tsgx,
and [@oleksenko2018varys]) restrict the usability as forbid demand paging, have
huge overheads, and are also susceptible to non-page-fault attacks that use the
dirty bits [[1yhmh234]].

## Non-intrusive hardware changes

While introducing hardware changes, the work aims to do it in the least
intrusive manner. It tries to _change only the same path that SGX's mechanisms
change in x86 architectures_. This includes (1) SGX-specific checks that are
performed after PTE checks during enclave mode, and (2) AEX page fault procedure
([[taztx2mo]]).

For the above reason, the paper also argues against using separated enclave page
tables, as used in many clean-slate designs for TEEs ([@costan2016sanctum]).
Such mechanisms (1) require complex collaborative page management between the
host OS and the enclave ([@aga2019invisipage]), (2) requires new protection to
prevent the enclave from mapping arbitrary host memory, and (3) require
significant changes to the performance-critical portions of the MMU (e.g., the
MMU need to be changed to differentiate between normal state and enclave states,
and use different page tables).

The paper suggests three small changes to the current SGX scheme. First, instead
of just masking the page offset in AEX page faults, the entire address is masked
so that it is invisible to the host.

Second, an additional flag is introduced in the TCS called the _pending
exception flag_. The bit is set when there is a page fault occurs. `ERESUME`
will fail when this flag is set, and `EENTER` clears the flag. Hence, the OS is
forced to use `EENTER` as a trusted enclave entry point that handles page
faults. This handler can use the SSA frame to determine if an exception has
occurred, and take appropriate actions defined by the software, such as
ORAM-based paging. After, `EEXIT` passes the control back the the OS page fault
handler, which can now use `ERESUME`, since the pending exception flag is
cleared. On the OS side, the EPC paging ISA (`EWB`, `ELDU`) can be used to
perform enclave paging as normal.

```
   
   Set pending exception flag   Check SSA frame to detect fault 
   
                                             
                                             
Enclave      Page fault      Self-paging Runtime        Fault handled
                   AEX     EENTER           Paging syscalls              
                                                             EEXIT       ERESUME
OS      Page fault handler       Autarky-aware syscalls        Page fault handler
                               
                  
                   Unset pending exception 
                  

```

The paper also suggested a _fast path_ to omit the expensive context switching
between enclave and OS (that includes TLB flushing): on a page fault, the CPU
saves the context to the SSA, increments the SSA stack, and automatically
performs enclave entry to the entry point.

Third, to prevent the OS from using the dirty bit to infer page accesses, by
adding a security check to _SGX-specific checks_ the PTE is fetched. The check
simply enforces that the access and dirty bit must be already set. This
essentially renders these bits useless.

_SUMMARY_: Together, these changes enable three properties: first, with the
faulting address hidden, all-natural page faults are hidden from the host.
Second, with the pending exception flag, all paging-related events must be
notified to the enclave, so that there are no unexpected page faults. Third, the
dirty/access bit in the PTE is irrelevant to an enclave's memory access pattern.

## Software components

With the above changes, page faults on the EPC pages are hidden from the host.
However, it renders demand-paging impossible, since the host does not know about
faulting address. Autarky implements a _self-paging_ runtime on top of the
Graphine-SGX library OS so that the enclave can directly request the host OS for
paging operations.

First, Autarky split pages into OS-managed pages and enclave-managed pages.

For the first type, the access patterns are not considered sensitive, so the
management of these pages is up to the OS. While it is not specified in the
paper, maybe the paging runtime just forwards the faulting addresses of those
pages to the OS's page fault handler, so that the OS can use `EWB`/`ELDU` to
swap these pages in/out.

For the second type, page faults on these pages are considered hostile (except
for the clustering and bounded leakage policiese), and the enclave may terminate
the execution when there are faults. Hence, the OS must make sure that these
pages are _memory-resident while the enclave is executing_. To reclaim these
pages, the only option for the OS is to _swap the entire enclave out_.

On enclave-managed pages, the enclave may perform _self-paging_ with the added
system called `ay_fetch_pages` and `ay_evict_pages` that require the OS to
fetch/evict a list of pages from/to the EPC memory.

Three different policies are introduced that make use of the self-paging.

### ORAM

ORAM policy enhanced the ORAM instrumentations used in [@orenbach2019cosmix]. In
the original, ever memory instruction is instrumented to perform an ORAM access.
Since enclave-managed pages are protected from the host, the paper uses those
pages as a cache for ORAM. Hence, the new instrumentation looks for the page in
the cache first, before requesting expensive ORAM accesses.

This policy requires program instrumentations on memory access to perform ORAM
accesses.

### Clustering

The second policy clusters pages together so that a group of pages is always
fetched and evicted together. On a fault, the runtime requests all pages in a
cluster together. Clustering a group of pages hides the access pattern within a
cluster.

This policy requires changes to the application to identify code/data pages that
belong to a cluster.

### Rate-limiting

The final policy aims to support unmodified applications. It clusters the code
pages and introduces a page fault rate. Since there is no trusted clock inside
the enclave, the rate is calculated using other events instead. The authors
suggest using different rate metrics for each application; for example, page
fault per socket received, or page fault per memory allocations.

notes.title: Avoiding Failure in ORAM
notes.body:
#oram

In most ORAM algorithms, there is a chance of failure, due to the stash
overflowing.

## Reversed path eviction

In the eviction phase (Path ORAM and Ring ORAM), blocks are pushed to the tree
in the reversed order, starting from the leaves, and ending at the root. The
reason for intuition is that blocks at higher levels are more likely to
intersect with another path, leading to higher chance the block is pushed to the
tree.

For example, in a tree with 3 levels, nodes on the last level (leaf nodes)
correspond to only one path. Nodes on the second level can be evicted on 2 paths
(1 can be evicted on paths 0 and 1). Nodes on the first level can be evicted on
any path.

```none
              0
          1       2
      3       4       5
---------------------------
path: 0       1       2
```

## Background Eviction

[@ren2013design] proposed _background eviction_, which happens when the free
slots in the stash becomes smaller than $Height*BucketSize$, i.e., the minimum
free blocks required in an ORAM access.

Dummy accesses are performed on random a path that read blocks into the stash,
and opportunistically place blocks back into the tree. At worst, if the path is
already filled, or no blocks can be evicted from the stash, the path is simply
written back to the tree.

Background eviction access pattern is identical to an ORAM access, so attackers
cannot know when background eviction happens.

notes.title: Binary Rewriting is Hard
notes.lead:
Rewriting binaries is useful for security instrumentations, like CFI
[@zhang2013control], randomization [@koo2018compilerassisted].
notes.body:
Rewriting binaries is useful for security instrumentations, like CFI
[@zhang2013control], randomization [@koo2018compilerassisted].

Two issues when modifying a compiled binary.

- **Unintended instructions**: First, it might mess up the instruction
  boundaries and lead to unintended instructions.
- **Addressing**: If you insert additional code, the instruction address now
  changes, which mess up existing IP-relative code.

## Reassembling

For correct rewriting, a common approach is _reassembling_
[@wang2015reassembleable]: perform rewriting on an intermediate representation,
than compile it back into a fresh binary/basic block. Still it is an error-prone
process [@kim2023reassembly].

## Control flow reconstruction

You may modify the binary layout for more flexible rewriting policies. However,
now you must also perform control-flow recovery, to cope with the changes in the
address space. This is a difficult problem in binary analysis [[fps6sygk]].

Many techniques avoid this by leveraging probes-based binary rewriting
[[4yeegysq]].

## Probing

Rewriting that _poke_ / probe the binary code with other code does not change
the address layout, so is safe with PC-relative code. For example, Kprobes
[[1mhpx5ds]] insert `int3` and `jmp` insertion to probe parts of the kernel.

Also, simple rewrite, e.g., absolute address replacement in absolute jumps
[@ren2022dynamic], where target instruction has the same size and semantics of
the replaced instruction, are safe to be performed. Another example is to
rewrite syscall instructions for hooking syscall [@yasukata2023zpoline].
Occasions for simple rewrite are hard to come by and require expert analysis.

Two issues:

1. **Overheads**: `int3` probes are slow, so `jmp` are much more desired.
   However, `jmp` are 5-bytes, which may overwrite more instructions if the
   probe target is smaller than 5. Instruction punning [[jejw1spb]] is a
   technique to maximize the `jmp` probes.
2. **Preserving original execution:** We must ensure that the probed (replaced)
   instruction is correctly executed:
   - If possible, the instruction should be single-stepped
   - Certain instructions must be emulated if they cannot be single-stepped
     properly.
   - Other relative-addressing must have their PC relative adjusted
3. **Multi-threading**: Probing on one thread leads to invalid execution on
   other threads if they access partially-modified code. Stop-the-world is not
   scalable, and dynamically probing code on-the-fly require careful
   considerations [@chamith2016living].

notes.title: Binary Rewriting without Control-flow Recovery
notes.body:
#binary-analysis

Many rewriting approaches requires control-flow recovery to that they can
relocate RIP-relative code [[n43kyyfh]] to different locations. However, these
approaches are not robust and require heuristics and assumptions. However,
control-flow recovery is generally undecidable [[fps6sygk]].

A class of binary rewriting techniques focus on not using control-flow (sub
function) recovery techniques for more robustness
[@chamith2017instruction,@duck2020binary]. To this end, probe-based techniques,
especially instruction punning [[jejw1spb]] does not requires fine-grained
control-flow recovery since they do not modify the binary layout.

notes.title: Binary disassembly
notes.body:
#binary

Disassembly is the process of analyzing a compiled binary, which consists of
sequences of opcodes, into a list of known instructions with known semantics.

## Techniques

Disassembly may be performed through two techniques: (1) linear scan through the
text section of the program, or by (2) recursively disassembling while
constructing the control flow.

### Linear scan

Linear scan may be confused by _gaps_ in the program, e.g., paddings for
alignment, [@zhang2013control], which it may incorrectly treat as instructions
(e.g., unintended instruction problem [[kskzr2l4]]).

### Recursive disassembly

Recursive disassembly tries to reconstruct the control flow graph of the
binaries. On each new control flow transfer instructions, e.g., `call foo`, it
adds the target (`foo`) to the list of identified entry list, and disassemble
the target.

Caveats includes how to accurately determine indirect jump targets, and
non-explicit control flow transfers like interrupts [[kskzr2l4]].

notes.title: Bit manipulation tricks
notes.body:
#programming #kernel #c #cxx



# Creating a mask with all N bit set
```c
#define mask(N) (1UL << N) - 1
```
For example, if N = 3, then the first shift will create ` 1000`. When subtracted by 1 bit, the result will be `111`

# Checking if the Nth bit is set in a word

```c
#define check(word, N) (word & (1UL << N))
```
# Clearing the Nth bit
```c
#define clear(word, N) (word & ~(1UL << N))
```
# Check if a number is power of 2 
The key property is that if the number is the power of 2, it only has m bit set in the leftmost bit.
```c
#define is_power_of_2(n) ((n & (n - 1)) == 0)
```

notes.title: Bits in page table entries
notes.body:
#os #architecture


# Present flag
The *present* flag indicates that there exists a backing physical frame for this page table entry. If the present bit is not set, a page fault will be triggered.


# Access and dirty flags
On x86, bit 5 is the *accessed* flag, and bit 6 is the *dirty* flag.

The _accessed_ flag is set when a page is accessed by the CPU during address translation. The *dirty* flag is set when a page is written by the CPU. 

After being set, these flags need to be cleared by the software.

The dirty bit indicates that page must be written to the disk before the frame can be reused for other pages. Else, the page content is unchanged, so it is safe to reuse the page [standford-paging].

# References
- @2023intel
- [standford-paging](https://web.stanford.edu/~ouster/cgi-bin/cs140-winter16/lecture.php?topic=paging)

notes.title: Bounce buffers
notes.lead:
Bounce buffers are buffers for bouncing data, e.g., containing parts of data
that must be isolated, commonly for security purposes.
notes.body:
Bounce buffers are buffers for bouncing data, e.g., containing parts of data
that must be isolated, commonly for security purposes.

## Confidential I/O

In CVMs, the host cannot freely access the guest memory, so the guest must
cooperate in sharing I/O data. It achieve this by maintaining a region of shared
(public) memory for bounce buffers (or SWIOTLB), to be used for shared data
structures, such as virtio descriptors/rings.

The guest's networking stack copies memory from its internal buffers into this
bounce buffers's shared memory, and the host must map this memory into the
hardware for DMA.

## Containing untrusted devices

Certain devices are commonly considered untrusted, e.g., USB. in the case of
virtualization, devices may also be configured to perform illegal actions by the
VM [[3eot91og]].

While IOMMU [[hxm4jt6e]] is useful in containing untrusted memory, it is
page-granular ([@markuze2016true]), so the shared page with the device might
contain other kernel memory.

The solution is to create a temporary buffer and to share data with the device.
Only the necessary portion of the data is copied to this bounce buffer.

More:

- <https://lore.kernel.org/linux-iommu/f416c0dc-a82b-f608-4c6a-c2441b417bfb@linux.intel.com/T/>
- <https://lwn.net/Articles/786558/>
- <https://docs.kernel.org/core-api/swiotlb.html>

## Overheads

Bounce buffering create redundant memory copies that reduce I/O performance.
This contributes to overheads in confidetial I/O [[68nms906]] and also
virtualized I/O [[3eot91og]].

notes.title: Branch Prediction
notes.body:
#architecture

In CPU architectures, branch prediction is an optimization that allows the CPU
to skip the instruction pipeline on certain indirect/conditional jumps
instructions. It does so by predicting the likely outcome of the jump target
using data from the previous execution.

Modern processor uses a Branch Target Buffer (BTB) structure to cache the recent
jump results for prediction.

```asm
                           Branch Target Buffer
                                                                       correct
                           | IP    | Target |                             commit
0xa00: jmp [eax] | 0xa00 | 0xd00  | speculative execution    results
                          | 0xd00 | 0xf00  |                           
                                                                        revert
                                                        actual       incorrect
                   CPU pipeline (slow)  target


```

Return instruction is also a type of indirect jump, as its target reles on the
instruction on the stack. The CPU keeps a separated mechanism called the Return
Stack Buffer (RSB) that is similar to the BTB to track the target of return
values.

The above naive BTB implementation probably cause a lot of misprediction since
it does not care about certain branch patterns, e.g., if taken vs. not taken
pattern is 0101, it would always mispredict. Modern CPUs additionally includes
some ways to make up for program patterns.

Early processors like the P1 [@fog2016microarchitecture] includes a Saturating
Counter in the BTB.

Later processors use a more complecated method of pattern matching. They
additionally keep a Pattern History Table that map certain branching pattern to
the next likely outcome. For example, the BTB might maintain a branch's history
as 0101. The branch prediction unit use this pattern to look up the pattern
history table to predict the likely conditional results, e.g., 1. This result is
combined with the target value in the BTB to predict the next instruction (the
following instruction or the one in the BTB).

```asm
| IP   | Target | Branch History |
| ---- | ------ | -------------- |
| 0xab | 0xcd   | 1100           |
| 0xcd | 0xef   | 0101           |
                  
          Prediction
                                              
                       | Pattern | Output |   
                       | ------- | ------ |

                        | 1100    | 1      |
```

notes.rawContent:
# Branch Prediction

#architecture

In CPU architectures, branch prediction is an optimization that allows the CPU
to skip the instruction pipeline on certain indirect/conditional jumps
instructions. It does so by predicting the likely outcome of the jump target
using data from the previous execution.

Modern processor uses a Branch Target Buffer (BTB) structure to cache the recent
jump results for prediction.

```asm
                           Branch Target Buffer
                                                                       correct
                           | IP    | Target |                             commit
0xa00: jmp [eax] | 0xa00 | 0xd00  | speculative execution    results
                          | 0xd00 | 0xf00  |                           
                                                                        revert
                                                        actual       incorrect
                   CPU pipeline (slow)  target


```

Return instruction is also a type of indirect jump, as its target reles on the
instruction on the stack. The CPU keeps a separated mechanism called the Return
Stack Buffer (RSB) that is similar to the BTB to track the target of return
values.

The above naive BTB implementation probably cause a lot of misprediction since
it does not care about certain branch patterns, e.g., if taken vs. not taken
pattern is 0101, it would always mispredict. Modern CPUs additionally includes
some ways to make up for program patterns.

Early processors like the P1 [@fog2016microarchitecture] includes a Saturating
Counter in the BTB.

Later processors use a more complecated method of pattern matching. They
additionally keep a Pattern History Table that map certain branching pattern to
the next likely outcome. For example, the BTB might maintain a branch's history
as 0101. The branch prediction unit use this pattern to look up the pattern
history table to predict the likely conditional results, e.g., 1. This result is
combined with the target value in the BTB to predict the next instruction (the
following instruction or the one in the BTB).

```asm
| IP   | Target | Branch History |
| ---- | ------ | -------------- |
| 0xab | 0xcd   | 1100           |
| 0xcd | 0xef   | 0101           |
                  
          Prediction
                                              
                       | Pattern | Output |   
                       | ------- | ------ |   
                   | 0101    | 0      |
                        | 1100    | 1      |
```

## Security Issues

Spectre attacks shows that branch predictor might be mistrained such that
speculative execution is performed incorrectly [@kocher2019spectre

notes.title: CAP-VMs: Capability-Based Isolation and Sharing in the Cloud
notes.body:
#literature #capabilities #vm #os #cheri #ipc #libos #container
[@sartakov2022capvms]

## One sentence summary

The paper built a container-like isolation abstraction on top of CHERI
architecture for efficient sharing on and isolation.

## Context

### Containers vs. Virtual machines

Containers and Virtual machines both have disadvantages for implementing
isolation and sharing. See [[h3manv25]].

### Capabilities

Cheri capabilities enable in-process compartmentalization with the hybrid
capability model.

### Contributions

This paper proposed the best of both world with CHERI capabilities: _cVM_, new
VM-like abstraction for cloud isolation with efficient, single-address space
sharing.

- Communication between cVMs bypass the OS with new in-process capabilities
  abstractions for trusted safe ipc.
- Compatible with existing applications with the _hybrid_ capability model. Only
  a subset of libC, the library OS, and the intravisor need to be
  capability-aware.
- No namespace isolation is required, since the isolation boundary is in-process
  through capabilities. The OS is only needed for I/O, synchronization,
  execution context (similar to a VM).

## System overview

The system introduces 2 layers of isolation. A _library OS_ provides namespace
isolation for and provides OS primitives for the cVMs. An _intravisor_ manage
cVMs instances, enable cross-communication and other primitives.

The program interacts with the libOS through the syscall interface provided by
the musl libc. LibOS interact with intravisor through hostcall interface. Both
interfaces are capability-ware.

## APIs

A set of APIs is provided to manage cVM and facilitate their communications.

CP_FILE-based interfaces enable file-like access to other cVM memory through
capability invocation. A cVM registers shared memory to be shared across other
cVMs with a key. Other cVMs read and write into the CP-FILE obtained with the
same key.

CP_CALL-based interfaces allows for capability-based registration and invocation
of external functions.

## Capability management

The system revoke CAP_STORE from capabilities, preventing them from being stored
into memory outside of the intra.

notes.title: Capabilities
notes.body:
Capabilities

## Why capabilities exists

The capability model enable two properties in systems

- Flexibility of systems policies [[c4icaua4]] through separation of mechanism
  and policies [[8113ygxd]]. That is, the reference monitor only needs to
  validate the references using simple mechanisms. The policies themselves are
  embedded in the capabilities.
- Avoid the problem of confused deputy [[y9wu5ut7]]. In a capability system, all
  subjects must be explicitly given the access rights, so that there is no
  _ambient authorities_.

## More

- [Capability Theory by Sound Bytes](http://www.cap-lore.com/CapTheory/): Notes
  of capabilities by [[j19hdkto]] himself.
- Eros [@shapiro1999eros] is one of the first application of capability for
  kernel access control, which laid the foundation for modern microkernels
  [@klein2009sel4]
- [[y0z8fhtd]]

notes.title: Code-centric vs. Data-centric Compartmentalization
notes.body:
#compartmentalization

For the selection of compartmentalization subjects (a part of defining
compartmentalization policy [[7r5okim8]]), the strategies can be broadly
classified into three types, _data-centric_ and _code-centric_ and _hybrid_
[@lefeuvre2024sok].

- Code-centric approaches treat the code (instructions, functions) as the
  subject of compartmentalization. Any input data results in the policies. E.g.,
  libjpeg is known to be buggy, so all of its code must be in a separated
  compartment
- Data-centric approaches starts from the data (resource) and select code unit
  that interacts with such data as the subject. Since pieces of data have
  _lifetime_ (e.g., network packets), this results in the selection of subject
  having _temporal_ property. E.g., the code that interacts with network packets
  must be isolated.
  - [@lefeuvre2024sok] noted that this model blends well with the process/thread
    model, e.g., isolated threads are spawned to process a specific packet.
- Hybrid approaches combine the two, akin to object-oriented programming. E.g.,
  capability systems like CHERI allows the subject of isolation to be both data
  and code.

## When to use which

- Code-centric is better when the source of distrust can be directed toward a
  specific piece of code.
- Data-centric is better on programs that either
  - Handle multiple information flows, e.g., same code accessing both trusted
    and untrusted components.lefeuvre2024sok
  - Source of distrust can be directed toward a source of input (i.e., network
    packets, stdin).
- Hybrid approach, well, achieves a the mix of the two.

notes.title: Compartment-aware hardening
notes.body:
#fleeting #idea

## Background

Software defenses such as DFI/CPI/CFI see the program at one unit.

Efforts in compartmentalization brings the boundary to within the program.

## Main arguments

Existing software hardening techniques are not compartment-aware, so they miss
classes of attacks on compartment interfaces.

Making them compartment-aware requires some static / runtime analysis at the
boundary.

## Compartment-aware CFI

CFI type matching + compartment-aware narrowing for cross-compartment indirect
calls e.g., A site can only call type B from compartment X.

## Compartment-aware DFI

Assuming data isolation between domains. DFI only for cross-domain objects.

- Use static analysis to determine subset of sensitive objects.
- We enforce DFI on them.

This has sanitizing effect, remove CIV.

notes.title: Confidential I/O Taxes
notes.body:
#tee #os #io

There are overheads for using I/O in TEEs due to several factors.

## CVMs

I/O in CVMs are predominantly performed through the `virtio` paravirtualized
drivers due to its performance [@li2023bifrost].

Even then, there are certain "taxes" that slow down the I/O performance in CVMs.

### Bounce buffering

Since the host cannot directly access the private memory of the CVM, bounce
buffers located in shared memory [[jj89s7vj]] must be maintained by the _guest_.
To send any packets to the hardware, the guest must copy the data from its
private memory into the bounce buffer, and the host must maps the bounce buffer
into the device (NIC) for it to perform DMA. The reversed direction is the
similar. This contributes 19.45% of CPU cycles [@li2023bifrost]

[@li2023bifrost] noticed that TLS itself must perform memory copies during
encryption and decryption, and requiring private memory and decryption at the
same time is not optimal. An optimization that directly decrypt data into shared
memory and encrypt data from shared memory into private is added.

### VMExits

VMExits is known to be more expensive on CVMs compared to normal VMs
[[eczmc02q]], since it have to encrypt VM states and perform security checks.
Asynchronous interrupt posting mechansisms supported by hardware kind of make
this less of an issue [@li2023bifrost].

### Packet processing

Packet processing is another major cost, but this is not unique to confidential
I/O. Still, one optimization can be made to _reassemble packets_ in the
host-side backend driver into larger packets [@li2023bifrost].

### Non-CVM costs

More: [[471vf8vr]].

notes.title: Conflict of security interest in cloud services
notes.lead: Modern cloud service models provide services where the clients can
notes.body:
Modern cloud service models provide services where the clients can

- Send their data and code to be executed on the cloud (e.g.,
  Infrastructure-as-a-Service, Function-as-a-Service)
- send their data to be processed by an external services and receive the
  results. Examples of this can be seen in can be AI prediction services, LLM
  chatbots, NaaS [[ijh22i54]]

A more detail threat model analysis reveal that there is a conflict in security
interest between the parties. Considering the cloud users and the cloud are
mutually distrusting.

- The clients want to keep their data and code secret from the cloud service
- The cloud want to isolate the client code so that they cannot attack the
  system
- a more complex scenarios can be seen in multi-party AI computation:
  - one party provide code
  - one party provide data
  - one party provide execution environment

Trusted execution technologies

notes.title: Confused deputy
notes.body:
#capabilities #compartmentalization

In securing any system, it is inevitable that there are some components that
have higher privilege than others. A confused deputy happens when a
high-privilege system is tricked into performing a certain action on behalf of a
lower-privilege system.

The confused deputy problem requires rethinking about access control, and leads
to development of capabilities-based access control models, where access through
resources are given to each user through _capabilities_ [[khi9ihj9]].

## An example

The example used in the original paper [@hardy1988confused] is a compiler
program. A user invoke the compiler with the name of the input file to compile a
program, and also an output file to receive statistics. The compiler is given
the authority to write into its home directory. Let's say there is another file
in the home directory of the compiler that contains the billing information. A
malicious user of the compiler can invoke it to trick the compiler into writing
into the billing file since it is within the authority of the compiler.

In a sense, confused deputy happens due to the _ambient authority_. In the
compiler case, the compiler user obtains more authority than needed (access to
the whole home directory) to perform it job (read input, write output).

To solve this problem, a naive solution would be to switch the authority of the
compiler (through some system call) to that of the invoked. However, such a
system would lead to complexity when there is a high amount of authorities, and
also hard to generalize.

## Interface vulnerabilities

Interface vulnerabilities is a manifestation of confused deputy problem, where
different mutually distrusting entities interacts with each other through
exposed interfaces [@lefeuvre2023assessing]. More: [[yef2w9yc]].

notes.title: Containers vs. Virtual machines
notes.body:
#vm #container #cloud #ipc #os #virtualization

Containers and virtual machines ([[s16ct1rj]]) are two main isolation primitives
when it come to cloud isolation.

Virtual machines provides strong isolation between application components with a
small TCB: a small hypervisor need to be trusted. However, data sharing between
VMs is challenging and commonly have high overheads [@yasukata2023exitless].

On the other hand, containers allows application components to share the
underlying OS. This enable richer OS-backed IPC mechanisms for better data
sharing. This comes at the cost of larger TCB: a shared OS have to implement
namespace isolation and complex IPC primitives [@sartakov2022capvms].

notes.title: Controlled-channel Attacks
notes.body:
#attack #tee #sgx

Controlled-channel attack refers to attacks launched by the higher-privilege system against the lower-privilege one. The confidential lower-privilege system (SGX, VM) lacks capabilities (e.g., paging, file access), and needs to request the higher-privilege system (OS, hypervisor) for resources. The higher-privilege can use this controlled channel to monitor the lower-privilege one. This scenario happens especially in a confidential execution environment, where the protected program does not trust the underlying infrastructure, or cloud service provider (CSP).

notes.title: Controlled-channel attacks against SEV
notes.body:
#controlled-channel #side-channel #sev #tee

# Nested page fault side-channels
Virtualization hardware enables two-stage translation process from gVA to gPA, and from gPA to hPA through the nested page table (NPT) ([[d3nt6uix]]). This is the same in SEV. Although there is no official documentation, many paper indicate that hypervisor cannot intercept guest page faults (gPF) and look for faulting address.

Page fault attacks in SEV is similar to the controlled-channel attacks on SGX @xu2015controlledchannel. 
The hypervisor can unset the present bit (`P` bit) in the NPT for particular physical pages, such that nested page fault (NPF) will be generated when the page is accessed by the VM, which the hypervisor can capture and analyze.

# IO events

notes.title: Cost of IPC in microkernels and Optimizations
notes.body:
#microkernel #sel4 #ipc #kpti #os

In microkernels such as sel4, kernel code is kept to the minimum, and most of
the system services such as file system, and networking are moved into the
userspace as a _system server_. Applications that use those services need to
invoke them through _IPC_. Since those services are in the userspace in
different address spaces, an IPC would consist of:

1. Privilege switch to from application the kernel
2. Process switch to the callee process
3. Privilege switch to the callee
4. Process switch back to the caller process
5. Privilege switch from kernel to the caller

## Overhead analysis

[@gu2020harmonizing] (see [[2a7l7odo]]) performed a study of the source of
overheads of such IPC. SQLite3 is run on Zircon and seL4 microkernels. It is
found that total IPC time is 79% the time on Zircon and 44% of the time on seL4
(with KPTI).

The overheads of each component are also studied in the following table.

| Parts            | w/o KPTI | w/ KPTI        |
| ---------------- | -------- | -------------- |
| Privilege switch | 158      | 690            |
| Process switch   | 295      | included above |
| Others           | 277      | 320            |
| Total            | 730      | 1010           |

_Privilege switch_ is the overhead of a syscall instruction. _Process switch_ is
mostly changing the page table by writing into the CR3 register (about 270
cycles). With KPTI enabled, an additional page table switch needs to be added to
every user-to-kernel privilege switch, which adds another layer of overheads.
Additionally, there are also other types of overheads such as permission checks,
and capabilities checks.

## Optimizations

One way to reduce this cost is to leverage fast in-process switching to isolate
the process from the microkernel. [@mi2019skybridge] uses VMFUNC and Underbridge
uses intel PKU [@gu2020harmonizing].

The other trend is to leverage the power of multicore with asynchronous IPC
mechanisms [@soares2010flexsc], that run each process in a separated thread and
use pooling. This lead to better per-core locality and also get rid of the
context switching costs.

notes.title: DPDK vs. io_uring
notes.body:
#os #io

DPDK (Data Plane Development Kit) [[qctx04tc]] and `io_uring` are both
techniques to improve I/O performance in Linux by reducing the amount of context
switches. `io_uring` implements new syscalls for asynchronous I/O in the kernel.

## Performance

Generally DPDK outperforms `io_uring` and traditional networking thanks to its
kernel bypass [@vorbrodt2023analyzing].

However, `io_uring` and traditional networking stack perform better under when
the requests exceed the maximum capabilities, potentially due to having access
to kernel resouces [@vorbrodt2023analyzing].

## Security

DPDK sacrifies safety, requiring it to trust other users of the devices, or
expecting some safe multiplexor [@hedayati2019hodor]. ([[qctx04tc]])

`io_uring` and traditional networking stack let the kernel be the sole user of
the networking devices, allowing safe multiplexing across users.

notes.title: Danish conference Visa from Korea
notes.body:
#visa



You have to go through the Swedish embassy in Korea. The process is the same as applying for a Swedish visa.


# Documents

- have a passport that is valid for at least three months after the visa has expired, was issued in the last ten years and has at least two empty pages
- be able to describe the purpose of your visit
- have an invitation from the company or the person that is arranging the conference
- have money to support yourself and for the return trip home (Sweden also requires you to have 450 SEK for each day you stay in Sweden, which can also be paid for by the company that has invited you)
- have an individual medical travel insurance that covers all costs that may arise in connection with emergency medical treatment, urgent medical care or transportation to your home country for medical reasons (the insurance must cover costs of at least 30,000 EUR and be valid for all Schengen countries)
- show that you intend to leave Sweden and the Schengen area on the last day before the visa expires
- a photograph that is in passport format and taken with you facing the camera and which is not older than six months
- other documents that the embassy may require.


# Process
1. Apply online at https://www.migrationsverket.se/
2. Wait for result

# References
- https://www.migrationsverket.se/English/Private-individuals/Visiting-Sweden/Visit-Sweden-for-less-than-90-days---apply-for-a-visa.html

notes.title: Data binary representation
notes.lead:
In the age of internet, data must be transferred as efficiently as possible.
While text-based format dominated the web, e.g., RESTful APIs, it is not best
known for efficiency.
notes.body:
In the age of internet, data must be transferred as efficiently as possible.
While text-based format dominated the web, e.g., RESTful APIs, it is not best
known for efficiency.

- Plain text is space in-efficient. E.g., ASCII uses 7 bits to encode
  characters, while UTF-8 uses 1 to 4 bytes. Moreover, encoding long numbers
  like `10000000` is more compact in binary (1/4/8 bytes), while in text, it
  requires one byte for each character.
- Parsing text is inefficient (compared to parsing binary data). Parsing text
  require you to decode each character, then parse the character into data
  format.

There has been specifications to encode data directly into the binary format.

Useful data usually has _structures_, e.g., C `struct`, Rust `Vec`, so there
must be ways to encode them into binary while preserving structures and a way to
decode the binary blob into structures on the receiving end. Encoding
programming language data structures into binary is called _serializing_ , and
the other direction is called _deserializing_.

## Examples

- **cbor** is a compact binary representation for JSON.
- **Protocol Buffer (protobuf)** is Google's proposal for language-neutral,
  platform-neutral to structured data serialization/deserialization.
- **Flat Buffers** allow deserializing parts of the binary.

notes.title: Data sharing in VMs
notes.body:
#os #virtualization

There are two main methods for sharing data across VMs: using (1) shared memory
mappings or (2) hypervisor delegation. Shared memory mappings is considered
insecure, as both party can freely access the underlying data. On the other
hand, hypervisor delegation provides controlled access to shared data, but
requires costly VMEXITs. With a exitless mechanism that enforce isolation like
VMFUNC, (2) can provide both efficiency and isolation [@yasukata2023exitless].

Other issues with Cross-VM sharing the significant different between the
programming model of VM sharing and existing process-based IPC interfaces.
Hence, VM programs must be specifically adapted to use the low-level shared
memory mappings and hypervisor delegation. A common research pattern is to
provides an POSIX environment (unikernels/library OSes/containers
[@sartakov2022capvms],[@belay2012dune]) with support for rich IPC interfaces,
while keeping isolation boundaries of VMs.

> the operator know if the VM can debug.

notes.title: Deconstructing Software Compartmentalization
notes.body:
#compartmentalization

Software compartmentalization is a common research goal, but usually each of the
paper propose a new compartmentalization models (e.g., two-level, capabilities),
or new methods, new automation, new mechanisms, which makes it difficult to
evaluate their impact in the grand picture.

[@lefeuvre2024sok] introduced a taxonomy model to classify them. A
compartmentalization model need to resolve three challenges:

- **Policy definition methods (PDM)**. How to determine what is the policy to
  enforce. This reflect the methodology for selecting the subject and resources
  (e.g., see [[x9zetwej]]) for isolation, which may be performed manually or
  automatically.
- **Compartmentalization abstractions**. How to represent compartmentalization
  as a programming abstraction. This deals with how the programmer interact with
  the compartmentalization model (through config files, program annotations,
  etc.).
- **Compartmentalization mechanism**. How compartmentalization is enforced at
  runtime.

The model allow comparision of some seemingly unrelated approaches and also
reveal the missing pieces in these models.

notes.title: Dependence analysis
notes.body:
#analysis #compartmentalization

Dependence analysis find dependencies between programs points, such that
security policies can be enforced.

One common use case is to split programs, where all code blocks that related to
particular variables are moved to another program. To do this, there must be a
dependence analysis to find all code dependencies.

Another use case is to enforce valid data flow between program points to prevent
data-only attacks [[gbkc1fhy]]. For instance, defenses such as DFI and WIT use
dependence analysis to find all valid writer to a variable.

## Data-flow-based

Program compartmentalization techniques such as [@liu2017ptrsplit] often relies
on dependence analysis to determine the data flow between code locations, then
separate the program based code dependency. Commonly it is done by first
identify all _control dependencies_ of instructions, which form a reachable
control-flow graph.

Then, on the reachable control-flow graph, data-flow analysis is performed to
find data dependencies.

### Limitations

[@lu2023practical] ([[4zdjxws6]]) notes several limitations with such an
approach:

First, control dependencies does not reflect all data dependencies.

- System calls and interrupt handlers is invoked at arbitrary time, and don't
  have a control-flow edge on the CFG.
- Two control-independent functions can still pass data through global variables
  or shared memory. Second, data-flow analysis requires points-to analysis
  - Points-to analysis is expensive can cannot scale to large programs
  - Points-to analysis produces a large amount of false positive

## Module-based and type-based

[@lu2023practical] describes a more simplified version of dependence analysis,
where only the dependence between modules (program source files) are analyzed. A
coarse-grained data-flow graph between modules can be analyzed based on data
flow observed in (1) cross-module function calls and (2) access to global
variables.

It uses construct type dependencies between modules to limit the possible data
flows. E.g., an object from module M1 of type A is able to flow to to module M2.

notes.title: Design
notes.body:
---

## How to find likely invariants?

- Place probes into SVF
  - record constraints and their derivations
  - when the points-to sets are updated
- Heuristics: trigger alerts in snowballing scenarios
  - Too many objects added to points-to set (100~1000)
  - Too many types added to points-to set (10~50)
- Perform analysis on NGINX webserver and minimal linux kernel
- Manually inspect the alerts

---

## Likely invariants summary

- Arbitrary pointer arithmetic (cleanly deal with pointer arithmetics)
  > _Assumes pointer arithmetic only points to array_
- Positive weight cycles (prevent loss of field sensitivity)
  > _Assumes PWC does not occur at runtime_
- Context sensitivity (selective context senstivity)
  > _Assumes certain pointer arguments are not updated_

---

## Arbitrary pointer arithmetics

![w:720 center](./pointerarith.png)

---

## Context sensitivity

![w:720 center](./contextsensitivity.png)

---

# Kd-powered CFI

![center](./cfi.png)

---

## Memory view switch integrity

- Must prevent attacker from arbitrarily switch memory view
- Use secure gates to switch between memory views
- On legitimate switch sites, push a secret value to the stack
- Validate the value in the call gate

---

## Security

- Reduce indirect call targets through IGO
- Attacker now have to
  1. Use restricted CFI version
  2. Bypass the monitor to enable more permissive CFI (i.e., data only-attack)
  - \> Maybe hard to do because the conditions are not directly related to the
    target function pointer

---

# Evaluation

- How Kaleidoscope impacts PTA precision?
- How much each of the likely invariant contribute?
- Runtime overheads of runtime monitoring?
- Are the likely invariants valid?

---

## Setup

- 10 _small_ applications: MbedTLS, Lighttpd, Memcached, LibPNG, ...

---

## Precision improvement

- Point-to set sizes distribution

![center](./pts-eval.png)

> $13.15 \times$ reduction in average PTS size.

---

## Impact on CFI

![center](./cfi-eval.png)

---

## Performance overheads

- Throughput evaluations

![center](./throughput-eval.png)

> $5.45\%$ throughput reduction on average.

## Pointer analysis


---

## Andersen-style analysis

- Based on solving **constraints**
- e.g., `p = &x` $\rightarrow x \in pts(p)$ (Addr-Of constraint)
- e.g., `p = q` $\rightarrow pts(p) = pts (p) \cup pts(q)$ (Copy constraint)

![w:720 center](constraints.png)

---

## Precision challenges in PTA

- Scalability vs. Precisions
- Directly affect security applications like CFI
- Why: Imprecision
  - Context sensitivity: Distinguish each calling context.
    - e.g., `p1 = malloc(512);` vs. `p2 = malloc(256);`
  - Field sensitivity: Distinguishing fields of struct objects
    - e.g., `p = &(obj->field);`
  - Flow sensitivity: Distinguish order of execution
  - Path sensitivity: Distinguish branch conditions

1. Imprecisions have a _snowballing effect_

![w:720 center](./mbedtls.png)

## Key observations

1. Imprecisions have a _snowballing effect_

   - \> It is important to detect and stop these imprecision early

   E.g., _points-to set increases 10-fold after adding a constraint_.

   - E.g., pointer `p` is unlikely to point a certain object `obj`

- Choice of invariant:
  - Should significantly impact PTS
  - Should be limited in number

- Enhance PTS-based security applications
- Employ different **Memory views** (i.e., different instrumented binary

notes.title: Designing Capability-based Interfaces
notes.lead:
When designing interfaces from the ground up for safety, capabilities
[[khi9ihj9]] is a good choice.
notes.body:
When designing interfaces from the ground up for safety, capabilities
[[khi9ihj9]] is a good choice.

- Nova [@nova] is a "micro-hypervisor" inspired by capabilities in microkernels.

To redesign an interface to use capabilities, how the system handle resources
must be redesigned from the ground up.

The most difficult part is to **encapsulate** (1) resources and (2) resources
operations into types of **objects**. Here, an **object** both identifies the
resource to access (e.g., file), and the authorization (e.g., R/W/X). Think
object-oriented programming, where a class definition define both data and the
operation that can be performed on the data.

> [!example] UNIX File descriptors
>
> For example, in Unix, a file in the file system is encapsulated into a **file
> object**. Each process is given control to the file descriptors (capability
> token) that both identify the file object and represent authority over it.
> Operations performed on the file descriptor only require the file descriptor
> itself for authorization.

Now, the decision of which resources to encapsulate is highly dependent on the
goal of the system.

> [!example] Microkernels
>
> For example, microkernels [[sn99wrm0]] goals is to provide a safe time-sharing
> environment. They encapsulate types of objects for scheduling (time resource),
> virtual address space (memory resource) and IPC (communication). Providing an
> IPC abstraction allow highly composable systems and also allow flexible
> policies. E.g., the right to perform IPC may be passed from processes to
> another.

> [!example] NOVA
>
> NOVA [@steinberg2010nova] is a _microhypervisor_ to that tried to minimize TCB
> of hypervisor. It offloads most of VMM functionalities into userspace in lieu
> of a microkernel-like architecture for the hypervisor. The objects of
> encapsulation are:
>
> - **Protection domains**: abstraction from processes and VMs, for managing
>   memory, I/O permissions, and capabilities
> - **Execution context**: abstraction from vCPU and threads.
> - **Scheduling context**: the time slice given to a VM execution context
> - **Portal**: Gateways for communication between VM and VMMs
> - **Semaphore**: Synchronization between execution contexts

The object handles are then given to the subjects (threads, processes,
compartments). There must be a security monitor that validate the **capability
invocations** to check for permissions and also allowing access to the resource.
For more on implementation: [[y0z8fhtd]].
