notes.title: Detecting bugs in Rust
notes.body:
#area #rust

## Rudra

Rudra [@bae2021rudra] analyzes Rust HIR and MIR to have a _generic type-aware_
analysis. Generic type-awareness is necessary because certain bugs only happen
for the implementation of specific types.

```rust
fn double_drop<T> (mut val: T){
  unsafe {ptr::drop_in_place(&mut val);}
  drop(val);
}
double_drop(123); // no violation since drop on an integer is no-op
double_drop(vec![1, 2, 3]); // double-free happens
```

More specifically, Rudra considers a generic function having bugs, if any of the
instantiation has a safety bug.

## Unsafe Dataflow Checker

This checker simply find if their exists a dataflow from the start of lifetime
bypass to a suspicious function call. The hope is to find dataflwo from unsafe
into functions that might `panic`, or functions that might implicitly requires
some higher-order invariants (but not upholded by the unsafe caller).

It is suprising that this simple heuristic helps finds a lot of bugs. On the
other hand, it has very high false positive rate (53.3% precision on highest
precision). Moreover, this kind of heuristic is coarse-grained, it does not try
to identify the _root cause_ of the bug, but instead finds pattern that commonly
have bugs,and rely on the programmer instead instead to filter out the bugs.

There are two heuristics used by this checker, to determine the lifetime bypass
locations, and to determine suspicious function calls.

### Suspicious function calls

This check marks all _unresolvable generic function call_ as suspicious.
Unresolvable functions are functions that their definitions cannot be found
without precise type parameters. An example was:

```rust
fn foo<T>(reader: T)
  where T: Reader {
  reader::read();
}

```

In this case, to know the definition of `read()`, the type of `reader` must be
known, but it is available at runtime. On the other hand, `Vec<T>::push()` has
implementation of `push()` implemeted for all possible type `T`.

The author finds that those unresolable function are where programmers usually
make mistake, since they have to _speculate_ about the function behaviors.

### Lifetime bypass locations

There are six classes of lifetime bypasses:

- Unintialized value (created by extending `Vec` with `Vec::set_len()`)
- Duplicating lifetime (e.g., `mem::read()`)
- Overwriting memory (e.g., `mem::write`)
- Copying values (e.g., buffer copy) (this has the effect of duplicating and
  overwriting)
- Transmuting a type and its lifetime
- Converting a pointer to a reference

Rudra uses three precision settings:

- High precision only detect uninitialized values (e.g., `Vec::set_len()`)
- Medium precision setting additionally find lifetime bypass using `read()`,
  `write()`, `copy()`.
- Low precision setting find all `transmute()`a and raw pointer casting.

notes.title: Dynamic Loader as OS extension
notes.body:
#os

Modern software are mostly delivered as dynamically linked code (up to 99% of
binaries in Ubuntu). Dynamic libraries are chosen due to their easy of
maintenance, and also to the of the fear of "license contamination" where some
licenses like GPL force statically linked code to also have the same license.

At the same time, if is often that the dynamic loader need to be modified, for
instance, to automatically harden binaries [@zhang2013control] and enforce
security policies like isolation [@ghosn2021enclosure,@sartakov2021cubicleos],
debloating [@quach2018debloating,@porter2020blankit] and rerandomization
[@williams-king2016shuffler]. Adapting these modifications into the official
loader is unlikely due to maintenance costs.

At the same time, the OS dynamic linker govern the operating system
[@castes2023dynamic]. In dynamic program, the dynamic loader (pointed to by
`.interp` section in the ELF) is always executed before the program (e.g., on
`execve` system call). It has control over all program execution on the OS, and
can serve as a "narrow waist" to extend the OS.

Given these premise, a recent trend is to introduce extensible interfaces to the
OS dynamic loader/linker [@castes2023dynamic,@ren2022dynamic]. iFed
[@castes2023dynamic] adds a pass-based framework based on glibc loader
([[26npf1xb]]) to implement transformations on the library. Spindl
[@castes2023dynamic] reimagine the OS dynamic linker with facilities to
implement extensions.

notes.title: Emulating x86 push and pop on ARM
notes.body:
#assembly #arm

Although there is no push and pop instructions, Arm support addressing modes
that can both update and address memory. This can be used to implement stack
push and pop More concretely, post-indexing is used for push, and pre-indexing
is used for pop

Pre-indexing update the address register _before_ the store, which is
essentially the same as x86 push instruction that decrease the stack pointer,
then store the value.

```asm
str x1, [sp, -#16]!
```

Pre-index addressing update the address register after the store.

```asm
ldr x1, [sp] #16
```

Source:

- [Addressing Lab](https://www.cs.uregina.ca/Links/class-info/301/ARM-addressing/lecture.html)

notes.title: Exitless system calls for SGX
notes.body:
#sgx #tee #system-call #performance #rpc

To perform system calls in SGX, the enclave must perform enclave exit and enter through `EEXIT`, `EENTER`. It is found that these two instructions have heavy overheads of about 3,300 and 3,800 cycles @orenbach2017eleos. This is much higher than the overheads of a normal system call, about 250 cycles.

Another cost of SGX is due to page fault, since in an enclave exit also need to be triggered.

# Elos
## RPC for system calls
@orenbach2017eleos proposed using RPC instead to serve system calls on an enclave. The system employs a separated thread in the untrusted part of the application to serve system call. Ocalls in SGX for serving system call is then replaced with RPC to the system call-serving threads. 

Moreover, the system uses Intel Cache Allocation Technology (CAT) to allocate only 25% of the cache to the worker thread, while keeping 75% cache. This avoids LLC pollution.

@orenbach2020autarky, @orenbach2019cosmix also adapts this.

## User-managed virtual memory 
Elos also includes a fine-grained page management system to avoid enclave exit on page faults. The idea is to cache the commonly used pages in the untrusted memory, and serve from it first, instead of relying on the OS.

## Related note
[[taztx2mo]]

notes.title: Exokernel
notes.lead:
Exokernel is a kernel architecture that maximize application direct access to
the hardware, while removing all the cost of kernel abstractions. In this model,
application are implemented as **library operating systems** that implement all
the abstractions. The exokernel tasks is to ensure safe multiplexing of hardware
resources by allocating resources to the applications.
notes.body:
Exokernel is a kernel architecture that maximize application direct access to
the hardware, while removing all the cost of kernel abstractions. In this model,
application are implemented as **library operating systems** that implement all
the abstractions. The exokernel tasks is to ensure safe multiplexing of hardware
resources by allocating resources to the applications.

The original exokernel paper [@exokernel] describes a _secure binding_ mechanism
that bind the application to an instance of resource, such that the resource may
be accessed at runtime without checking costs. This mechanism is highly
resource-specific and is unlikely generalizable.

- For memory, a binding may be made by caching the address translation inside
  the TLB/page table.
- For networking, the exokernel proposed using packet filtering to deliver
  packets to the correct applications.
- File system might be exposed as in-memory pages.
- Some specific hardware provide binding between the owner and the resource,
  e.g., frame buffer hardware.

This concept is different from microkernels [[sn99wrm0]] in that there is almost
no abstractions in exokernels. However, implementation of the secure binding
mechanisms is very dependent on the type of resource. It is unclear if the
approach results in a smaller TCB compared to microkernels. E.g., a network
filter is required in the kernel for multiplexing of networking.

notes.title: Exploiting Unprotected I/O Operations in AMDs Secure Encrypted Virtualization
notes.body:
#literature #side-channel #sev @li2019exploiting

# Summary

The paper proposes an attack method that exploits the unprotected I/O operations
in AMD SEV. Here, _unprotected_ means that the I/O operations (MMIO and DMA)
must be performed on unencrypted memory that is visible by the hypervisor. The
paper shows that by replacing ciphertext blocks in the VM memory, the hypervisor
can create trick the VM into encrypting and decrypting arbitrary data, hence
encryption/decryption oracles.

# Attack overview

## Encryption oracle

The target of the attack is an SSH service running inside a cVM. While the ssh
packets are encrypted, due to unprotected I/O [[zmt276jl]], the hypervisor can
observe and modify the TCP and IP headers.

Briefly, the attack finds the _encrypted_ page that contains the packet to be
sent over the I/O channel. It then replaces the encrypted header (16B) with
another encrypted block of data, right before the packet is copied into the
unencrypted I/O memory observable by the hypervisor. Using this method, a
decryption oracle is built that allows the decryption of any memory block.

The attack is performed in three steps: pattern matching, ciphertext
replacement, and packet recovery.

### Pattern matching

Pattern matching stage uses the nested page fault side-channel [[qq4qcbos]] to
determine which pages are being accessed when the VM serves the SSH packet. The
hypervisor first sends an SSH packet to the VM, then clears the present bits in
the NPT PTEs. It collects the sequences of page fault accesses to build a
_signature_ of the page accessed from the time of receiving the request, to the
time right before sending the packet. It then uses this signature to determine
the page containing the `sk_buff` structure that contains the packet.

### Ciphertext replacement

Ciphertext replacement replaces the ciphertext inside the header of the SSH
packet and recovers the plaintext result. Since SEV's memory encryption applies
a teak function based on the physical address, steps need to be done to recover
plaintext: Assuming the ciphertext $c$ is copied from the address $P_c$.
Plaintext must be obtained by:

$m = d \oplus  T(hPA((P_{priv}+16))/16*16) \oplus T(P_c)$

Where $d$ is the decrypted text of $c$, T is the tweak function. Essentially,
this negates the effect of the teak of the current address and applies the teak
of the target location.

### Plaintext recovery

The original plaintext must be recovered so that the attack is stealthy. Since
the attack only modifies the header of the SSH packet, which is public, it only
needs to predict the content of the current header (replaced by the attack).
Here, the ID of the packet is increased by 1 after each response, so it adds
that to the response's header.

# Mitigation

The attack in this paper is mitigated by SEV-SNP since the hypervisor cannot
write into encrypted memory anymore.

Since SNP did not exist at the time, the paper also suggests other mitigations.
One of them is to make the VM encrypts the _entire_ packets, and use a trusted
proxy server to decrypt the packets, before forwarding them to the client.

notes.body:
#writing

Sometimes it is hard to *determine what to write* for a particular idea. Using *frameworks* would helps in such cases. 

Generally, following prompts helps: 
- Answering What, why, how
- Give an example
- What is this idea similar to
- What contradicts this idea

Keep in mind:
- Why is this an important issue
- Why reader has to know about this




Other note taking frameworks might helps, such as:

- [[zz3cedu0]]

notes.title: Flat vs. hierarchical notes
notes.body:
#fleeting

# Flat notes
Flat notes make use of hashtag and linking for navigation

## Arguments for flat notes
Flat notes make every notes equally important.

Flat notes is easier for linking.

Easy to maintain. You can create a a grouping of concepts by just inserting a new hashtag.

## Argument agaisnt
Hashtags can be cluttering.

This is related to a good hashtag system.

# Hierarchical notes
Hierarchical notes group notes using folders/directories. It is great when you use a file system to maintain your zettel.

Hierarchical notes is good when the content within the directory is 
(1) well-maintained, 
(2) well-separated: though, this kind of go against the linking your thinking ideologies. 
(3) you need multiple 

## Argument for hierarchical notes
Visually separated in the file system.

Easy to move around. Though, you rarely need to move your notes.

Support multiple layers of grouping.

```
- Group A
  - Note a.1  
  - Note a.2
  - Group A.1
    - note A.1.1 
- Group B
  - Note b.1
```

## Arguments against
Your conceptual grouping of notes might change over time.

Linking requires an extra indirection (`\[\[directory/note\]\]`). This might be dependent on the note manager you are using.



# Conclusion

If you are sure the grouping of notes is permanent, and you want to clearly and visually separate those notes from the rest, using a directory is fine. For instance, generally Zettlekasten gurus recommends you to separate fleeting, literature, and permanent notes.

For notes where their grouping might change overtime, it is best to use flat notes plus hashtags.

notes.title: Force function inline in LLVM
notes.body:
#llvm #compiler

Inlining with attributes, e.g., `__attribute__((__always_inline__))` is more
like a _suggestion_ to the compiler and does not always work.

`Lib/Transform/Utils/Cloning.h` provide a function call
`InlineFunction(CallInst, ...)` when invoked it would try to inline the call
instruction. This way, a function call site may be reliably inlined.

Inlining with attributes, e.g., `__attribute__((__always_inline__))` is more

notes.title: Foreach pattern in C macro
notes.body:
#c #programming

You can define a foreach macro like this. Useful when iterating over custom
structures.

```c

#define FOREACH(var) for (var = 0; var < PREDEFINED_LEN; var++)

#define FOREACH(var, len) for (var = 0; var < len; var++)

#define FOREACH_TYPE_T(ptr)                                                    \
  for (ptr = begin(); ptr != end(); ptr = get_next_ptr(ptr))
```

notes.title: Fork is an outdated OS abstraction
notes.body:
#os

The `fork` system call clone the context of a process. In the past, `fork` is
useful to quickly setup isolated processes.

A recent opinion is that providing `fork()` as a first-class abstraction in OSes
is more harmful than good [@baumann2019fork] due to its bad
scalability/efficiency and difficulty in supporting single-address-space OSes.

Scalability: Fork is wasteful in its resource useage.

Necessity: `fork()` is not even really essential, since most modern applications
that use fork (Apache, Chrome, PostgreSQL) have Windows port that does not use
fork [@baumann2019fork].

Still, some workloads, nginx, Redis, greatly benefits from it
[@lupu2023nephele].

notes.title: From reading to notes
notes.body:
#reading #notes

[evergreen] describes a 5-step iterative process.

1. Write broad notes, capturing the big idea
2. Write finer-grained notes
3. Connect. Find previous notes and link them together
4. Revisit the broad notes with improved understanding from detailed notes
5. Repeat

## Zettelkasten style

From [zettel]:

- Taking note: Write short, atomic notes during the reading.
- Processing notes:
  1. Pull notes from the book
  2. Cluster notes, let overview emerges
  3. Write notes from clusters
     1. General note per cluster
     2. Detailed notes
     3. Improve general notes with detail notes

## References

[evergreen]:
	https://notes.andymatuschak.org/How_to_process_reading_annotations_into_evergreen_notes
[zettel]: https://zettelkasten.de/posts/create-zettel-from-reading-notes/

notes.title: Git Commit Log is a Manual
notes.body:
#git #programming

The commit log is not only a history into the project. It can be seen as a
manual of how to do something.

- **PR**: How to do X. E.g., X = "implementing a virtio driver".
- **Commit titles**: the steps must be taken. E.g.,
  - > virtio_bus: Add header for `virtio` rings definitions
  - > virtio: Implement PCI capabilities bus discovering
  - > virtio_pci: Implement `virtio_pci` driver
- **Detailed commit text**: Detailed explanations.
- **Code diff**: How it is done.

So, keep your git log clean.

## Implications

- AI models can leverage this for better in-context learning ([Shawn]).
- Also, segmenting your git commits into PRs achieve this goal better.

## Reference

- [Shawn]:
  	https://x.com/narphorium/status/1806778340323512472?s=09&t=NBsImYx9vO2InQpJtca9zQ

notes.title: GitJournal: The missing piece to my note taking workflow
notes.body:
#blog

## Some Background

I have been using [zk](https://github.com/zk-org/zk) for taking notes in plain
markdown. While it lacks features compared to the well-known Obsidian, I prefer
it over tools like Obsidian for the following reasons:

- Using your preferred editor is possible. I am an avid
  [Neovim](https://neovim.io/) user and would prefer to do all of my writing
  with Vim key bindings if possible. I like it so much that I even created a
  [language server](https://github.com/kha-dinh/bibli-ls) to support BibTeX
  citations in my notes.

- Terminal-first workflow. zk's nice [fzf](https://github.com/junegunn/fzf)
  integration allows me to access my notes with just a single keyboard shortcut.
  This enables me to avoid using a mouse in general.

- Lightweight design. I like that zk provides the bare minimum tools for looking
  up your notes and providing editor-agnostic diagnostics highlighting through
  its LSP protocol. This enables me to quickly set up the note-taking workflow
  on any new desktop.

For maintaining my notes, I have a private GitHub repo that I regularly push to.
I prefer this to cloud synchronization due to its simplicity.

## Complaints

One of the pet peeves I have with the terminal + git workflow is that it is
fundamentally difficult to **synchronize** and **access** your notes on mobile
devices. All available options are not ideal.

For synchronization:

- Upload your notes to a cloud service and use
  [syncthing](https://syncthing.net/) to automatically synchronize. This means
  you must keep your notes in two places.

For reading/editing:

- Using a terminal emulator like [termux](https://termux.dev/en/). A keyboard is
  required which is only sometimes available on the go, and setting up is still
  a hassle.
- Directly accessing your notes through GitHub's web interface. This results in
  a terrible editing experience.

In contrast, Obsidian has a dedicated [mobile app](https://obsidian.md/mobile)
that streamlines the experience on both desktop and mobile phones. Obsidian
users might use Obsidian's cloud service or the Obsidian git plugin to maintain
their notes.

## GitJournal

Recently, I encountered the
[GitJournal](https://github.com/GitJournal/GitJournal) mobile application that
solves the aforementioned issues. It simplifies notes synchronization and
editing into a single mobile app:

- Markdown preview/editing support. The app prioritizes support for markdown
  notes in plaintext.
- Simplified git synchronization at the push of a button.
- _Links between notes work_! I can just press on a link, e.g., `[[AkgiO4ax]]`,
  to visit the note. This is partly thanks to zk's use of the file name (a
  random UUID) as notes link.

While there are still a few minor issues, I can live with them:

- The pricing for pro features is a bit steep, so I need some time to decide if
  it's worth it.
- Note UUID generation scheme doesn't match with my zk's note ID system. Still,
  I can edit them when I get to my desktop.

## Conclusion

GitJournal has filled a crucial gap in my note-taking system, allowing me to
maintain the terminal-first, git-based workflow I love on the desktop while
gaining seamless mobile access. It proves that we don't always need to
compromise between power-user preferences and mobile convenience. For those who
prefer lightweight, text-based note-taking tools like zk but want better mobile
integration, GitJournal offers an elegant solution that respects the simplicity
and flexibility of plain markdown files while making them accessible on the go.

  [syncthing](https://syncthing.net/) to automatically synchronize. This means
  you must keep your notes in two places.

For reading/editing:

- Using a terminal emulator like [termux](https://termux.dev/en/). A keyboard is
  required which is only sometimes available on the go, and setting up is still
  a hassle.
- Directly accessing your notes through GitHub's web interface. This results in
  a terrible editing experience.

In contrast, Obsidian has a dedicated [mobile app](https://obsidian.md/mobile)
that streamlines the experience on both desktop and mobile phones. Obsidian
users might use Obsidian's cloud service or the Obsidian git plugin to maintain
their notes.

## GitJournal

Recently, I encountered the
[GitJournal](https://github.com/GitJournal/GitJournal) mobile application that
solves the aforementioned issues. It simplifies notes synchronization and
editing into a single mobile app:

- Markdown preview/editing support. The app prioritizes support for markdown
  notes in plaintext.
- Simplified git synchronization at the push of a button.
- _Links between notes work_! I can just press on a link, e.g., `[[AkgiO4ax]]`,
  to visit the note. This is partly thanks to zk's use of the file name (a
  random UUID) as notes link.

While there are still a few minor issues, I can live with them:

- The pricing for pro features is a bit steep, so I need some time to decide if
  it's worth it.
- Note UUID generation scheme doesn't match with my zk's note ID system. Still,
  I can edit them when I get to my desktop.

## Conclusion

GitJournal has filled a crucial gap in my note-taking system, allowing me to
maintain the terminal-first, git-based workflow I love on the desktop while
gaining seamless mobile access. It proves that we don't always need to
compromise between power-user preferences and mobile convenience. For those who
prefer lightweight, text-based note-taking tools like zk but want better mobile
integration, GitJournal offers an elegant solution that respects the simplicity
and flexibility of plain markdown files while making them accessible on the go.

notes.title: Gramine-TDX Slides
notes.body:
#slides

## Intro

- Confidential computing & CVMs
- Memory encryption & access control prevent direct access
- Now the attack surfaces come the interfaces with the hosts.

## What are the Attack surfaces

- Shared memory. virtio.
- PORT I/O & MMIO.
- CPUID leaves & MSRs.
- Hypercalls. Iago attacks.
- Interrupts. Heckler attacks

## Just harden the interfaces!

- Fuzzing the kernel is time-consuming, best-effort and inconclusive
- A lot of manual effort for hardening
- Huge TCB; 20 M line of code 15,000 configurations

## Solution: Minimizing TCB and attack surfaces

- Minimize TCB size (LoC)
  - Offload non-security operations if possible
  - Reimplement functionalities with security in mind
- Minimize attack surfaces.
  - Turn off unnecessary features
  - Filter out notifications
  - Sanitize inputs

## Approach: Lightweight LibOS

- LibOS: specialized image that contain only the necessary to maintain POSIX
  compatibility
  - Enable running unmodified POSIX applications in SGX
- Gramine (Graphene) & Gramine-SGX

notes.title: Grammar for your concepts note
notes.lead:
Ideas like atomic notes insists that your notes should focus on a single idea,
but often not clearly define what is an "idea" here.
notes.body:
Ideas like atomic notes insists that your notes should focus on a single idea,
but often not clearly define what is an "idea" here.

It seems that what constitute as an idea can be formally defined like how you
define programming language syntaxes.

```bnf
concept = concept relationship concept
        | concept implications
        | idea;
idea    = single
        | composite;
composite = idea vs. idea;
```

For example:

```
Memory encryption vs. Access control
         v        v         v
	idea      vs.      idea
```

## Edited AI generated stuff

Extended Grammar for Conceptual Notes

```c

/* Basic concept structure */
concept     = concept relationship (concept | statement)
            | idea
            ;

/* Relationships - ways concepts connect to other concepts */
relationship    = "connects_to"
                | "depends_on"
                | "leads_to"
                | "influences"
                | "correlates_with"
                | "causes"
                | "contradicts"
                | "exemplifies"    // Concrete example
                | "illustrates"    // Abstract example
                ;

/* Simple statements */
statement   = value_judgment      // e.g., "is bad"
            | factual_claim       // e.g., "increases risk"
            | recommendation      // e.g., "should be avoided"
            ;

/* Core idea representations */
idea        = single_idea
            | composite_idea
            ;

/* Idea types */
single_idea     = statement;
composite_idea  = comparison
                | synthesis
                | categorization
                ;

comparison      = idea "vs." idea;
synthesis       = idea "combined_with" idea;

/* Hierarchical structures */
categorization  = category        // contains subcategories
                | whole          // consists of parts
                | general        // specializes to specifics
                ;

```

test cases:

```
// Basic single ideas
smoking                                              // single_idea
exercise                                             // single_idea

// Simple concept -> statement relationships
smoking implies "is harmful"                         // concept relationship statement
exercise suggests "improves mood"                    // concept relationship statement

// Concept -> concept relationships
smoking causes cancer                                // concept relationship concept
exercise enhances "sleep quality"                    // concept relationship concept

// Chained relationships
smoking causes cancer implies "requires treatment"   // (concept relationship concept) relationship statement

// Composite ideas - comparisons
cardio vs. strength_training                        // comparison
async vs. sync_programming                          // comparison

// Composite ideas - synthesis
frontend combined_with backend                      // synthesis

// Composite ideas - categorization
programming_languages                               // category
  - interpreted_languages                           // subcategory
  - compiled_languages                             // subcategory

human_body                                         // whole
  - cardiovascular_system                          // part
  - nervous_system                                 // part

animal                                            // general
  - mammal                                        // specific
  - reptile                                       // specific

// Complex nested examples
(cardio vs. strength_training) implies "different benefits"    // (comparison) relationship statement

programming_languages influences
  (interpreted_languages vs. compiled_languages)              // concept relationship comparison

(frontend combined_with backend) suggests "full-stack development"  // (synthesis) relationship statement

// Multiple relationships chain
smoking causes cancer contradicts healthy_lifestyle implies "needs change"
  // (concept relationship concept) relationship concept relationship statement
```

notes.title: HYDRA:The Kernel of a Multiprocessor Operating System
notes.body:
#literature #os #capabilities
@wulf1974hydra



## Noteworthy arguments
### Hierarchical layering limits flexibility: See [[c4icaua4]].
However, maintaining order in a non-hierarchical manner is challenging in traditional systems. HYDRA's capability model enable flexibility by rejecting hierarchical structuring. In HYDRA, a *template* define the security checking mechanism of a procedure, and allows a procedure to *derive* higher capabilities from the argument capabilities (belong to the caller). This way, a callee function might have greater capabilities than the caller, but the caller have no way of obtaining those capabilities by itself. This enable invocation of procedures in any orders, as long as the callee adhere to the rules defined by the system designer.

As a downside, such a system must have the support from the kernel. HYDRA uses a kernel-assisted CALL mechanism. The kernel checks for the parameter capabilities with the according to the security requirements. It then derives new capabilities and place it in the callee's environment. Finally, the kernel transfer the control to the callee function.

### Protection (mechanism) should be separated from security (policy)
The paper argue that the protection mechanism does not necessary grant security. Take password for example, the password checking mechanism does not guarantee that the user will use a strong enough password.

Hence, HYDRA aims to provides primitives (mechanisms) to implements the policy (security), but not to provide  the security by itself.

notes.lead:
Hardware are commonly located the lowest in the stack (L2, before physical
layer), but sometimes they provide features that belong to higher levels (L3,
networking). Moreover, for flexibility, many hardware functionalities are
implemented in software as a dedicated service, i.e., [[szlwwqsj]]
notes.body:
Hardware are commonly located the lowest in the stack (L2, before physical
layer), but sometimes they provide features that belong to higher levels (L3,
networking). Moreover, for flexibility, many hardware functionalities are
implemented in software as a dedicated service, i.e., [[szlwwqsj]]

- **Switches** are located at L2 (Data link), which connect devices within a
  local area network (LAN). Switches uses MAC addressing, to route packets
  directly from one machine to another, which put it at L2.
- **Router** is located at L3 (Networking), which connect different networks to
  each other. Since it's at L3, it is aware of IP addresses of source
  destinations. The router determine the most optimal path for the packet to
  travel.
- **Hardware NIC** are at L2 (Data link). This means it is only aware of device
  MAC. The delivering of correct packets into the NIC is handled by the router.
  Through, some NIC is aware of headers of higher layers for better packet
  balancing.

notes.title: Harmonizing Performance and Isolation in Microkernels with Efficient Intra-kernel Isolation and Communication
notes.body:
#literature #mpk #microkernel #sel4 #os [@gu2020harmonizing]

## Context

The paper argues that the cost of IPC in microkernels are too high, and proposed
using MPK-based domains to reduce the number of context switches during IPCs.
The paper provides a motivation study by profiling the overheads of IPC in
common microkernels (see [[i2blyo37#Overhead analysis]]).

### Background

Previous systems use MPK for single address-space isolation.

Previous state-of-the-art [@mi2019skybridge] enables fast IPC by retrofitting
VMFUNC., but still have high overheads due to Page table switching

### Contributions

The proposed system tackles three main challenges in the context of microkernels
that previous work did not solve.

- The first is to prevent illegal IPC calls, since intel MPK does not check for
  permission before executing code. This is solved by secure IPC gates for the
  specific connections between two specific servers (a _system server_ is an
  application that provides system-level services) in the trusted domain (core
  kernel).
- Second is the limited number of domains. The paper designs a _server
  migration_ technique that allows a server to be migrated between userspace
  (same as normal microkernel) and kernel space.
- Third, due to the server executing in the privileged space, the system needs
  to prevent it from executing privileged instructions.

Hierarchical layering limits flexibility
notes.body:
#capabilities #os

Many systems use the strict hierarchical layering for resource allocation. In
those systems, the rules enforced by the kernel is that

1. A process can only allocate resources that it own to its children,
2. Can only start/stop/remove its own children's, and
3. A process's resources must be returned to its parent when it terminates.

These rules can be seen in modern UNIX system.

However, [@wulf1974hydra] argued that hierarchical layering of a system limits
its flexibility.

- While resource allocation might contain hierarchical layering (one component
  allocate for the other), as shown above, the _control_ (e.g.,
  starting/stopping subprocesses) need not have the same hierarchical.
- Strict hierarchical system leads to increasingly privileged system components,
  and therefore leads to a component that have the "most privileged" only
  because it manages other subsystems. This leads to confused deputy problems
  ([[y9wu5ut7]]) in those components.

Capabilities [[khi9ihj9]] systems naturally remove hierarchies by centralizing
access control decision to a reference monitor.

## Related

- State spills hinders flexibility in systems similarly by creating implicit
  dependencies [[2j6s9zpm]].
- [[8113ygxd]]
- [[4vysjbn9]].

notes.title: Hourglass structure of information
notes.body:
#reading #learning

In most forms of writing, information is usually structured in an hourglass
structure. Usually high-level (easier to get) and most important information at
the beginning and the end, More specific information and less important in the
middle.

Hence, during reading, more time should be spent on the beginning and the end of
the chapter/sections/paragraph.

## References

- <https://web.stanford.edu/class/ee384m/Handouts/HowtoReadPaper.pdf>

notes.title: How to handle quotes in my zk
notes.body:
#quote #note-taking #zettelkasten

Maintaining/collecting quotes is important, so I try to somehow incorporate them
into my notes.

- [[msjmb62t]]
- [[amyz6o6h]]

## Goals

What I want in my quotes:

- R1. Easily searchable. Should be able to find quotes for the appropriate
  context.
- R2. Metadata: Relevatant info (author, pages in the book, what context) should
  be maintained.
- R3. Non-redundancy: Repeating occurances of the same quote should pointed to a
  single entry.
- R4. Linkable. Should be easy to pull out a quote and put them in the
  appropriate context.

## My system

R1. First, the title of the note contains the quote itself. This will make the
entire quote a first-class content. It will shows up in zk, for example. A
`#quote` tag is attached to the note. This allows for better indexing.

R2. The note should contains description of the note. For instance, who is it
from, in what context.

The remaining problem is left is to maintain authors of quotes to avoid
redundancy. There are two approaches, linking to the (may empty) note about
author, or use hash tag, both of which have trade-off. Linking force you to
create a note on the author, which may not be populated. using hashtags kind of
clutter you tags. Searching using hashtags may not be ideal (I might change my
mind later).

R3, R4. Now, to reference a quote, you link to the quote in the appropriate
context. Since the title is the quote it self, it can be searched easily.

# How to handle quotes in my zk

#quote #note-taking #zettelkasten

Maintaining/collecting quotes is important, so I try to somehow incorporate them
into my notes.

- [[msjmb62t]]
- [[amyz6o6h]]

## Goals

What I want in my quotes:

- R1. Easily searchable. Should be able to find quotes for the appropriate
  context.
- R2. Metadata: Relevatant info (author, pages in the book, what context) should
  be maintained.
- R3. Non-redundancy: Repeating occurances of the same quote should pointed to a
  single entry.
- R4. Linkable. Should be easy to pull out a quote and put them in the
  appropriate context.

## My system

R1. First, the title of the note contains the quote itself. This will make the
entire quote a first-class content. It will shows up in zk, for example. A
`#quote` tag is attached to the note. This allows for better indexing.

R2. The note should contains description of the note. For instance, who is it
from, in what context.

The remaining problem is left is to maintain authors of quotes to avoid
redundancy. There are two approaches, linking to the (may empty) note about
author, or use hash tag, both of which have trade-off. Linking force you to
create a note on the author, which may not be populated. using hashtags kind of
clutter you tags. Searching using hashtags may not be ideal (I might change my
mind later).

R3, R4. Now, to reference a quote, you link to the quote in the appropriate
context. Since the title is the quote it self, it can be searched easily.

notes.title: Hypervisor (VMM)
notes.body:
#virtualization #os

A hypervisor, also known as virtual machine monitor (VMM) manage virtual
machines.

It performs interposition ([[s16ct1rj#interposition]]) on a certain
_interesting_ instructions to _emulate_ then, hence _trap-and-emulate_. Those
interesting instruction can be:

- Access to hardware devices
- Special instructions (e.g., CPUID)
- Access to important and dangerous registers that have global effect

Hypervisor works by exploiting modern hardware supports that allows trapping of
those important instructions.

## Launching VM

Processor state of the VM is stored in a Virtual Machine Control structure/block
(VMCS/VMCB) (see [VMCS](https://shhoya.github.io/hv_vmcsdata.html)). VMCS is a
complex structure containing informations related to a VM's state. A pointer to
the current VMCS is stored in a dedicated register, loaded with `VMPTRLD`
instruction ([VMPTR](https://www.felixcloutier.com/x86/vmptrld.)).

The hypervisor is required to setup the VMCS correctly with necessary
information.

The `VMLAUNCH\VMRESUME` instruction is then used to lanch the VM based on the
current VMCS.

## Memory management

### Legacy

Previously, all access to physical memory in the Guest need to be interposed and
emulated, which causes a lot of overheads. Address translation and paging need
to be perform twice.

### Shadow Page Table

To avoid this, Shadow page table (SPT) is a per-VM page table used by the
hypervisor to translate guest virtual memory to host physical memory. It
maintain a copy of the guest page table in a _shadow_ page table, and mirror
every page table update from the guest.

This shadow page table is pointed to by CR3, and contains the actual mapping.

Upon a guest page fault (aka, shadow page fault):

- The hypervisor trap it, then forward it to the guest for it to update its page
  table since there is no entry yet.
- The guest update its page table (which will not be used by hardware
  translation). This may trigger a real page fault if guest page table is set at
  Read-only. Here the hypervisor can intercept and update the shadow page table.
- The guest then access the memory. Since the mapping is now contained in the
  shadow page table, it can access it.

Note that this process bypass the two-time address translation.

Still, this is expensive when there is a lot of paging in the guest VM, since
every page fault in the guest is forwarded to the host.

Nowaday it is still used in nested virtualization.

### EPT/NPT

Extended page table (EPT), aka Nested page table (NPT), is a hardware extension
implementing second-level address translation (SLAT). Each VM will have an
additional extended page table translate from guest physical address (gPAddr)
into host physical address (hPAddr). This extended page table is stored in the
VMCS. In virtualization mode, the MMU now walk the guest VM page table first to
translate gVAddr to gPAddr. Then the MMU, without stopping, translate the second
page table in the host. Hence, host page table is _nested_ within the guest page
table to translate (gPAddr->hVAddr->hPAddr). If there is a page fault, the host
OS simply update the nested table with the mapping. This allows more efficient
translation.

With the technology, when there is on guest's page fault, there is no exit to
the hypervisor; the CPU automatically wals both page table.

For more implementation details of the feature, see
[bhyve](https://people.freebsd.org/~neel/bhyve/bhyve_nested_paging.pdf)'s
implementation.

## More resources

- [High-level introduction to the Low-Level virtualization](http://haifux.org/lectures/312/High-Level%20Introduction%20to%20the%20Low-Level%20of%20Virtualization.pdf)
- Intel manual?

notes.title: I/O operations in AMD SEV
notes.body:
#sev #io #tee

SEV VMs interacts with virtualized hardware through QEMU. More particularly,
QEMU-KVM on the host side will serve I/O requests of the VM.

Supported common I/O operations are PIO, MMIO, DMA.

## DMA

The IOMMU maps DMA-capable I/O buses of hardware devices to the physical memory.
Because the IOMMU only supports memory encryption with ASID=0 (host ID), DMA
operations must be done on pages that are shared between VM and host. Those
pages are called the Software I/O Translation Look-aside Buffer SWIOTLB.

On a read DMA request from the guest VM, QEMU-KVM instructs the IOMMU to perform
DMA transfer from device into the SWIOTLB (e.g., swapping pages from the disk).
The guest VM then copy the pages inside SWIOTLB into its own memory.

On a write DMA request, the guest need to copy its data into the SWIOTLB first.
QEMU-KVM then commands the IOMMU to transfer those pages to the devices.

## Security

Because I/O is unencrypted, the cVM needs to encrypt the I/O data using the
software. However, certain types of data cannot be encrypted. For instance,
packets for DHF key exchange are not encrypted.

[@li2019exploiting] shows an example where a malicious hypervisor patches the
`sshd` binaries to bypass the authentication.

[@li2019exploiting] took a closer look at I/O operations that must not be
encrypted:

- In network I/O, the header of IP or TCP cannot be encrypted. Hence, the
  attacker can forge the header.
- In display I/O (e.g., VNC), QEMU-KVM redirects the VGA display from the guest
  to the VNC protocol.
- Disk I/O can be encrypted with a secret key provisioned by the cVM owner.
  However, the key is stored in memory and can be extracted using the encryption
  oracle described in the paper.

## Related notes

- [@li2019exploiting]: [[ncfh611p]]

notes.title: IOMMU, usage and considerations
notes.lead:
The IOMMU enable a virtual memory subsystem for the hardware devices and enforce
paging-like protection for each PCI device.
notes.body:
The IOMMU enable a virtual memory subsystem for the hardware devices and enforce
paging-like protection for each PCI device.

This is in response to threats of malicious DMA from devices [[3eot91og]].

The hypervisor can use the IOMMU to enforce intra-OS (isolating the buggy
devices from the kernel) and inter-Guest protection.

## DMA isolation

For the most security, a transient mapping is created per transaction between
the VM and the hardware, and the mapping is destroyed right after. E.g., NIC
driver maps the VM packet buffers to hardware to the hardware NIC to receive
packets, then unmap after packet is received.

This mechanism is refered to as **bounce buffering** [[jj89s7vj]] by Linux
developers and some modern papers.

Related:

- [[asuoudgb]]

## Overheads

Maintaining transient IOMMU mappings this lead to high overheads, mostly due to
IOTLB flushing and IO Virtual Addresses (IOVA) management. These mappings are
created and destroyed millions of times per second [@peleg2015utilizing].

- IOVA management taks up to 70% of cycles for IOMMU managment, due to the need
  to aquire a global lock [@peleg2015utilizing] for each allocation.
- For IOTLB flushing, it takes about 2000 cycles on Intel Sandy Bridge
  [@markuze2016true].

## IOTLB invalidation is (generally) more expensive than copying

While it is a common knowledge that copying should be avoided, for most cases it
is actually cheaper to copy the packets (~1500 bytes due to MTU). In stead of
temporarily allowing DMA to some kernel addresses, [@markuze2016true] propose to
instead maintain an always-mapped DMA buffer, and copy data from/to kernel
memory into it at every device transaction.

## SWIOTLB

SWIOTLB is kind of an emulation of hardware IOMMU [1]. In certain scenarios,
like confidential computing [[jj89s7vj]], DMA cannot be performed directly onto
the target memory buffer. SWIOTLB is an allocator that allocate memory that
conform to the restriction for DMA (e.g., unencrypted memory). The CPU copy data
to this bounce buffer, then data from the bounce buffer is DMA-ed by the device.

## More

- [1]: https://xillybus.com/tutorials/iommu-swiotlb-linux

notes.title: IP configuration in Linux distributions
notes.body:
#admin #linux

## Ubuntu

Ubuntu uses `netplan` for network configurations
(<https://ubuntu.com/server/docs/network-configuration>). To create a network
configuration, create a file named `/etc/netplan/99_config.yaml` (or change the
existing config file.).

```yaml
network:
        version: 2
        renderer: networkd
        ethernets:
                eth0:
                        addresses:
                                - 10.10.10.2/24
                        routes:
                                - to: default
                                  via: 10.10.10.1
                        nameservers:
                                search: [mydomain, otherdomain]
                                addresses: [10.10.10.1, 1.1.1.1]
```

After, runs `sudo netplan apply` to apply the configuration.

notes.title: Idea Compass
notes.body:
#zettelkasten #note-taking

Idea Compass is a thinking tool that helps define how to think about a
particular idea. In particular, it is described in
[Compass of Zettelkasten Thinking](https://feeei.substack.com/i/48707291/the-compass-of-zettelkasten-thinking)
as follows:

>

1. take one idea (X) and put it in the centre
2. imagine the four compass directions. each direction helps give definition to
   the idea in different ways.

- NORTH: _Where does X come from?_ what are its origin? what group/category
  does X belong to? what exists an order of magnitude higher? zoom out. what
  gave birth to X? what causes X
- WEST: _What is similar to X?_ what other disciplines could X already exist
  in? what other disciplines could benefit from X? what are other ways to say/do
  X?
- SOUTH: _Where can X lead to?_ what does X contribute to? what group/category
  could X be the headline of? what exists an order of magnitude lower? zoom in.
  what does X nurture?
- EAST: _What competes with X?_ what is the opposite of X? what is X missing?
  its disadvantage? what could supercharge X?

3. The Zettelkasten structure created around the idea could look something like
   this:

- NORTH
  - The Idea
    - SOUTH
    - EAST
    - WEST

Takes the idea of the _idea compass_ itself for example. We can start from the
NORTH:

- NORTH: _"Where does X come from?"_
  - This idea comes from the lack of clear instructions for using the
       zettelkasten method. For instance, what should an idea contain? How do
       you connect it with other ideas?
  - Hence, the author introduces a framework for finding the _context_ of an
       idea.
  - SOUTH: _What can X leads to?_
    - This idea helps to discover the context of a Zettelkasten note. More
            importantly, helps writing notes easier [[cemsxh4n]]
  - EAST: _What competes with X?_
  - WEST: \*What is similar to _X?_
  - [This](https://zettelkasten.de/posts/creative-technique-within-zettelkasten-framework/)
       introduces another technique called the _knowledge flower_ [[dyx2t4oz]]
       that is more open for interpretation.

notes.title: Immediate Novelty
notes.body:
#research

A type of research novelty I usually see is the novelty when directly compared
against a limited set of previous work, usually only in the scope of a problem.

For instance, [@bang2023trust] proposes a new compiler framework for isolating
unsafe Rust components. Its immediate comparison targets are only 3 papers, each
tackle a different parts of the problem in Rust (only Unsafe Rust, or only
external libraries).

Now, this paper's individual novelty is judged one by one, it is not very
interesting. The idea of improving points-to analysis with cloning exist before.
Moreover, automatic isolation using compiler is hardly a new thing, as there has
been a numbers of previous works for C.

However, as the comparison target is only its immediate predecessor in the scope
of Rust, the paper has clear advantages over these works and is considered (at
least by the reviewers [[itd1o3ic]]).

notes.title: Implementing capability systems
notes.body:
#capabilities

Capability concepts are simple enough to understand, but implementing them is a
different story.

## Unforgeability of token

A fundamental challenge is how to make the capability tokens _unforgeable_,
while also allowing the user (subjects) to keep them. For example, plain
pointers are not capabilities token, as they may be easily modified by the
untrusted program.

Implementing a storage for capability token requires maintaining their
integrity, which have two classical solutions: (1) access control and (2)
cryptographic hash. This can be also phrased as (a) protected storage vs. (b)
unprotected storage.

- OSes use the access control model for simplicity, speed, and making use of
  hardware assisted isolation (ring levels).
  - For example, Linux maintains a per-process file descriptor table, and give
    the index to the userspace. The userspace can use FD from the table, but
    cannot obtain more privileges.
- Hardware capabilities systems uses both approaches.
  - CHERI-type system enforces access control. They store capability tokens in
    write-protected memory regions.
  - Cryptographic capabilities systems combines pointer encryption.
- In distributed systems, cryptographic hash is used since network
  communications already take most of the overheads, this implementation omits
  the need for a centralized capability storage.

For access control type, it requires a centralized storage of capability tokens.

## Invocation

There must be a security monitor that serves **capability invocations**. Usually
in OSes capabilities are given as an opaque handle that are index to a
kernel-maintained capability table [@steinberg2010nova,@klein2009sel4]
([[sn99wrm0]]), which cannot be used directly, but must be _invoked_ through the
privileged software through system calls.

An alternative design is to let capabilities be invoked directly, e.g., pointer
access, but somehow enforce all invocation are checked (complete mediation).
This can be done through

- Fault handler [@shapiro1999eros]
- Compiler checks [@dinhduy2023capacity, @framer] (not common)
- CPU automatic checks [@watson2015cheri]

## Implementing delegation and revocation

Realizing delegation and revocation is another headache. Most capability systems
often do not support revocation.

Ideally capability tokens should be freely given by a subject to other subjects.
In a centralized capability system, Delegation is easy enough. When receiving a
delegation request, you simply copy the capability (permissions) over to the
target.

### Revocation require tracking delegation

However, enabling revocation is non-trivial and require complex state
managements. It requires the enforcement to keep track of the flow of the
capability tokens across different subjects. For example if
`A - delegate -> B - delegate -> C`, and A want to revoke the A to B delegation,
the delegated token for B and C must be revoked.

This complexity is often too much for hardware implementation, as they not only
need to keep track of where capabilities are, but also

1. The chain of delegation of the capability
2. All the copies of this capability in memory (i.e., runtime information flow
   tracking).

### Single-ownership

Enforcing single-ownership is another way to simplify revocation. In fact, there
is no need revocation in the first place, as the capability token is basically
transferred to the target.

Still, the challenge is to "revoke" the existing capability of the delegating
subject. Doing so also require tracking where this capability has been, e.g.,
what if the subject make copies of the capability before delegation.

Single-ownership can be enforced with programming language invariants
[@narayanan2020redleaf,@boos2020theseus].

## Retrofitting interfaces for capabilities

One must decompose existing interfaces into a set of capability objects and the
set of operations that may be invoked on them.

#archive

# Goals

- Provide binary compatible annotations of security policies
- Compatible with existing attacks
- Provide opt-in protection for applicable functions

# How

- Annotation should be able to specify the following things:
  - **T1: Context**: A user can decide the context where the protection is
    enabled
  - **T2: Protection type**: Among **P1: Paging**, **P2: Cache** and **P3:
    Ciphertext**
  - **T3: Semantic of memory**: A user can selectively enable protection based
    memory semantic (stack, heap, code and data)
  - **T4: Protection granularity**: The user may decide to trade-off security
    for performance by coarsening the protection granularity

# Example

## Case study 1: protecting constant-time EdDSA from ciphertext

- The implementation of EdDSA is vulnerable to collision attack.
- While secret may resides in the heap or global data, the actual target for
  ciphertext attacks is secret-dependent variables resides on the stack memory.

  - This is true for most of ciphertext-vulnerable implementation

- T1: EdDSA signing function (e.g., libsodium `crypto_sign`)
- T2: P3
- T3: Stack memory
- T4: Scratchpad size

notes.title: IncognitOS binary-instrumentation-based scheduling
notes.body:
## Motivations

Our binary-instrumentation-based seek to solve two problems. First, it uphold
the security invariant of the ORAM-backed paging scheme, that require the timely
validation of huge mappings that may be smashed by the hypervisor. Second, it
implements a layer of defense that is adaptive to the costly extraction phase
attacks. Extraction phase attacks are costly, thus inevitably leave side effects
such as prolonged execution time, or identifiable interceptions. Previous work
demonstrated compiler-based detection schemes for SGX that use the compiler to
insert checking code at configured interval, e.g., per-basic blocks
[@chen2017detecting,@oleksenko2018varys], but require application source code.

More generally, we want to reliably schedule security tasks alongside execution
of the unikernel application thread.

Now with OS support, this security tasks could be built into the kernel through
its scheduling. Unfortunately, there are challenges., scheduling is made
unreliable in CVMs, due to the hardware timer being virtualized. Moreover,
unikernels use cooperative scheduler that is unsuited for scheduling tasks
per-interval.

## Idea

Our idea is to leverage binary rewriting to self-insert interception code (i.e.,
probes) into the application binary. The interception is then used as scheduling
ticks, which replace the unreliable virtualized interrupts of the kernel.

By carefully choosing the probe insertion, the OS can now dictate when the
control flow must be passed back to the scheduler, which solve two problems at
the same time: (1) lack of reliable hardware interrupts and (2) unikernel's lack
of preemptive scheduling.

## Design goals

Requirements:

- R1. For reliability, the scheduling ticks must be performed at least at each
  basic block. This is to handle loops that may delay the scheduling of security
  tasks.
- R2. The intercepted execution must not leak information about the code. Now
  that the original instruction is replaced with a probe, the execution flow
  must take a _detour_ to a different location.
- R3. The location of the probes must be randomized per CVM boots. This is to
  avoid the attacker bruteforcing to try to infer probe locations.
- R4. The probes must not incur significant overheads.
- R5. Should not relies on complex analyses. Analyzing binaries is challenging
  and error prone.

## Design decisions

To achieve R1, we must insert probes at every `jmp` instructions.

To achieve R3, we implement load-time binary rewriting. Our kernel binary
rewriting facility (based on linux kprobe) randomize location of probes on every
CVM boots.

## Design space

## Internal

- Kprobe [[1mhpx5ds]] offer similar functionalities.

notes.title: IncognitOS binary-instrumentation-based scheduling
notes.body:
## Motivations Our binary-instrumentation-based seek to solve two problems. First, it uphold the security invariant of the ORAM-backed paging scheme, which require the timely validation of huge mappings that may be smashed by the hypervisor. Second, it implements a layer of defense that is adaptive to the costly extraction phase attacks. Extraction phase attacks are costly, thus inevitably leave side effects such as prolonged execution time, or identifiable interceptions. Previous work demonstrated compiler-based detection schemes for SGX that use the compiler to insert checking code at configured interval, e.g., per-basic blocks, but require application source code. More generally, we want to reliably schedule _security threads_ alongside execution of the unikernel application thread. Unfortunately, there are challenges. Scheduling is made unreliable in CVMs, due to the hardware timer being virtualized. Moreover, unikernels uses a cooperative scheduler (non-preemptive) that is unsuited for scheduling tasks per-interval. ## Idea Our idea is to leverage binary rewriting to self-insert interception code (i.e., probes) into the application binary. The interception is then used as scheduling ticks, which replace the unreliable virtualized interrupts of the kernel. By carefully choosing the probe insertion, the OS can now dictate when the control flow must be passed back to the scheduler, which solve two problems at the same time: (1) lack of reliable hardware interrupts and (2) unikernel's lack of preemptive scheduling. ## Design goals Requirements: - R1. For reliability, the scheduling ticks must be performed at least at each basic block. This is to handle loops that may delay the scheduling of security tasks. - R2. The intercepted execution must not leak information about the code. Now that the original instruction is replaced with a probe, the execution flow must take a _detour_ to a different location. Such detour must not leak information through side-channels - R3. The location of the probes must be randomized per CVM boots. This is to avoid the attacker bruteforcing to try to infer probe locations. - R4. Compatibility. Must not hurt existing unikernel binary compatibility ## Design decisions ### R1 Reliable per-basic-block ticks - We may intercept every `jmp` instructions. - Using this, we may rewrite existing 5-bytes `jmp` instructions with jmp to our detour execution cache as an optimization - In NGINX, about 70% of `jmp` are 5-bytes - More complex 2B `jmp` may be supported through normal `int3` - Concern: Long basic blocks - [Control transfer instructions](https://pdos.csail.mit.edu/6.828/2018/readings/i386/s03_05.htm) ### R2 Oblivious _detour_ execution - _Detour execution_ just takes place in the ORAM-backed huge page - Self-protection: the timely scheduling of security tasks already prevents using extraction primitives to leak informations ### R3 Randomization - We implement load-time binary rewriting. Our kernel binary rewriting facility (based on linux kprobe) randomize location of probes on every CVM boots. ### R4 Eagerly loading dependencies - We include a dynamic loader that eagerly load all binary dependencies. This dynamic loader replaces the ELF's default loader. This reduces the overheads of runtime instrumentation. ## Design ### Workflow ```graphviz digraph { rankdir=LR subgraph cluster_0 { label="Input" elf [label="ELF",shape=square] lib [label="*.so",shape=square] } subgraph cluster0 { func [label="Analyze symbol table"]; load [label="Load to memory (mmap)"]; } subgraph cluster1 { decode [label="Decode functions"]; jmp [label="JMP locations"]; } subgraph cluster2 { i1[label="INT3 replacement",]; i2[label="Optimize 5-byte JMPs"]; i3[label="Optimize 2-byte JMPs"]; } elf->func lib->func elf->load lib->load func->decode[label="function addresses"] jmp->i1 load -> decode[] decode -> jmp[constraint=false] i1->i2[constraint=false] i2->i3[constraint=false] } ``` ### Jump optimization ```mermaid flowchart LR subgraph t direction TB subgraph a [original exec] org["0x1000: jmp RIP+64"] modified["0x1000: jmp 0x2000"] orig_target["0x1040: XXXX"] end modified-->A org-->modified A-->orig_target subgraph b [trampoline cache] A---B---C---D A["0x2000: backup_registers
0x20XX: call security_cb
0x20XX: restore_registers
0x20XX: jmp RIP-0xFC0// target with modified RIP"] B["0x3000: "] end end style A text-align:left style B text-align:left style C text-align:left style D text-align:left style org text-align:left style modified text-align:left ``` ## Design Space - `jmp` probe vs. `int3` - `jmp` is 16x faster per intercept ### How to handle dynamic libraries Dynamic libraries loaded at runtime by the dynamic loader (`/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2`). How do we rewrite dynamic libraries as they are loaded? Challenges: Program loader is also pre-compiled and loaded at runtime #### Approach 1: Runtime rewriting: hooking dynamic linker At runtime, dynamic linker open the shared object files (`libc.so`), maps it into memory, and resolve missing plt calls. We need to somehow obtain the load address + which shared library it is (for the function addresses) when it is after it is loaded into memory One way we can do this is by hooking PLT entries. ``` Disassembly of section .plt: 0000000000001020 <.plt>: 1020: ff 35 9a 2f 00 00 pushq 0x2f9a(%rip) # 3fc0 <_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_+0x8> 1026: f2 ff 25 9b 2f 00 00 bnd jmpq *0x2f9b(%rip) # 3fc8 <_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_+0x10> 102d: 0f 1f 00 nopl (%rax) 1030: f3 0f 1e fa endbr64 1034: 68 00 00 00 00 pushq $0x0 1039: f2 e9 e1 ff ff ff bnd jmpq 1020 <.plt> 103f: 90 nop Disassembly of section .plt.got: 0000000000001040 <__cxa_finalize@plt>: 1040: f3 0f 1e fa endbr64 1044: f2 ff 25 ad 2f 00 00 bnd jmpq *0x2fad(%rip) # 3ff8 <__cxa_finalize@GLIBC_2.2.5> 104b: 0f 1f 44 00 00 nopl 0x0(%rax,%rax,1) Disassembly of section .plt.sec: 0000000000001050 <__printf_chk@plt>: 1050: f3 0f 1e fa endbr64 1054: f2 ff 25 75 2f 00 00 bnd jmpq *0x2f75(%rip) # 3fd0 <__printf_chk@GLIBC_2.3.4> 105b: 0f 1f 44 00 00 nopl 0x0(%rax,%rax,1) ``` #### Approach 2: Eager libraries loading Our own elf loader loads the dynamic libraries and prepare plt before execution happen. We can perform binary rewrite at this stage. Challenges: How to find all required symbols Advantages: - Unikernel don't need to share libraries, so we can do crazy things #### Approach 3: Rewrite pre-execution We rewrite the shared libraries before load time and make the rewritten version available to the loader. - Challenge: Relocation? ### Instrumentation (LIM) ```asm ;; Original (2byte jump) 0x00: 48 85 c0 test rax,rax 0x03: 75 03 jne 8 ``` #### Naive Approach(Base Line): Inject Interrupt(`int3`) We instruments every jump instructions to ensure that our interrupt handler executed on every _basic blocks_. ```asm ;; Phase-1 : Inject Interrupt 0x00: 48 85 c0 test rax,rax 0x03: cc int3 ; Interrupt Handler Emulates `jne` 0x04: 90 nop ``` The `0x03:int3` transfers the control to our interrupt handler. emulates the original `jne` instruction #### Optimization : Jump Instrumentation ```asm ;; Phase-2 : Jump Optimization ; Emulates `test`+`jne` 0x00: e9 00 00 cc 90 jmp cc001b ``` ### Optimization Space for jmp - Reduce registers to backup - Reusing trampolines for same jmp opcodes - Sampling reduces the cost of too frequent jumps, thanks to branch predictor ```c if (jmp_cnt > 1000){ do_security_ticks(); jmp_cnt = 0; } else { jmp_cnt++; } emulate_jmp(); ```

Must not hurt existing unikernel binary compatibility ## Design decisions ### R1 Reliable per-basic-block ticks - We may intercept every `jmp` instructions. - Using this, we may rewrite existing 5-bytes `jmp` instructions with jmp to our detour execution cache as an optimization - In NGINX, about 70% of `jmp` are 5-bytes - More complex 2B `jmp` may be supported through normal `int3` - Concern: Long basic blocks - [Control transfer instructions](https://pdos.csail.mit.edu/6.828/2018/readings/i386/s03_05.htm) ### R2 Oblivious _detour_ execution - _Detour execution_ just takes place in the ORAM-backed huge page - Self-protection: the timely scheduling of security tasks already prevents using extraction primitives to leak informations ### R3 Randomization - We implement load-time binary rewriting. Our kernel binary rewriting facility (based on linux kprobe) randomize location of probes on every CVM boots. ### R4 Eagerly loading dependencies - We include a dynamic loader that eagerly load all binary dependencies. This dynamic loader replaces the ELF's default loader. This reduces the overheads of runtime instrumentation. ## Design ### Workflow ```graphviz digraph { rankdir=LR subgraph cluster_0 { label="Input" elf [label="ELF",shape=square] lib [label="*.so",shape=square] } subgraph cluster0 { func [label="Analyze symbol table"]; load [label="Load to memory (mmap)"]; } subgraph cluster1 { decode [label="Decode functions"]; jmp [label="JMP locations"]; } subgraph cluster2 { i1[label="INT3 replacement",]; i2[label="Optimize 5-byte JMPs"]; i3[label="Optimize 2-byte JMPs"]; } elf->func lib->func elf->load lib->load func->decode[label="function addresses"] jmp->i1 load -> decode[] decode -> jmp[constraint=false] i1->i2[constraint=false] i2->i3[constraint=false] } ``` ### Jump optimization ```mermaid flowchart LR subgraph t direction TB subgraph a [original exec] org["0x1000: jmp RIP+64"] modified["0x1000: jmp 0x2000"] orig_target["0x1040: XXXX"] end modified-->A org-->modified A-->orig_target subgraph b [trampoline cache] A---B---C---D A["0x2000: backup_registers
0x20XX: call security_cb
0x20XX: restore_registers
0x20XX: jmp RIP-0xFC0// target with modified RIP"] B["0x3000: "] end end style A text-align:left style B text-align:left style C text-align:left style D text-align:left style org text-align:left style modified text-align:left ``` ## Design Space - `jmp` probe vs. `int3` - `jmp` is 16x faster per intercept ### How to handle dynamic libraries Dynamic libraries loaded at runtime by the dynamic loader (`/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2`). How do we rewrite dynamic libraries as they are loaded? Challenges: Program loader is also pre-compiled and loaded at runtime #### Approach 1: Runtime rewriting: hooking dynamic linker At runtime, dynamic linker open the shared object files (`libc.so`), maps it into memory, and resolve missing plt calls. We need to somehow obtain the load address + which shared library it is (for the function addresses) when it is after it is loaded into memory One way we can do this is by hooking PLT entries. ``` Disassembly of section .plt: 0000000000001020 <.plt>: 1020: ff 35 9a 2f 00 00 pushq 0x2f9a(%rip) # 3fc0 <_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_+0x8> 1026: f2 ff 25 9b 2f 00 00 bnd jmpq *0x2f9b(%rip) # 3fc8 <_GLOBAL_OFFSET_TABLE_+0x10> 102d: 0f 1f 00 nopl (%rax) 1030: f3 0f 1e fa endbr64 1034: 68 00 00 00 00 pushq $0x0 1039: f2 e9 e1 ff ff ff bnd jmpq 1020 <.plt> 103f: 90 nop Disassembly of section .plt.got: 0000000000001040 <__cxa_finalize@plt>: 1040: f3 0f 1e fa endbr64 1044: f2 ff 25 ad 2f 00 00 bnd jmpq *0x2fad(%rip) # 3ff8 <__cxa_finalize@GLIBC_2.2.5> 104b: 0f 1f 44 00 00 nopl 0x0(%rax,%rax,1) Disassembly of section .plt.sec: 0000000000001050 <__printf_chk@plt>: 1050: f3 0f 1e fa endbr64 1054: f2 ff 25 75 2f 00 00 bnd jmpq *0x2f75(%rip) # 3fd0 <__printf_chk@GLIBC_2.3.4> 105b: 0f 1f 44 00 00 nopl 0x0(%rax,%rax,1) ``` #### Approach 2: Eager libraries loading Our own elf loader loads the dynamic libraries and prepare plt before execution happen. We can perform binary rewrite at this stage. Challenges: How to find all required symbols Advantages: - Unikernel don't need to share libraries, so we can do crazy things #### Approach 3: Rewrite pre-execution We rewrite the shared libraries before load time and make the rewritten version available to the loader. - Challenge: Relocation? ### Instrumentation (LIM) ```asm ;; Original (2byte jump) 0x00: 48 85 c0 test rax,rax 0x03: 75 03 jne 8 ``` #### Naive Approach(Base Line): Inject Interrupt(`int3`) We instruments every jump instructions to ensure that our interrupt handler executed on every _basic blocks_. ```asm ;; Phase-1 : Inject Interrupt 0x00: 48 85 c0 test rax,rax 0x03: cc int3 ; Interrupt Handler Emulates `jne` 0x04: 90 nop ``` The `0x03:int3` transfers the control to our interrupt handler. emulates the original `jne` instruction #### Optimization : Jump Instrumentation ```asm ;; Phase-2 : Jump Optimization ; Emulates `test`+`jne` 0x00: e9 00 00 cc 90 jmp cc001b ``` ### Optimization Space for jmp - Reduce registers to backup - Reusing trampolines for same jmp opcodes - Sampling reduces the cost of too frequent jumps, thanks to branch predictor ```c if (jmp_cnt > 1000){ do_security_ticks(); jmp_cnt = 0; } else { jmp_cnt++; } emulate_jmp(); ```

- [ ] Shorten 5.1, challenges & contribution
- [ ] Follow R1 R2 R3 structure
- [ ] Use positive terms (no attacker-observable, constrained)
- [ ] Novelty?

Overview: here are the rules

- R1
- R2
- R3

- Some background on access pattern leakage and implications

Challenges

- We must efficiently protect the page table access due attack vectors above.
  Particularly, GPT access from from MMU and also the OS must follow R1-3. We
  make two observations that enable efficientcy:

  - (1) unused space in the PTE may be retrofitted for ORAM metadata and
  - (2) due to the hierarchy of the page table, the rerandomization and
    ORAM-access of both GPT and data pages may be incorporated in a single OS
    page table walking without requiring multiple page faults.
  - Sec 5.1 describe the paging scheme that also protect page table pages.

- Page eviction is a component swapping page in and out of active regions on R2
  and also used for rerandomization (R3).

  - Now that page tables are also incorporate in ORAM-accesses and
    rerandomization, the page eviction scheme must respect paging hierarchy.

- Finally, we must retrofitting existing full system memory to use the proposed
  paging rules. We analyze how unikernel memory is initialized, and also found
  some unevitable exceptions that must be made to the rules (5.3).

## Evaluations

<!-- We evaluate the securit of two components, runtime exit rate tracking and -->
<!-- adaptive rerandomization that is based on the measured exit rate. -->

## Exit rate tracking accuracy

- We repeat the scenarios (S1-3, S5) on the NGINX webserver to see how well the
  exit rate is tracked.
- We use our profiling framework to collect ground truth measurements traces
  along the CVM execution the results and compare against the measured rate
  (ExitRate).

- Results in Fig5 shows that seen that the tick placement is indeed effective in
  detecting premonitions of attacks.

  - During normal execution, the groundtruth as well as measured exit is low
  - As long as an attack begins (annotated in figure), the detected exit rate as
    well as the rerandomization rate quickly spike up and stay there for the
    duration of the attack.
  - While our detected exit rate maxed out at 0.2, this is more than enough to
    detect the potential of attacks.

- Moreover, while there are overlapping between upper bound of I/O exit rate the
  lower-bound of attack scenarios, the rate-adaptive approach allows it to
  response without crashing.

## Effectiveness against real attack

- Goal: Show that our system makes attacks impractical by minimizing attacker's
  temporal resolution

- Protection against profiling:

  - We repeat the attack methodology from [] that collect a profile of GPA
    access during an attacker-contrlled event (chosen to be NGINX webserver
    handling requests).
    - Profiling require frequent exits, which causes high rerandomization rate.
  - The results are shown in Figure6. Without adaptive rerandomization, the
    frequency of page accesses is distictive in the histogram.
  - On the ohter hand, our adaptive rerandomization flatten out the histogram
    and make it hard to any useful frequency.
  - Moreover, we show that adaptive rerandomization scheme allow larger
    scratchpad sizes while preserving security.
    - Scratchpad sizes: 512 causes significantly more faults than 1028 due to
      frequent replacement. However, both shows the same level of security.

- Protection agaisnt Secret extraction:

  - We repeat the image extraction attack, re-implemented to use the NPF
    controlled channel.
  - We assume ideal attacker: start and end of the sensitive section is known to
    attacker since constant rerandomization makes profiling difficult.
  - The results shows that our adaptive eviction scheme adds significant noises
    to the extracted image compared to the unprotected execution.
  - Random vs full eviction:
    - Compared to full eviction, random-eviction introduce more noises to the
      extracted image.

## Microbenchmark

- nbench also used in other works and is representative of general workloads
- We study the three aspect that contribute to the overheads: instrumentation,
  page swapping from limited scratchpad sizes and adaptive rerandomization.

- Configurations: different configurations to

  - Sched: Only instrumentation
  - Paging: Only enable paging (no rerandomization) to study isolated
    performance of paging subsystem
  - NonAdaptive vs. Adaptive: Shows the effectiveness in supressing runtime
    overheads.

- Instrumentation causes majority of overehads ( 4x)

  - This is worst-case since nbench has tight loops. Will be better in
    real-world applications with I/O ()
  - We also instrument all program libraries and elf for most security.
  - This overhead may be improved through optimizations, and non-sensitive
    libraries skipping

- Paging: We stresstest performance of paging under limited scratchpad size

  - Larger scratchpad compared to previous work to facilitate whole-system pages
  - Even with high amount of PF, it shows low relatively low overheads, thanks
    to efficient paging (compared to klotski)
  - Also, it achieve scratchpad contains whole working set, overheads is minimum
    due to lack of software MMU instrumentation

- NonAdaptive vs. Adaptive
  - We test non-adaptive using static rerandomization rates.
    - Low static rate causes high overheads, while high static rate leads to
      extended attack window.
  - On the other hand, \thename's adaptiveness enable minimized static rate
    during normal execution, leading to small amount of PF. This leads to only
    small increase in overheadsheads compared to just instrumentation overheads.

### Real-world applications

- Shows our practicality through large application evaluations

# subsec: IncognitOS Page tables 
## Unique feature 1: integrates ORAM page pool as its backend (i.e., replacing disk)
- **ORAM page pool for securing paging-in** Any page-in process is subject to ORAM shuffling of page pool 
   - **Security Objective**: hypervisor does not learn which page has been brought in.
   
- **Modified soft MMU walk** We extend the traditional page-in process also perfrom ORAM-backed paging for table pages recursively.
  - Security Objective: 
  	- Same as above
  	- Support the page table rerandomization scheme
  - Efficiency: 
  	- A single page fault fetches the GPT and data page similar to a recursive ORAM
  	- Additional metadata maintenance is avoided.

## Unique feature 2: Pages that map page tables (PG_{pgt}) themselves are subject to rerandomization
- **Motivation**: Hypervisor can single out NPF-on-PGTs to group memory accesses into distinct 2MB regions (while exact address is unknown without knowing PTE content)
   - **Leak through NPF-on-PGTs** can happen in two cases
        - Soft walk during OS page management code (e.g., page fault handler) walking the PGTs
        - MMU's hardware walk
      

- **Remaining challenge**:  Normal page to PGT page dependency
  - **dependency-aware eviction scheme**
	- Explanation on security of this scheme?

# Subsec: Rerandomization
- Rerandomization happens through random eviction 
  - Upon demand from scheduler, We randomly choose N pages, where N is a random number between 0.5 * 512 (Num. 4K pages in 2MB active region) and 1.0 *512),
      -  Evicted pages naturally go through the shuffling of ORAM page pool explained above 
       - Security Objective: hypervisor does not know which pages had been evicted
          - Brings complete change in access trace: in both total counts, and order of accesses
          - **Conclusion**: Eviction and ORAM-backed paging-in naturally creates a seemingly random access pattern
