notes.title: InkTag: Secure Applications on an Untrusted Operating System
notes.body:
#literature #hypervisor

# Background

At the time of this paper, SGX that have the same functionality but without
hypervisor have yet to exist.

Previous system on protection against untrusted OS, OverShadow
[@chen2008overshadow] only focus on isolation of memory (code and data) from the
OS. This papers provides methods for verifying OS behaviors, allowing the
protected program to use OS services securely.

# Main arguments

## Verifying OS behaviors with the hypervisors is more simple than reimplementing OS services inside the hypervisor

- OS services often have simple specifications.
- Only implementing verification in the kernel reduces the TCB of hypervisor.
- The introduced technique called _paraverification_ to verify the unstrusted
  OS. Essentially, the OS is changed to cooperate with the hypervisor for
  verifiable OS services (e.g., page management).

## Untrusted OS verification leads to security

- This directly address the Iago Attack [[ns7lcn8t]] where the untrusted OS
  feeds incorrect values to trusted application.
- InkTag enable crash consistency
- InkTag is able to secure files with defined access control policies.

# Control flow

The High assurance programs (HAPs) and the operating system interacts through a
_untrusted trampoline_. The application first invoke the hypervisor to request
system call. The hypervisor switch the control to an untrusted trampoline that
actually invoke the system call.

This allows the untrusted OS to schedule among the untrusted trampolines and
other contexts.

NOTE: Not quite understand.

# Memory isolation

InkTag provides two layers of memory isolation: kernel to High assurance
programs (HAPs), and between the HAPs. Memory isolation are provided by EPT
virtualization plus paraverfication. This isolation is maintained from the file
system up to the memory pages.

The _object_ abstraction represents files. Each object is given a unique ID
(_OID_). An objects consists of _secure pages (S-pages)_ that contains metadata
about the owner object and the offset within the object (_<OID, offset>_), and
also the _hash_ of the data (for verification).

## Two EPTs

Two EPTs are used for trusted context (HAPs) and untrusted context (kernel /
normal apps). The trusted EPT maps the plaintext S-page physical frames. The
untrusted EPT maps the other frames.

- When OS / untrusted applications access a mapped S-pages in trusted EPT (not
  mapped in untrusted), the hypervisor unmap it in trusted EPT, take the hash,
  encrypt the page, then map it to untrusted EPT.
- When HAP access the frame, hypervisor decrypt the page, verify the hash, map
  it to trusted EPT, unmap it from untrusted EPT.

## Isolation between HAPs

The hypervisor manage page table updates for HAPs, to enforce access control
policies of objects. For normal pages, the OS can map without intervention.

notes.title: Inside of Linux support for AMD SEV
notes.body:
#sev #virtualization #os #linux

Configuration for SEV starts at, where kernel initialization starts. This is
called after the kernel have been decompressed and loaded into memory
(`kernel/arch/x86/boot/compressed/head_64.S`).

## Configuration

`CONFIG_AMD_MEM_ENCRYPT`

## Booting

### Protected mode

### Long mode

In `startup_64`, `kernel/arch/x86/boot/compressed/head_64.S`, which is the
booting code in 64-bit long mode that performs kernel decompression, there is
this code;

```c
#ifdef CONFIG_AMD_MEM_ENCRYPT
	/*
	 * Now that the stage1 interrupt handlers are set up, #VC exceptions from
	 * CPUID instructions can be properly handled for SEV-ES guests.
	 *

	 * CPUID instructions being issued, so go ahead and do that now via
	 * sev_enable(), which will also handle the rest of the SEV-related
	 * detection/setup to ensure that has been done in advance of any dependent
	 * code.
	 */
	pushq	%rsi
	movq	%rsi, %rdi		/* real mode address */
	call	sev_enable
	popq	%rsi
#endif
```

`sev_enable` first checks whether SEV is supported using `native_cpuid`, which
calls `cpuid` instruction. Then, it call `snp_init`. The function looks for the
struct `cc_blob_sev_info` defined as follows:

```c
/*
 * AMD SEV Confidential computing blob structure. The structure is
 * defined in OVMF UEFI firmware header:
 * https://github.com/tianocore/edk2/blob/master/OvmfPkg/Include/Guid/ConfidentialComputingSevSnpBlob.h
 */
#define CC_BLOB_SEV_HDR_MAGIC	0x45444d41
struct cc_blob_sev_info {
	u32 magic;
	u16 version;
	u16 reserved;

	u32 secrets_len;
	u32 rsvd1;
	u64 cpuid_phys;
	u32 cpuid_len;
	u32 rsvd2;
```

In this struct's definition, you can notice `secrets_phys` and `cpuid_phys`
fields, which correspond to the physical address of the _special pages_ inserted
into the guest memory

command `SNP_LAUNCH_UPDATE` is used by the hypervisor to insert a _secrets_ page
and a _CPUID_ page. The secrets page contains encryption keys that the guest can
use to interact with the firmware. The CPUID page contains the
hypervisor-provided CPUID information, which the guest can request the firmware
to validate.

table

indexed using GUID

```c
/*
 * Indicate SNP based on presence of SNP-specific CC blob. Subsequent checks
 * will verify the SNP CPUID/MSR bits.
 */
bool snp_init(struct boot_params *bp)
{
	struct cc_blob_sev_info *cc_info;

	if (!bp)
		return false;

	cc_info = find_cc_blob(bp);
	if (!cc_info)
		return false;

	 * If a SNP-specific Confidential Computing blob is present, then
	 * firmware/bootloader have indicated SNP support. Verifying this

	 * CPUID table is used. See comments over snp_setup_cpuid_table() for

	 * phase.
```

SEV-related parts of the kernel.

## Kernel initialization

In `startup_64` (`arch/x86/kernel/head64.S`), you will see the following code,

```c
SYM_CODE_START_NOALIGN(startup_64)

#ifdef CONFIG_AMD_MEM_ENCRYPT
	/*
	 * Activate SEV/SME memory encryption if supported/enabled. This needs to

	 * which needs to be done before any CPUID instructions are executed in
	 * subsequent code.
	 */
	movq	%rsi, %rdi
	pushq	%rsi
	call	sme_enable
	popq	%rsi
#endif
	/* Sanitize CPU configuration */
	call verify_cpu

	 * Perform pagetable fixups. Additionally, if SME is active, encrypt
	 * the kernel and retrieve the modifier (SME encryption mask if SME
	 * is active) to be added to the initial pgdir entry that will be
	 * programmed into CR3.
	 */
	leaq	_text(%rip), %rdi
	pushq	%rsi
	call	__startup_64
	popq	%rsi

	addq	$(early_top_pgt - __START_KERNEL_map), %rax

```

protocol.

```c
void __init sme_enable(struct boot_params *bp)
{
  //...
	/* Check the SEV MSR whether SEV or SME is enabled */
	sev_status   = __rdmsr(MSR_AMD64_SEV);
	feature_mask = (sev_status & MSR_AMD64_SEV_ENABLED) ? AMD_SEV_BIT : AMD_SME_BIT;

	/* The SEV-SNP CC blob should never be present unless SEV-SNP is enabled. */
	if (snp && !(sev_status & MSR_AMD64_SEV_SNP_ENABLED))
		snp_abort();

	/* Check if memory encryption is enabled */
	if (feature_mask == AMD_SME_BIT) {
    //...
	} else {
		/* SEV state cannot be controlled by a command line option */
		sme_me_mask = me_mask;
		goto out;
	}
  //...

		physical_mask &= ~sme_me_mask;

		cc_set_mask(sme_me_mask);
	}

```

Linux provides an abstraction abstract of the capabilities of confidential
computing platforms, under namespace `x86/coco/core.c`. The interface defines
the `cc_attr`` enum that represents confidential computing features. The current
list of features are:

```c
enum cc_attr {
	/**
	 * @CC_ATTR_MEM_ENCRYPT: Memory encryption is active
	 *

	 * includes running either as a bare-metal system or a hypervisor
	 * and actively using memory encryption or as a guest/virtual machine
	 * and actively using memory encryption.
	 *

	 */
	CC_ATTR_MEM_ENCRYPT,

	/**
	 * @CC_ATTR_HOST_MEM_ENCRYPT: Host memory encryption is active
	 *
	 * The platform/OS is running as a bare-metal system or a hypervisor
	 * and actively using memory encryption.
	 *
	 * Examples include SME.
	 */
	CC_ATTR_HOST_MEM_ENCRYPT,

	/**
	 * @CC_ATTR_GUEST_MEM_ENCRYPT: Guest memory encryption is active
	 *
	 * The platform/OS is running as a guest/virtual machine and actively
	 * using memory encryption.
	 *
	 * Examples include SEV and SEV-ES.
	 */
	CC_ATTR_GUEST_MEM_ENCRYPT,

	/**
	 * @CC_ATTR_GUEST_STATE_ENCRYPT: Guest state encryption is active
	 *
	 * The platform/OS is running as a guest/virtual machine and actively
	 * using memory encryption and register state encryption.
	 *
	 * Examples include SEV-ES.
	 */
	CC_ATTR_GUEST_STATE_ENCRYPT,

	/**
	 * @CC_ATTR_GUEST_UNROLL_STRING_IO: String I/O is implemented with
	 *                                  IN/OUT instructions
	 *
	 * The platform/OS is running as a guest/virtual machine and uses
	 * IN/OUT instructions in place of string I/O.
	 *
	 * Examples include TDX guest & SEV.
	 */
	CC_ATTR_GUEST_UNROLL_STRING_IO,

	/**
	 * @CC_ATTR_SEV_SNP: Guest SNP is active.
	 *
	 * The platform/OS is running as a guest/virtual machine and actively
	 * using AMD SEV-SNP features.
	 */
	CC_ATTR_GUEST_SEV_SNP,

	/**
	 * @CC_ATTR_HOTPLUG_DISABLED: Hotplug is not supported or disabled.
	 *
	 * The platform/OS is running as a guest/virtual machine does not
	 * support CPU hotplug feature.
	 *
	 * Examples include TDX Guest.
	 */
	CC_ATTR_HOTPLUG_DISABLED,

```

The `cc_set_mask` set the global `cc_mask` variable. The `cc_mask` variable is
defined in `x86/coco/core.c`, which provides an architectural-independent
interface to control memory encryption in different architecture. `cc_mask`
holds the mask for the bit in the page table entry that indicates memory
encryption should be performed.

```c

// arch/x86/include/asm/pgtable.h
#define pgprot_encrypted(prot)	__pgprot(cc_mkenc(pgprot_val(prot)))
#define pgprot_decrypted(prot)	__pgprot(cc_mkdec(pgprot_val(prot)))

// arch/x86/coco/core.c
u64 cc_mkenc(u64 val)
{
	/*
	 * Both AMD and Intel use a bit in the page table to indicate
	 * encryption status of the page.
	 *
	 * - for AMD, bit *set* means the page is encrypted
	 * - for AMD with vTOM and for Intel, *clear* means encrypted
	 */
	switch (cc_vendor) {
	case CC_VENDOR_AMD:
		if (sev_status & MSR_AMD64_SNP_VTOM)
			return val & ~cc_mask;
		else
			return val | cc_mask;
	case CC_VENDOR_INTEL:
		return val & ~cc_mask;
	default:
		return val;
	}
}
```

To enable SME, the mask has to be set according to the bit position in the page
table entry, returned by CPUID. In `sme_enable`, line 528, you can see

```c /*
	/*
	 * Check for the SME/SEV feature:
	 *   CPUID Fn8000_001F[EAX]
	 *   - Bit 0 - Secure Memory Encryption support
	 *   - Bit 1 - Secure Encrypted Virtualization support
	 *   CPUID Fn8000_001F[EBX]
	 *   - Bits 5:0 - Pagetable bit position used to indicate encryption
	 */
	eax = 0x8000001f;
	ecx = 0;
	native_cpuid(&eax, &ebx, &ecx, &edx);
	/* Check whether SEV or SME is supported */
	if (!(eax & (AMD_SEV_BIT | AMD_SME_BIT)))
		return;

	me_mask = 1UL << (ebx & 0x3f);
```

The bit operation clears the other bits in ebx (`ebx & 0b11111`), then shift the
bit right according to the value in bits 5:0. For example, if bits 5:0 in ebx is
0b000011, it means the encryption bit (c-bit) is bit 3 of the page table entry,
and the mask should be 0b0...01000.

notes.title: Instruction punning
notes.body:
#binary-analysis

Instruction punning is used in binary rewrite
[@duck2020binary,@chamith2017instruction] extends the support for `jmp`-based
probes to instruction smaller than 5 bytes. The problem is that any bytes next
to the target rewrite may be a valid jump target.

```asm
   jmp probe (5B)
e9 xx xx xx xx xx                Target probe (only 3B)
                                          
48 89 03 	mov %rax (%rbx) 
48 83 c0 20	add $32 %rax    Some instructions may jump here

```

Punning reuse the bytes of the following instructions as the offset.

```asm

[48 89 03]  [48 83 c0 20]
             Still valid if some instructions jump here.
            
[e9 XX XX  [48 83]]c0 20]
              
               2 bytes are "punned"
```

Now, this requires that the jump target to falls in the range of (little endian)
the punned byte `83 48 XX XX`

## Adding flexibility with trapping

Another strategy is to additionally insert trapping opcode (`int3` and illegal
instructions) to flexibly changes the target for `jmp` target
[@chamith2017instruction].

```asm
             int3 trap if some instruction jump here so its fine
               Now we can repurpose this byte for extra flexiblity
              
[e9 XX XX  [cc XX]]c0 20]
              
               2 bytes are "punned"

```

Now, if the replaced instruction happens to be frequent target of control flow,
the amount of traps will destroy any performance gain from punning, so this
approach need some kind of control flow recovery [@duck2020binary] that has its
own limitations [[4yeegysq]]

## Playing with instruction encodings

Instead of relying on traps which might create overheads, e9patch
[@duck2020binary] uses several strategies, including:

### Padding

Pad the `jmp` instruction with dummy bytes to change the relative offset
encoding.

```
Now the encoded offset is c8 83 48 XX  (from 83 48 XX XX)
         
         
[48 [e9 XX ]  [48 83 c8]]
```

### Evicting instructions

This technique rewrite neighboring instructions so that the byte encoding
changes, leading to more potential jump targets.

```
     Now encoded address is XX e9 XX XX
              Rewritten (evicted) with a trampoline
             
[e9 XX XX ]  [e9 XX] XX]]
```

The rewriter can insert short jump to another location, so that it can evict an
instruction at another address. This technique, though incur more performance,
leads to reliability because most of the time there is a good evicting target
within the range of the short jump

```asm

            Rewritten to a short jump
     Jump to the actual trampoline
                                  
[eb 07 03]   .........     [e9 YY [e9] 83 7b]
                            
                             Evicted
```

Integrity Attacks on SEV
notes.lead:
Previous versions of AMD SEV lacks integrity protection for both (1) memory
encryption and (2) nested table mappings, which leads to several integrity
attacks.
notes.body:
Previous versions of AMD SEV lacks integrity protection for both (1) memory
encryption and (2) nested table mappings, which leads to several integrity
attacks.

- No integrity protection for memory allow the Hypervisor to inject arbitrary
  encrypted payload and rely on an decryption oracle (a gadget that copy memory
  from private to shared) to decrypt memory [@wilke2020sevurity]. SEV-SNP
  disallow the hypervisor write access to private memory pages with RMP checks.
- Non page table mapping enables the attacker to change the page table mapping
  to point to an injected code page [@morbitzer2021severity]. SEV-SNP verify the
  integrity of page table mappings.

notes.title: Intel SGX
notes.body:
#sgx

# Execution flow

An enclave is entered with the instruction `EENTER`
(<https://www.felixcloutier.com/x86/eenter>), which launches the enclave at a
predefined and attested entry point. CENTER is invoked with `ENCLU`, with the
index for it contained in the eax register (i.e., `ENCLU[EENTER]`).

## `EENTER`

`EENTER` takes RBX and RCX as an argument. RBX contains the memory region for
the thread control block (TCS) of the enclave to be executed. RCX contains the
address of the Asynchronous exit pointer (AEP), which is a handler that will be
executed when the host serves faults from the enclave through asynchronous
enclave exit. `EENTER` flushes the TLB, then put the processor into the enclave
mode. Note that more checks are also performed, such as disabling Precise Event
Based Sampling
([SGX Internals](https://blog.quarkslab.com/overview-of-intel-sgx-part-1-sgx-internals.html)).

## EAX & `ERESUME`

On a fault, an Asynchronous enclave exit (AEX) happens, which (1) saves the
current context into a region called the state save area (SSA), pointed to by
the OS, fill the context (register content) with dummy ones, and invoke the OS
exception handler.

`ERESUME` restores the context saved by AEX and resumes the enclave's execution.
AEX and `ERESUME` mechanisms are transparent to the enclave

The SSA is managed as a stack: the TCS contains the counter for the current SSA,
and the counter is increased for each AEX. The size of an SSA is in the
`SSAFRAMESIZE` inside the enclave's SECS. `ERESUME` decreases the counter to pop
the stack of SSAs. The SSA stack allows for the reentering (`EENTER`) of the
enclave during an AEX while preserving the SSA for the previous AEX. For
instance, calling `EENTER` to query an enclave's information used to serve AEX?

# Memory management

## EPCM

The processor uses an Enclave page cache (EPC) map (EPCM) to kep track of the
status of EPC pages. The EPCM contains an entry for each EPC page to keep track
of the owner enclave and the allocation status:

| field       | bit | description                 |
| ----------- | --- | --------------------------- |
| VALID       | 1   | 0 for unallocated EPC pages |
| PT          | 8   | Page type                   |
| ENCLAVESECS |     | identify the owner enclave  |

When the processor is in enclave mode, after the PTE is fetched and PTE
permissions are checked, the MMU is modified to look up the EPCM. Hence, the
enclave is protected from the OS mapping pages incorrectly: mapping another
enclave's page, or mapping two pages to the same virtual address.

## Demand paging

SGX has two isntructions to support demand-paging:

- `EWB` evicts a page from the EPC memory and stores it in normal memory. This
  encrypts the page and also integrity-protect it. It takes `PAGEINFO` in RBX,
  EPC page address in `RCX` and the VA of normal memory in `RDX`.
- `ELDU` restores the encrypted page into EPC memory.

## SGXv1

In SGXv1, the EPCM is updated by SGX instructions `EADD`, which adds a page to
an enclave's initial memory. This allocation is static and can be attested. It
only works if the VALID bit is not set.

`EADD` takes a `PAGEINFO` structure as the parameter, which contains

1. The virtual address
2. The source non-EPC page
3. The virtual address of the SECS of the enclave
4. The virtual address of the Security information (SECINFO) of the page

### SGXv2 extensions

SGXv2 included instructions to dynamically allocate/deallocate EPC pages at
runtime. The OS uses the following instructions to manage EPC pages.

- `EAUG` add a page. It takes `SECINFO` and the virtual address of the EPC page
  as the argument.
- `EMODT` deallocate a page
- `EMODPR` changes the permissions

The enclave can then use additional instructions to confirm the allocation
requests by the OS: `EACCEPT` and `EACCEPTCOPY`.

- `EACCEPT` [felixcloutier](https://www.felixcloutier.com/x86/eaccept) takes the
  same arguments as `EAUG`.

# Related

- [[fvom56lw]]
- [[1yhmh234]]

# References

- [Quarks lab SGX Internals](https://blog.quarkslab.com/overview-of-intel-sgx-part-1-sgx-internals.html)
- [SGX 101](https://sgx101.gitbook.io/sgx101/)

notes.title: Intel Transactional Synchronization Extensions (TSX)
notes.body:
#intel #tsx

TSX simplifies concurrent programming with ISA support for transactional memory
([[cosmdjej]]). It introduce two modes of execution, hardware lock elision
(HLE), which

## Restricted Transactional Memory (RTM)

RTM adds 4 instructions: `XBEGIN`, `XEND`, `XABORT` and `XTEST` A thread can
initiate transaction with the `XBEGIN` instruction, and terminate the
transaction with `XEND`.

```c
if ((status = _xbegin()) == XBEGIN_STARTED)
  // Perform transaction
  // ...
  // commit to memory
  _xend();
else {
  // handle transaction error
}
```

In the above example, a transaction begin by calling `_xbegin()`. If it can
happen, the code inside the `if` block is executed. During the execution, if
conflicts or exceptions occur, the transaction is rolled back to `_xbegin()`,
and the program execute the `else` block, which handle the error.

TSX uses the L1 cache as the intermediate buffer for transaction. Hence, the
existing cache coherence protocols can be used to detect conflicts (e.g., memory
is modified by two transactions) without introducing new hardware logics.

### Faults during transactions

A transaction is also aborted when an interrupt occurs. For synchronous
exceptions (e.g., page faults), TSX _suppress_ the transaction and does not
deliver it to the OS. For asynchronous exceptions (e.g., timer/IO interrupts),
the exception is delivered to the OS _after_ the transaction is rolled back and
aborted, since blocking it would interfere with OS scheduling.

However, TSX does not allows the program know which type of exception happened.
Hence, page fault, divided-by-zero, conflicts, ..., are treated equally.

## Use for security

Since page faults are suppressed by TSX, the OS cannot know whether page faults
occurs or not. This property has been used by defenses against control-channel
attacks that use the page table on SGX [@shih2017tsgx]. The enclave can stop
execution, when ever it encounters a page fault. See [[fvom56lw]].

notes.title: Interface classification and partitioning
notes.body:
#security #interface

When trying to harden an interface that were not built with security in mind,
while not wanting to limit the set of features, a useful course of action is to
classify the interface with security label, and enforce further policies based
on these labels.

One guideline is to determine (1) the type of resources that an API access, and
(2) the subject that may be allowed access this resource. Confidential threat
models introduce complexity to this process. The host is in charge of resource
management but cannot access the resource. The protected application owner is
allowed to access the resource, but cannot be given too much access for resource
management.

## Example: Splitting interfaces for configurable trust

ProxOS [@ta-min2006splitting] split the application-OS interfaces into trusted
and untrusted system calls. Trusted system calls are routed to a trusted OS in
the private VM, while untrusted OS system calls are routed to the untrusted OS.

This allows for "configurable trust" in the app-OS interface
[@ta-min2006splitting]. Useful in cases where the trusted app must communicate
with the other apps through shared OS facilities (socket, pipes). This shared OS
is subjected to attacks from the untrusted application, while the trusted OS is
safely isolated.

## Example: Confidential containers

Confidential container technologies is not built with confidential computing
security model in mind, but trying to reuse the existing deployment model,
leading to a mismatch in threat model [@valdez2024crossing].

[@valdez2024crossing] apply the labels `Host-Exclusive`, `Owner-Exclusive`,
`Shared`, `Sanitized`, `Switch`, `Not Supported` to the API endpoints of in-CVM
kata container management (kata-agent). The purpose is to cleanly separate the
responsibilities between the Host system (resource allocation and management)
and owner (container management) and avoid common attack vectors such as
information leakage.

The `Sanitized`, `Switch`, `Not Supported` labels makes the partitioning process
expressive.

- `Sanitized` marks that the API input/output must be _sanitized_.
- `Switch` makes the API _state-aware_: for certain period it is accessible by
  the Host
- For certain cases where the security model cannot be applied, `Not Support` is
  reasonable.

notes.title: Interface design for distrust
notes.body:
#compartmentalization

[@lefeuvre2022assessing] proposed 8 guidelines for designing safe interface that
helps reduce the interface vulnerabilities.

## 1. Clearly segregate resources

This means that each component must be responsible for allocating and freeing
their own resources. In other words, they should _not_ expose a malloc-like
interface to other compartments. Doing so, attackers from a compartment can
exploit the allocator (e.g., heap feng shui), or trigger arbitrary
use-after-free (if the allocated data is used at both side).

## 2. Always copy cross boundary objects

In other words, never let two compartments concurrently modify data. Doing so
leads to TOCTOU issues, and the need of cross-compartment synchronization.

## 3. Simplifying API-crossing objects

APIs should not contains private states of the compartment, since they can
easily corrupted.

Moreover, private states are very hard to check for correctness, especially
pointer data.

Maintaining immutability of those state is also a hard problem.

## 4. Trusted-components allocates

The trusted component must allocates memory.

This guideline is to avoid validating may-corrupted data from other components.
Especially, for strings, since the trusted component allocate, it knows the size
of the buffer, so checking NULL-termination is not needed.

It is not sure if it is applicable to other data except from String. A more
generalized version is that the trusted component must allocate memory where the
size is unknown.

## 5. Trusted interface functions must be thread-safe

This is to avoid temporal attacks.

## 6. Ordering requirements

Interface must enforce ordering requirements if possible.

## 7. No sharing of unintialized data

This is to avoid leaking of private data in uninitalized memory.

## 8. Check for CIV ASAP

Safety checks should be performed as soon as the untrusted data is received.
This is because it is very hard to ensure the safety once the data is propagated
throughout the program, which leads to duplicated checks.

Moreover, it prevent untrusted data from flowing to other compartments.

notes.title: Interface security
notes.lead:
Thanks to abstractions, software components exposes _interfaces_ (APIs,
notifications, RPCs, queues) to each other to hide the underlying
implementations. Each software components are also encouraged to be
isolated/compartmentalized from each other according to the principle of least
privilege.
notes.body:
Thanks to abstractions, software components exposes _interfaces_ (APIs,
notifications, RPCs, queues) to each other to hide the underlying
implementations. Each software components are also encouraged to be
isolated/compartmentalized from each other according to the principle of least
privilege.

Communications between isolated components leads to the problem of _interface
security_, where the interface between the components should not compromise the
enforced isolation between them. Interface vulnerabilities is a manifestation of
the confused deputy problem [@lefeuvre2023assessing] [[y9wu5ut7]].

Thus, considerations must be made in designing interfaces for security
[[qti6u06p]].

## Across the stacks

The interface problem exists in multiple layers of software where there exist
isolation boundaries. Here are some examples:

1. The two-way boundaries between (confidential) virtual machines and host
   [@hetzelt2021analyzing,@li2019exploiting].
2. Syscall: A malicious process can exploit the system call interface to
   tricking the kernel into corrupting itself. The kernel can feed data through
   syscall responses to a protected application (Iago attack
   [@checkoway2013iago]). Subprocess components can use the syscall to attack
   each other [@yang2024endokernel,@connor2020pku] other.
3. Libraries APIs, in-process compartments, whose are not originally designed
   for compartmentalization [@lefeuvre2023assessing].

# Interface security

Thanks to abstractions, software components exposes _interfaces_ (APIs,
notifications, RPCs, queues) to each other to hide the underlying
implementations. Each software components are also encouraged to be
isolated/compartmentalized from each other according to the principle of least
privilege.

Communications between isolated components leads to the problem of _interface
security_, where the interface between the components should not compromise the
enforced isolation between them. Interface vulnerabilities is a manifestation of
the confused deputy problem [@lefeuvre2023assessing] [[y9wu5ut7]].

Thus, considerations must be made in designing interfaces for security
[[qti6u06p]].

## Across the stacks

The interface problem exists in multiple layers of software where there exist
isolation boundaries. Here are some examples:

1. The two-way boundaries between (confidential) virtual machines and host
   [@hetzelt2021analyzing,@li2019exploiting].
2. Syscall: A malicious process can exploit the system call interface to
   tricking the kernel into corrupting itself. The kernel can feed data through
   syscall responses to a protected application (Iago attack
   [@checkoway2013iago]). Subprocess components can use the syscall to attack
   each other [@yang2024endokernel,@connor2020pku] other.
3. Libraries APIs, in-process compartments, whose are not originally designed
   for compartmentalization [@lefeuvre2023assessing].

notes.title: Interrupt handling in Unikraft (x86)
notes.body:
#unikraft

On x86, `lidt %0` loads the IDT address into IDT register ([osdev]).

In Unikraft, `traps_table_init` initialize the traps vector table, a.k.a the IDT
([osdev]). It writes into the `cpu_idt` table, with the corresponding trap
index.

The function pointer to the handler in IDT is set to a stub, named
`asm_trap_{trapname}` (defined by the macro `ASM_TRAP_SYM`). E.g.,
`asm_trap_page_fault`.

The stubs are defined in `cpu_vectors_x86_64.S`. Its implementation stores the
register states into `struct __reg` and calls the function with the name
`do_{trapname}`. Declarations of these `do_*` functions can be found in
`plat/x86/traps.c`.

The following macro create implementations for the trap that actually call a
`_raise_event_{event}` function.

```c
#define DECLARE_TRAP(name, str, event)                                         \
  void do_##name(struct __regs *regs) {                                        \
    int rc;                                                                    \
    rc = _raise_event_##event(TRAP_##name, regs, 0);                           \
    if (unlikely(rc < 0))                                                      \
      uk_pr_crit("trap handler returned error: %d\n", rc);                     \
                                                                               \
    if (!rc)                                                                   \
      do_unhandled_trap(TRAP_##name, str, regs, 0);                            \
  }
```

```c
DECLARE_TRAP(debug, "debug", UKARCH_TRAP_DEBUG)
DECLARE_TRAP_EC(int3, "int3", UKARCH_TRAP_DEBUG)
```

When raise_event is called, it invokes the list of handlers registered for the
event. For example, `do_page_fault` invoke the registered handler for
`UKARCH_TRAP_PAGE_FAULT`. The handler is registered in
`ukvmem/arch/x86_64/pagefault.c` with `UK_EVENT_HANDLER_PRIO`.

This design enables an architectural event to be handled in many stages.

## References

- [osdev]: [url](https://wiki.osdev.org/Interrupt_Descriptor_Table)

notes.title: Invariants in Rust
notes.body:
#rust

Ralf Jung described two types of *invariants* in Rust in [this post](https://www.ralfj.de/blog/2018/08/22/two-kinds-of-invariants.html), *safety* and *validity*.

# Safety invariant
Essentially, *safety invariants* are the invariants of a particualr types, that must be upholded, such that that *no matter what safe code does, it must not cause undefine behaviors*.

One example of this for any primitive type `T`, the invariant is that the object having the type must be initialized (accesing unintialized data is an undefined behavior). Another example is that reference types must be aligned, non-null, and points to an allocated memory that have no other pointer accesses.


## Custom/higher-order safety invariants
There can also be *custom* safety invariants -- *higher-order* invariants that are not maintained by the compiler, but must be maintained by the unsafe code @bae2021rudra. For example, *Vec*, defined as 
```rust
pub struct Vec<T> {
    ptr: Unique<T>, // pointing to the heap-allocated backing store holding all the data
    cap: usize, // number of elements that fit the backing store
    len: usize, // number of elements that are actually initialized in the backing store
}
```
, must uphold that `ptr` must points to valid memory size of `cap*sizeof(T)`, . The difference between invariants of Vec and other primitive types is that it is defined by the owner, and that the implementer of the type and the unsafe users must uphold them.

More specifically, for those types, the Rust compiler only guarantee the corectnesses of the signature. Some higher-order invariants can related to (see @bae2021rudra): 
1. Logical consistency (e.g., respecting total ordering)
2. Purity (e.g., always returns same value for the same input, have no side effect) (possibly related to [[013pr50f]])
3. Semantic restrictions (e.g., only write to the arguments because it may contains unintialized memory)
NOTE: It seems that the first and second types of higher-order invariants cannot trigger undefined behaviors by themself. It is not sure we should consider them safety invariants, even. [There has been discussion among Rust community about this](https://users.rust-lang.org/t/should-i-use-unsafe-merely-to-encourage-users-to-maintain-invariants/27856/4). The conclusion was that they should *not* be unsafe invariants.

### Invariant boundaries of unsafe
The unsafe code writter to make sure that they are correct *only at the boundaries* with safe code.
This boundary highly depends on the unsafe user. Generally, if an *unsafe* block is well-contained, the safety invariants should be upholded *at the end* of the unsafe scope.
On the other hand, for some libraries that use unsafe, but provide safe wrapper for safe code to use, the safety

---

# Validity invariants
The other type of invariant is the validity invariant. Validity invariants are the invariants that must be maintained between Rust and the compiler, so that the optimization can be performed safely. For instance, `Option<bool>` can be stored in 1 byte of memory, because it can only have three possible values (`true`, `false` and `None`).


Different from safety invariant that the unsafe code must uphold only at the boundaries with safe code, validity invariants are the invariants unsafe must *always* uphold.


# Related notes
[[zzq5zy5v]]

notes.title: InvisiPage: Oblivious Demand Paging for Secure Enclaves
notes.body:
#literature [@aga2019invisipage]

## Summary

Two-page tables are assumed: one to map EPC pages, and the other to map normal
pages. The EPC page table is safely stored within the EPC, and only the enclave
can maintain it. Moreover, page faults are handled by the in-enclave page fault
handler, so that the faulting address is not learned by the OS. Based on this,
InvisiPage then supports the oblivious _demand paging_ for the EPC pages. It
supports the spilling of EPC pages into non-EPC memory and uses ORAM to decide
which pages to spill.

## Oblivious page management

The goal is to allow the OS to control how many pages that are allocated to an
enclave, but not which virtual address that are mapped.

First, it maintains two page tables, one to map the EPC pages, the other is for
normal use. This approach already exists in [@costan2016sanctum]. However, the
new thing is that it allows the OS to swap EPC pages into non-EPC memory
obliviously.

To do this, the enclave and the OS have to collaborate for memory management.

## Collaborative memory management

### Spilling EPC page to non-EPC

The OS provides interface to spill a list of provided virtual addresses to
non-EPC memory (`opam_access(o-vpn[])`)

The ORAM tree is maintained by the OS in a separate tree data structure. This
tree is indexed by the oblivious page number (`o-vpn`), which is essentially the
block ID in the ORAM tree.

On receiving the `opam_access()` request, the OS has to keep the requested pages
_memory-resident_. The enclave runtime then spills/fetches the EPC pages
according to the ORAM algorithm.

On a spill, data from EPC pages are copied into non-EPC pages. For fetches, data
from non-EPC pages are copied into EPC pages. For this step, there is one
optimization introduced: only one page is copied from thea non-EPC into EPC
memory. The rest of the non-EPC pages are reshuffled within the non-EPC memory.
To the OS, it only seems like a path is accessed. It cannot tell which page is
actually copied into the EPC.

The page table is retrofitted to store position map information.

### Freeing an EPC page

To free a EPC page, the OS request a free request to the enclave, but the actual
page that get freed is schosen by the enclave.

notes.title: Kernel Bypass / Direct I/O / DPDK
notes.body:
#io #os

Kernel bypass maps the IO memory for hardware devices (PCIe, NIC) directly to
into userspace memory, allowing applications to build their I/O processing
entirely outside of the kernel, avoiding expensive syscalls. DPDK is the main
user of the approach by Intel.

## Performance

DPDK achives 4.5x performance gain against traditional Linux stack ([src]).
However, many of the performance gain is from the decisions made by DPDK, which
may also be applied to Linux. When the Linux is fully optimzied, DPDK is only
about 50% faster ([src])

- [src]: https://talawah.io/blog/linux-kernel-vs-dpdk-http-performance-showdown/

## Safety issues

DPDK requires that the application be the sole user of the device. While runing
DPDK in a virtualized environment is possible ot multiplex hardware, it defeat
the purpose of the technique the first place (while it can be used to boost
virtualized I/O performance [@li2024bridge] similarly to non-virtualized).

Single Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) is an extension to the PCIe inteface to
allows a single physical device to be safely **partitioned** between VMs at the
hardware level. Several work introduces OS abstractions to take advantage of
this for safe [@peter2014arrakis]. Hardware support leads to near-native
virtualized I/O performances using DPDK, but require dedicated hardware support
and reduce the host OS flexibility [@hedayati2019hodor].

### Isolation

[@hedayati2019hodor] suggests fault-isolating the DPDK stack via fast in-process
isolation (PKU,VMFUNC) with a protected library abstraction. Library OSes
[@belay2014ix,@peter2014arrakis] are also proposed to provide VM-level isolation
to direct-IO stacks.

notes.title: Kernel long development cycles
notes.body:
#os

Developing things at the kernel level takes a lot of time. Take networking for
example. To reload a driver, one would need to close all the active networking
applications, or more reboot the entire system. It takes up to 1-2 months do
deploy a change to the networking stack [@marty2019snap].

For this reason, an option for fast development cycles is to bring things to the
userspace. This is especially important for applications that intimately
interact with hardware and are performance sensitive like networking.

notes.title: Kernel/User Semantic Gaps
notes.lead:
Semantic gaps are commonly discussed in the context of virtualizations between
VMs and hypervisor. However, it is also the bottleneck in many userspace
mechanisms. Here are two:
notes.body:
Semantic gaps are commonly discussed in the context of virtualizations between
VMs and hypervisor. However, it is also the bottleneck in many userspace
mechanisms. Here are two:

- **In-process resources isolation**. When userspace security domains are
  created, the system call interface inerently interface vulnerabilities
  [@lefeuvre2024sok] enabling the bypassing of userspace memory isolation
  mechanisms. This is inerently due to the kernel not being aware of userspace
  security domains, and enforce a different security policy for process-wide
  system resources. Many userspace comparmentalization work are made to be aware
  of this gap. Still, it's complicated to make safe with signal deliveries and
  threading [@yang2024endokernel].
- **Memory mapping management**. Leveraging the mostly unused address space to
  implement one-time-allocation is a common technique to prevent use-after-free.
  However, this approach results in huge memory consumptions, so a common
  technique is to create "alias" mappings. Creating these mappings require
  syscalls incur a lot of overheads [@ahn2024budalloc].

## Overcoming the gap

A way to overcome this semantic gap is to (1) make the kernelspace aware of
userspace mechanisms, or (2) the other way around.

For (1), this comes as the cost of introducing complexities to kernel
implementation, and also leads to safety issues.

- Many work propose "minimal" modifications to the kernel to achieve their goal
  [@peng2023mswitch].
- eBPF is a safe interface that enable extensibility [@ahn2024budalloc], but
  also have costs in expressiveness.
- Single address-space libOSes and unikernels
  [@belay2012dune,@gorter2022dangzero] allows userspace mechansims to directly
  access the underlying hardware. However, they loose the rich abstrations
  provided by Linux kernel, and also lead to reduced compatibility.
- This approach reuses existing kernel abstrations, better for maintainability.
  It may lack expressiveness, due to having to constrain to existing APIs and
  interfaces (e.g., eBPF). Otherwise, significant changes to the kernel is

The other case (2) introduce significant complexities to the userspace.

- [@schrammel2022jenny] uses the Syscall User Dispatch SUD to forward the system
  call decisions to userspace.
- [@yang2024endokernel] basically virtualizes all kernel abstrations (syscall,
  signals, file system, memory mappings, threads).
- This approach may be better for more expressiveness in defining userspace
  policies.
- This create new complexities that is challenging to ensure security.

## Synchronization

When bridging the semantic gap, a kind of "synchronization" of states is
required. This synchronization must cross the user-kernel worlds, e.g., through
syscalls, which is expensive. A common technique is to only perform this
synchronization whenever required.

- $\mu$switch switches [@peng2023mswitch] the memory view in the userspace, and
  only synchronize the kernel state on system calls (e.g., implicit context
  switch).
- Budalloc [@ahn2024budalloc] install custom eBPF handler that automatically
  manage VA-to-PA mappings based on user-defined memory mappings policies.

notes.title: Klotski: Efficient Obfuscated Execution against Controlled-Channel Attacks
notes.body:
#literature #controlled-channel #oblivious #sgx @zhang2020klotski

## Noteworthy Arguments

### Positioning

- Previous solutions for controlled-channel protection are either (0) incomplete
  against attacks, (2) have incomplete protection for code and data, and (3) has
  high overheads.
- Incompleteness against attack:

  - TSX-based solutions [@shih2017tsgx] , that tries to detect interrupts of
    enclaves, but there has been attacks that can trigger without enclave exit.

- Incomplete protection for code and data

  - Some only protect data accesses @sasy2018zerotrace @drsgx
  - Other only protect code access @zizagger, and can be defeated fine-grained
    attack

- High overheads
  - @shinde2016preventing places sensitive code and data inside one page, but
    has high overheads (4000x)
  - Obfuscuro @ahmad2019obfuscuro only supports small code and data size (8KB).

## Oblivious memory subsystem scheme

### Memory subsystem

Klotski's memory subsystem consists of three levels (akin to the actual memory
subsystem). The first is the code and data caches, that has reconfigurable
sizes, called the _vCache_. The second level is the ORAM _stashes_ for code and
data. The final layer is the _ORAM tree_.

The stash and the tree are parts of an ORAM scheme.

Memory from the higher level is evicted into the lower level, with some
policies.

The main reason for _vCache_ is to trade-off security for some performance. This
is the main difference with Obfuscuro @ahmad2019obfuscuro vCache can be
configure to be larger than the page size.

- Why do you need three levels, why not just configure the stash size then?

    work (e.g., the path does not fit into the stash).
  - The stash in untrusted memory, an can span several pages.
  - Similar to [@ahmad2019obfuscuro]: just storing pages in the stash would leak
    lotta info since stash size is large.

@sasy2018zerotrace?

  into untrusted storage.

## Memory access hierarchy

### Logical addresses

Logical addresses are the address that the instructions use (i.e., virtual
addresses).

Klotski use 32-bit addresses in their implementation, maybe to limit the number
of entries in the software PT?

The program is instrumented to _translate_ the logical address on every
operations into _real address_, which is an address inside the execution cache.

as real page table. The following function translates logical address into page
table index:

```cpp
size_t getRealAddress(size_t logicAddr){

```

The address itself also seems to contain the block ID.
`LOGIC_INDEX_TO_BLOCK_INDEX(index,blockIndex)` gets the correct block ID from
the position map index.

In this translation function, if page is not in the page table, then it is not
in the cache, so address translation happen. This is not what is described in
the paper: a PTE also contains the path ID. Maybe this function is only used for
static data...

The real translation function seems to be `dereference_data()`.

### ORAM access

On a page miss, ORAM access is triggered to fetch block into the vCache. First,
the ORAM block (2KB _minipage_) is fetched in to the _stash_, and the position
map is updated. The block is then moved to the vCache, and a block inside vCache
is swapped out.

#### Stash<->ORAM

Ring ORAM evict the blocks after $k$ accesses. On eviction, blocks inside the
stash is flushed into the ORAM tree.

#### vCache<->Stash

The minipage is then swapped into the vCache, where a block is _randomly_
evicted from the vCache to make space.

The paper argue that _LRU_ cache eviction may leak information.

There is also a reconfigurable re-randomization of the vCache: the user can
configure such that the vCache is flushed after $n$ accesses.

inside vCache, in the same way a MMU translate physical to virtual address.

```c

loadImm R1, logicalAddr
call vPTE_lookup(R1)
// use pointer
load R2, R1
...
```

```c
    vPTE_t vPTE = position_map_scan(logicalAddr);
    if (vPTE.cached)
        return vPTE.addr;
    else
        // slow path
       if (vPTE.in_stash)
           vPTE = stash_fetch(vPTE.oramIndex);
       else
           vPTE = oram_read(vPTE.oramIndex);
       return vPTE.addr;
}
```

### Operations

#### vCache and Stash

- `LoadCache` reads the target minipage

## Compiler & runtime

Compiler changes all memory instructions, call, return, into calls into the
runtime functions. Implementation:
[Here](https://github.com/nczhang88pan/KlotskiSGX/tree/master/klotski/llvmProgram/llvm/lib/Transforms/Instrumentation/Klotski)
Maybe the compiler transformation would looks like this:

```llvm
%0 = alloca 100
%1 = load ptr %arg1
%2 = add %1, 100
call foo()
store %2, ptr %0
---
%1 = call mmu_load(%arg1)
%2 = add %1, 100
call mmu_call(&foo)
call mmu_store(%2, %1)
```

The compiler also split code and data into blocks of 2KB, which is also the ORAM
block size. The code is compiled as relocatable code, so that it can be
relocated to any virtual addresses.

-  Why do you need relocatable code here?
-  What is effiective virtual address, why does it change at runtime?

The runtime functions acts as a memory subsystem: given a virtual address, it
look up

## ORAM Accesses

The paper uses Ring ORAM for its ORAM algorithm. However, there are several
noteworthy extensions. Because the memory used for posmap (virtual page table)
and stash is in untrusted memory, attackers can find out which stash slot and
posmap entry is accessed.

### ORead

An `ORead` operation is introduced to lineary scan over all data that must be
touched to remain oblivious, similar to a `cmov`. The data is stored into a
256-bit ymm registers. 1 register is reserved for reading unused data, and the
remainings is used to store the required data.

NOTE: it is not exactly similar to `CMOV`, you only need to actually touch the
data in `ORead`, but not write it back.

---

The `ReadPath` operation that read from ORAM path into stash uses this to bring
data into the stash without revealing the actual bucket/block that is accessed.

For example, consider fetching of a path in traditional Ring ORAM. On each
bucket along the path, a block is fetched, but discarded. On the block that
contain non-dummy data, it is actually read into the stash. With visibility over
stash and tree, the attacker can see that there is a read from the tree,
following by a write into the stash. This means that the block that is just read
contains the requested data.

By fetching all data into YMM registers, and delay the write back to the stash
to the last moment, this can be hidden.

---

`LoadCache` that load an entry from stash into cache also needs this (for same
reason above). It must scan over all stash entries, and only copy the one needed
into the vCache.

## WriteStash

The WriteStash operation, that write into the stash, is also made oblivious.
There are two potential leakage, when the attacker learns about the stash
access:

1. If data is written into a slot, it means that the slot is empty, so it must
   have been evicted recently.
2. If data is written into a stash slot twice (without being read), it can be
   infered that the slot contained dummy blocks.  Is there actually dummy
   blocks in the stash?

To solve this, every (1) block must only be written once (before being
reshuffled), and (2) a write to a slot must not reveal the last block being
evicted Klotski solve this by keeping a pointer to slot that is last written,
and increment the pointer to the next slot at every write. When the pointer move
to the last empty blocks, the stash is reshuffled.

```
      Spare stash ptr
            |
            v
| 2 | 5 | 3 | <empty> | 4 | <empty> |
```

After write:

```
                      v
| 2 | 5 | 3 | *6* | 4 | < empty > |
```

Pointer moved to the last empty block, so reshuffle:

```
                           v
| 2 | <evited> | <evicted> | 6 | 4 | *1* |
```

Reshuffling moves actual blocks to the begining and update the spare stash ptr.

```
                v
| 6 | 1 | 4 | 2 | <empty> | <empty> |
```

notes.title: Knowledge flower
notes.body:
#zettelkasten #note-taking

[This blog post](https://zettelkasten.de/posts/creative-technique-within-zettelkasten-framework/)
proposes a framework to think about zettelkasten notes.

1. Choose an idea and place it in the center.
2. Think of each leaf as an aspect of the thought that is needed to fully
   develop it. The thought blossoms like a flower.

- _Truth_: Are there arguments for its truth? Is there empirical evidence for
  its truth? Is it free of self-contradiction?
- _Relevance_: To whom is the thought important? To whom is it not?
- _Usefulness_: What problem can be solved by the thought? Can it become a tool?
- _Beauty_: How does the thought promote harmony and elegance?
- _Simplicity_: How can you make the thought simpler and easier to understand?
  Can the thought be used to simplify something else?

notes.title: LLVM register data flow graph
notes.body:
#area #llvm #analysis #backend

LLVM provides a Register Data Flow Graph that contains the flow of registers
between instructions. Probably useful for some backend analysis.

- [LLVM: include/llvm/CodeGen/RDFGraph.h Source File](https://llvm.org/doxygen/RDFGraph_8h_source.html).

The graph is a collection of **Nodes**, where each node can be either a **code
node** or a **reference node**.

- A **code node** is a collection of other nodes. E.g., A **basic block** code
  node contains **instruction** code nodes, and instruction code node contains
  **Reference nodes**
- **Reference node** describe the register reference. It can either be a
  **DefNode** or a **UseNode**
  - DefNode defines the register
  - UseNode uses the register

DefNode contains:

- Reaching definitions: Nodes that this definition uses
- Sibling: nodes with the same reaching definition as this node
- First reached use: the first node that use this definition.
  - To traverse other register uses, we can use the slibing of the UseNode
- First reached definition: First node after this that redefine the register
  UseNode contains :
- Reaching definitions: Nodes that this definition uses
- Sibling: nodes with the same reaching definition as this node

Linux DMA APIs
notes.lead:
There are two types of DMA mappings, streaming and consistent. Streaming are
mapped for one DMA transfer, then unmapped right after. This mean only one party
can access the DMA memory at a time. Consistent/coherent remains mapped
throughout execution, allowing both side access.
notes.body:
There are two types of DMA mappings, streaming and consistent. Streaming are
mapped for one DMA transfer, then unmapped right after. This mean only one party
can access the DMA memory at a time. Consistent/coherent remains mapped
throughout execution, allowing both side access.

API interaction with IOMMU [[hxm4jt6e]]:

- `dma_map` Initialize the transaction. It takes a buffer address, size and
  access rights, allocate an IOVA from the device address space, then create a
  mapping in the device's IOMMU page table. An IOVA address is returned to the
  caller. The control of the buffer is now belong to the device.
- `dma_unmap` Ends the transaction. It takes IOVA address, unmap the buffer
  inside IOMMU page table, returns the address range IOVA space. Now the device
  is not able to access the buffer, and the driver can read data from it.
- `dma_alloc_coherent`/ `dma_free_coherent` allocate/free memory accessible by
  both device and OS (remained mapped in IOMMU). Useful in implementing
  descriptor rings, mailboxes.

- [linux-dma]: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/DMA-API-HOWTO.txt

notes.title: Linux exception table
notes.body:
#linux

The exception table is used in Linux to handle faults in userspace access (e.g.,
through `get_user`). The point is to delay the checking of safe user access
until a page fault.

On a user access, one of 4 scenarios may occur:

1. Accessible, nothing is wrong
2. Inaccessible, but the address is in the user process's VMA
3. Inaccessible, and the address is NOT in user process's VMA, and
      1. The faulting instruction is in the exception table
      2. The faulting instruction is NOT in the exception table

In cases 2 and 3, the page fault handler is invoked due to permission
errors/unmapped pages. Case 2 is treated as normal user space page fault, so the
page fault handler maps the address.

For case 3, the kernel now must determine if the inaccessible instruction is
recoverable. If exception happens from userspace memory access, kernel should be
able to recover from it. Exception table allows the kernel to register custom
exection handler for these user access sites to handle case 3.1.

For case 3.2, the user access is done at an unknown site.

`do_user_addr_fault`

```c
 /*
  * Kernel-mode access to the user address space should only occur
  * on well-defined single instructions listed in the exception
  * tables.  But, an erroneous kernel fault occurring outside one of
  * those areas which also holds mmap_lock might deadlock attempting
  * to validate the fault against the address space.
  *
  * Only do the expensive exception table search when we might be at
  * risk of a deadlock.  This happens if we
  * 1. Failed to acquire mmap_lock, and
  * 2. The access did not originate in userspace.
  */
 if (unlikely(!mmap_read_trylock(mm))) {
   if (!user_mode(regs) && !search_exception_tables(regs->ip)) {
     /*
      * Fault from code in kernel from
      * which we do not expect faults.
      */
     bad_area_nosemaphore(regs, error_code, address);
     return;
   }
   /* ... */
 }
```

## Exception table

In Linux's source code:

```c
/*
 * The exception table consists of two addresses relative to the
 * exception table entry itself and a type selector field.
 *
 * The first address is of an instruction that is allowed to fault, the
 * second is the target at which the program should continue.
 *
 * The type entry is used by fixup_exception() to select the handler to
 * deal with the fault caused by the instruction in the first field.
 *
 * All the routines below use bits of fixup code that are out of line
 * with the main instruction path.  This means when everything is well,
 * we don't even have to jump over them.  Further, they do not intrude
 * on our cache or tlb entries.
 */

struct exception_table_entry {
  int insn, fixup, data;
};
```

At every user access site, an entry to the exception table is registered. e.g..

```c
#define __get_user_asm(x, addr, itype, ltype, label)                           \
  asm_volatile_goto("\n"                                                       \
                    "1: mov" itype                                             \
                    " %[umem],%[output]\n" _ASM_EXTABLE_UA(1b, % l2)           \
                    : [output] ltype(x)                                        \
                    : [umem] "m"(__m(addr))                                    \
                    :                                                          \
                    : label)
```

The kernel linker script `vmlinux.lds.h` collects these entries into the
`__ex_table` symbol:

```c
*Exception table * /
#define EXCEPTION_TABLE(align)                                                 \
  .= ALIGN(align);                                                             \
  __ex_table:                                                                  \
  AT(ADDR(__ex_table) - LOAD_OFFSET) {                                         \
    __start___ex_table =.;                                                     \
    KEEP(*(__ex_table))                                                        \
    __stop___ex_table =.;                                                      \
  }
```

## Reference

- <https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/x86/exception-tables.txt>

# Linux exception table

#linux

The exception table is used in Linux to handle faults in userspace access (e.g.,
through `get_user`). The point is to delay the checking of safe user access
until a page fault.

On a user access, one of 4 scenarios may occur:

1. Accessible, nothing is wrong
2. Inaccessible, but the address is in the user process's VMA
3. Inaccessible, and the address is NOT in user process's VMA, and
      1. The faulting instruction is in the exception table
      2. The faulting instruction is NOT in the exception table

In cases 2 and 3, the page fault handler is invoked due to permission
errors/unmapped pages. Case 2 is treated as normal user space page fault, so the
page fault handler maps the address.

For case 3, the kernel now must determine if the inaccessible instruction is
recoverable. If exception happens from userspace memory access, kernel should be
able to recover from it. Exception table allows the kernel to register custom

notes.title: Linux thrashing on OOM
notes.body:
#linux-user #distro #arch

On linux, when swap is enabled, sometimes the system becomes unresponsive when
the memory use is high. This is because of continuous swapping of memory that
locks the system.

## EarlyOOM

EarlyOOM utility kills the process before the system goes into thrashing.

- <https://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Changes/EnableEarlyoom>
- <https://github.com/rfjakob/earlyoom>

In arch it can be enabled through package earlyoom

```bash
sudo pacman -S earlyoom
systemctl enable earlyoom
systemctl start earlyoom
```

notes.title: Memory Encryption vs. Access Control
notes.lead:
TEEs often uses a combination of access control and automatic memory encryption
to achieve confidentiality and integrity. For software attacks, access control
is sufficient.
notes.body:
TEEs often uses a combination of access control and automatic memory encryption
to achieve confidentiality and integrity. For software attacks, access control
is sufficient.

Access control prevent subjects that use the shared CPU to access shared memory.
Hardware DMA accesses also have a kind of access control through the IOMMU
[[hxm4jt6e]] [@feng2024siopmp] [@sang2024portal].

Memory encryption is useful against attackers with very high capabilities that
bypass the CPU (e.g., hardware attacks on DRAM or bus snooping
[@lee2020offchip]).

However, doing _both_ at the same time may be redundant if the assumption of
hardware attack is not practical. For example, on mobile SoC, every component is
baked into the chip and there also some kind of hardware tamper detection, so
inserting probe into the SoC is very unlikely [@sang2024portal].

Especially, _memory encryption is not free_, as it needs (1) CPU acceleration
for encryption and (2) the device to also support decryption for I/O case. In
these scenarios, getting rid of memory encryption and adding more comprehensive
access control is a more practical choice [@sang2024portal].

Microkernels
notes.body:
#os

The microkernel is a minimized OS layer that only implement the minimal
_mechanisms_ [[8113ygxd]] for safe multiplexing and interactions, while letting
the _policies_ being implemented in the userspace.

The three fundamental pieces of a microkernel are **address spaces** (memory
management), **scheduling** (time-share management), **inter-process**
communication (IPC) (first conceptualized in [@liedtke1995microkernel]). Looking
back at the goals of operating systems [[7t4jlnaq]], these are the minimum
abstraction to achieve them.

- **Scheduling**: Kernel only implement context switching mechanisms and
  interruption. Scheduling decisions is implemented in userspace.
- **Memory management**: Memory allocation policies, e.g., malloc, free are
  implemented in userspace.
- **IPC**: Message routing and services are implemented in userspace. The kernel
  does not try to interpret the message content.

Microkernel offloads most the remaining functionality, e.g., device drivers,
file system, into the userspace. This contributes to the minimal kernel control
plane, making formal verification feasible [@klein2009sel4].

notes.title: Network Functions Virtualization (NFV) and Middleboxes
notes.body:
#networking

Network function virtualization virtualize a class of networking functions
(commonly provided by hardware devices) and implement them in software that run
on COTS processors. This is the results of efforts done by large carriers
somewhere in 2012 [@panda2016netbricks]. A virtual network function is also
called a _software middlebox_.

This approach provides several advantages to traditional devices:

- **Flexible network architecture implementations** (e.g., firewall, load
  balancers, WAN [[q4cvky96]], ... ). This allows faster development and also
  deployment.
- **Simplified management.** NFV are usually deployed in virtual
  machines/containers, so there management is the same as VM management.
  - Multiple NF can be served in a single machine leading to better resource
    utilization.
  - This also provide fine-grained resource accounting for implementing
    pay-as-you-go models.

This naturally leads to a service model where third party services provide
networking functionalities like firewall, load balancer, VPN, to enterprises as
cloud services [[ijh22i54]].

Traditionally network functions are running in VMs, which comes at a high costs
for isolation, which leads to exploration for more lightweight isolation models,
e.g., using language runtime [@panda2016netbricks].

notes.title: Network flow
notes.body:
#networking

A flow in networking is a set of identifying information that helps identifying
packets belonging to a particular trafic. This is important in ensuring scalable
network processing.

A _flow identifier_ identify packet belong to a certain flow. This is useful in
automating networking tasks like forwarding packets of some flow to some ports.

```
in_port(1), eth(src=e0:91:f5:21:d0:b2, dst=00:02:e3:0f:80:a4),
eth_type(0x0800), ipv4(src=172.16.0.20, dst=172.18.0.52, proto=17, tos=0,
frag=no), tcp(src=49163, dst=80)
```

Identifying flows useful in scaling network processing. For example, hardware
NICs provides multiple Tx, Rx rings, and enforces each rings to contain packets
of certain flow [@turtles] [[2i45v7qf]]. Some NICs determine the rings is based
on the hashing of certain fields packet headers (also called Recieved Side
Scalling (RSS)).

notes.title: Networking Stack Overheads and Optimizations
notes.body:
#io #networking

## Cost study

[@peter2014arrakis] profiled the cost of networking in a Linux process and
categorized the costs into 4 categories:

- Network stack costs: Time for packet processing packet headers.
- Scheduler overheads: Time to wake up a process, select it to run, and context
  switching.
- Kernel crossings: The time to switch between kernel/user
- Copying of packet data: Packets are copied between users and kernel on sendmsg
  and recvmsg system calls.

|                 |         | Percentage (%) |
| --------------- | ------- | -------------- |
| Network stack   | in      | 37.6           |
|                 | out     | 31.3           |
| Scheduler       |         | 5              |
| Copy            | in      | 7.1            |
|                 | out     | 13.2           |
| Kernel Crossing | syscall | 2.9            |
|                 | return  | 2.9            |

## Optimizations

Certain costs might be eliminated completely if the stack is to be refactored.

- Direct I/O ([[qctx04tc]]) and unikernels remove kernel crossing costs.
- Scheduling costs is removed with a run-to-completion model [[llh2ly47]], where
  a thread perform all packet processing steps until it completes
  [@belay2014ix].
- Removing copying at the syscall boundary (zero-copy) removes the cost of
  copying [@peter2014arrakis].

notes.title: No Security without Integrity
notes.body:
#security

Traditionally, the (Confidentiality Integrity Availability) CIA triad represents
three main principles of information security.

However, when applied to securing software, _integrity_ is the most important,
and is the prerequisite for the other two properties. That is, if the attacker
can hijack the program execution (i.e., violating execution integrity):

- Avaiability is sure to suffer, if the attacker executes his own code instead
  of the intended one.
- Confidentiality also compromised: The attack may now modify program execution
  to leak its own secret data.

The manifestation of this imbalance is the integrity attacks on SEV [[ya2sfv7q]]
that can compromise confidentiality.

Another manifestation can be found in SFI techniques, where the "fault
isolation" aspect is emphasized to maximize availability. Thus, confidentiality
is sometime skipped as an optimization [@nativeclient], e.g., only memory writes
are instrumented, instead of read.

In memory safety, Control Flow _Integrity_ is the most adapted, since it has the
highest impact from the attacker's perspective. Confidentiality is sometimes
discussed [@scott2017datashield, @dynpte], but not as much.

separated notes and linked together.

notes.title: Novelty is Subjective
notes.body:
#research

Novelty in research usually refer to an idea, or product of research being
new/original. Usually, it add a new perspective, or contribute to existing
knowledge to the study of the field.

Novelty is subjective.

First, your idea (in the form of a research paper) is in the end judged by a
group of people (reviewers) that have their own believes and bias. A reviewer
with fewer experiences in the field might consider many ideas novel. On the
other hand, an experienced reviewer with deep knowledge might notice that a
similar idea has been discussed before.

Second, it probably follows some principles/patterns that has been applied
before [[kfs6h55d]].

Third, not only the originality is considered, the potential _impact_ of the
idea is often the more important factor. Potential impact is a highly subjective
thing, which is again judged by the biased reviewers.

notes.title: ORAM Algorithmic Optimizations
notes.body:
#oram #oblivious

## Superblock
In ORAM, because accesses are always shuffled, the locality is terrible, because individual block's position is shuffled at every access.

Superblock optimization (@ren2013design) ensures that a group of blocks are always in the stash together. This group of blocks is called the *superblock*. Accessing a block in a superblock would brings all block into the stash, which improve the locality. Note that the number of blocks in a superblock can be smaller than the height of the tree. 

At initialization time, blocks on the superblock $S$ are placed on the same leaf. Whenever a block from the superblock is requested, the entire path is brought into the stash, so the blocks in $S$ is inside the stash. Like normal Path ORAM, the leaf index of the requested block in the position map is updated. This requested block is like a leader, which all blocks in the same superblock follow. Potition of blocks in the superblock are also updated to the leader block's path. Hence, when they are evicted, they would be evicted on the same leaf. 

### Security
@ren2013design (3.2.2) argues that this does not affect the security of ORAM. On each access, superblocks are mapped to a random leaf. Same as normal path ORAM, the observer can only see randomized path accesses, regardless of the superblock. 

### Why posmap update for blocks other than the requested block is fine in this case?
This is fine fine because the superblock can be seen as a single block in the ORAM access.

In a more generalized scenario, when updating the position for blocks inside the stash, the new position should be random, or *independent* of the block content/access pattern (not sure if this is correct).

notes.title: ORAM Stash and Cache
notes.body:
#oram

In traditional ORAM algorithms, data is loaded into the stash and then used
in-placed.

However, when ORAM is retrofitted for obfuscated execution (e.g., SGX), there is
no secure client storage for stash. Commonly a scratchpad region is added
[@zhang2020klotski,@ahmad2019obfuscuro] as a cache for ORAM.

This design can also be seen in secure processor [@fletcher2015freecursive]
designs. While the stash is in secure storage, the cache is needed because there
is no locality within the stash at all, as blocks are agressively flushed each
round.

notes.title: OS Processes
notes.body:
#kernel #os #linux

In the most simple term, a process is a running program (that have been loaded
from the disk into memory and launched by the OS). A running process is defined
by its states, which includes its memory, its registers contents, and opening
files (FDs).

The OS stores a process's state is stored in the process control block (PCB)
(`task_struct` in linux). For instance, in xv6, the PCB contains:

```c
// Per-process state
struct proc {
  uint sz;                     // Size of process memory (bytes)
  pde_t* pgdir;                // Page table
  char *kstack;                // Bottom of kernel stack for this process
  enum procstate state;        // Process state
  volatile int pid;            // Process ID
  struct proc *parent;         // Parent process
  struct trapframe *tf;        // Trap frame for current syscall
  struct context *context;     // swtch() here to run process
  void *chan;                  // If non-zero, sleeping on chan
  int killed;                  // If non-zero, have been killed
  struct file *ofile[NOFILE];  // Open files
  struct inode *cwd;           // Current directory
  struct shared *shared;       // Shared memory record (0 -> none)
  char name[16];               // Process name (debugging)
};
```

The list of all process is stored by the OS in a _process list_ data structure.

## APIs

Processes are created through process system call APIs. There are API for:

### Creation

- `fork()` creates a new process identical to the current one. It copies the
  address space, file descriptors and other info to a new process. Since copying
  the entire address space is costly, Copy-on-write is used in modern systems to
  reduce the costs. Fork is rather obsoleted in modern systems .
- `exec()` spawn a new process with a given executable/forked process.

### Destroy

- A process is controlled through _signals_. The `kill()` syscall send signals
  to a process (e.g., `SIGINT`) to control it.

### Wait

- The `wait()` system call wait for a spawned process to finish.
