notes.title: Overview
notes.body:
### Adaptive obfuscation: Why and what

#### Motivations (Why)

##### High exit rates of attacks

- On the other hand, attacks have a very high exit rate, way above normal
  scenarios.

###### Empirical analysis

- We show this aspect through an empirical analysis (table x)
  - The collected numbers and why
- How we did this analysis
- The results show that the Exit rate may be clearly distinguished between
  attack and normal execution.

##### High overheads of obfuscation

- Previous work proposed overly ideal attack models leading to high overheads
- There are practical works that allow security tradeoffs.
- We extend the practical direction by using the observed high vmexit rate to
  guide the obfuscation scheme, which enables robustness without compromising
  security.

#### Our proposal: Rate-adaptive obfuscation (What)

##### Overview of rate-adaptive obfuscation

- We propose an approach that continuously monitors the trend in VMExit rate.
- The continuous rate measurement is then used to dynamically scale a memory
  re-randomization rate
- A memory rerandomization scheme re-randomizes the memory layout of the CVM
  according to the rate.

##### Why the approach works

- All side-channel attacks require one of two conditions:
  - Need a minimum temporal resolution
    - Example 1: Profiling attacks need full page memory access trace when
      serving one SSH request
    - Example 2: fine-grained side-channel attacks (cache) must be performed
      with a specific window of 1\~100 memory accesses when the sensitive
      operation is performed.
  - Have a maximum spatial resolution to be practical.
    - E.g., performing a ciphertext attack is only practical if performed on a
      limited number of pages. The overheads and costs of the attack scale
      exponentially when more pages must be monitored.
- Our approach works by providing the following two properties during attacks.

###### Principle1: Adaptively minimizing the attacker's temporal resolution

- With frequent rerandomization, the temporal resolution is continuously
  minimized during attacks.
  - A round memory rerandomization completely detaches previous side-channel
    measurements from what is to come next.
    - This means that the attacker may not carry the information learned from
      one input (e.g., the CVM page acces frequency) to the next input, as there
      will be multiple rerandomizations during one round of attack
  - Even when you can somehow bypass profiling attacks, fine-grained attacks
    have way higher exit rates, which leads to accelerated rerandomization,
    throwing attacker back to the profiling before the attack is finished.
- To overcome frequent randomization, the attacker must obtain more samples,
  which in turn triggers more rerandomization.

###### Principle2: Adaptively maximizing required spatial resolution (for fine-grained attacks)

- Now that temporal resolution is limited, e.g., memory is essentially performed
  every few accesses.
- Memory rerandomization frequently relocates the memory to random different
  addresses. Thus, it is infeasible just monitor memory accesses to a few pages.
- This renders these attacks impractical.

##### What is different from previous attempts

- Previously, there were designs for
  - Memory obfuscation using ORAM/software instrumentation,
  - Detection of abnormal exit rates (Varys, TSGX)

###### Limitation1 Detection-based approaches suffer from false-positive detections and have to reduce their detection threshold

###### Limitation2 Previous "static" obfuscation scheme suffers from high overheads or have to make tradeoffs for practicality (Klotski)

###### Advantage. Our approach overcomes the two limitations by combining the two approaches.

- During normal execution, overheads are kept low, while intense randomization
  is only during attacks.

### Challenges

To enable this approach for CVM, two challenges must be solved.

#### Challenge1How do we build a sampling system that accurately determines exit rates?

- VMxit detection: Unforgeable VMExit occurrence information in VMSA to
  establish a primitive for in-CVM sampling of VMExits
- First, a mechanism to periodically invoke VMSA sample collection without a
  trustworthy interrupt delivery becomes indispensable.
- Second, even if we do achieve such a periodic invocation, how do we build a
  sampling system that can accurately determine the current VMExit rate?

#### Challenge2 How do we design a robust rerandomization scaling based on exit rate measurement

- Now, with accurate exit rate tracking, we must design a rerandomization
  adaptation such that side-channel attacks are rendered much more difficult
  while normal execution remains usable.

#### Challenge3 How to we randomize memory layout now that the trust boundary contains the whole CVM (kenrel+user)

- Previously, numerous proposals proposed memory randomization schemes (e.g.,
  ORAM, Permutation, multiplexing), but we found them to be inadequate for whole
  CVM memory randomization.

##### Limitation3 Limited scalability

- Previous attempts at all have limited scalability when large memory is used.
  - Obfuscuro, shinde2016preventing, only supports small functions.
  - DR SGX only reerandomizes data through random permutations, and rerandomize
    and rerandomized at a at relaxed rate (every 300,000 memory accesses), but
    still have
  - Klotski Limits available memory use to 1GB (2^30)
- This is not to mention these approaches implement a kind of "SoftMMU", which
  would cause compatibility issues when the whole kernel is implemented.

##### Limitation4 Require the application's source code to be available, or manual modifications.

- They are inapplicable to third-party libraries or binary-only server programs.
- Compiler-based solutions inevitably cause complications regarding software
  maintenance; a response to a newly discovered attack vector or bugs in the the
  solution itself requires the recompilation of all target programs.

##### Limitation5 Limited applicability to the OS kernel

- The existing works\~\\cite{ahmad2019obfuscuro,obelix,zhang2020klotski} do not
  address their applicability to the OS kernel.
- A full system obfuscation (i.e., including the OS kernel) is crucial in
  protecting CVM-based workloads.
- However, a security guarantee through a custom compiler pass is hardly
  feasible for kernels due to its peculiar programming patterns that involve
  inline assemblies and complex preprocessor macros.
- Moreover, the TCB of \\gls{cvm} application is significantly increased now
  that it includes a full OS kernel. Even considering the size of
  microVMs\~\\cite{agache2020firecracker}, the total memory footprint is
  magnitudes higher than workloads secured by the SGX userspace enclaves.

## Solution overview

- IncogniTOS is a unikernel for full-system obfuscation.
- To enforce the adaptive memory obfuscation approach practically for CVM, it
  retrofits two key OS components: Scheduler and page management

### Goals

#### Goal1: Full-system obfuscation(Challenge3)

#### Goal2: Practicality through binary-only (Limitation4)

- We use binary-comatible techniques to achieve this goal.

#### Goal3: Limiting obfuscation overheads through adaptive obfuscation while retaining robustness during attacks (Challenges1,2)

### Unikernel approach

#### OS-level defense (Goal2)

#### Unikernel (Goal1)

- Unkernel small memory footprint and single-address-space
- Direct hardware access renders MMU access efficient (used in our page
  management scheme)
- Lack of address space switching is also crucial for low-overhead synchronous
  scheduling

### Scheduling

#### Novelty1: Replace scheduling driven by interrupts from untrusted hypervisor with synchronous tick delivery through binary instrumentation (Goal2,3).

-

#### Novelty2: Sliding window-rate and adaptive scaling policy enable low overheads during normal execution while quickly reacting to (Goal3)

### Page management

#### Novelty3: Our solution to enable practical full-system (Goal1) and binary-compatible (Goal2) memory randomization lies in the OS's ability to control memory address translation.

- MMU access: Keep GVA the same, while only relocating GPA (Goal2)

- Combination of ORAM and randomized active region is the most scalable option
  (Limitation3)

  - ORAM allows supprt of large amount of memory.
  - Active region keeps the rerandomization operations to limited locations

- Since ORAM obliviously brings pages into active regions, rerandomzation is
  simply performed thorough active regions flushing,

#### Novelty4: A requirement for full-system obfuscation (Goal1) is that the page table are also reerandomized

notes.title: PARA method
notes.body:
#organization

The PARA method provide a framework to organize your information so that they
can be retrieved with less friction.

The core of PARA is to split your information into categories based how
_actionable_ they are.

```text
    Actionability    
       
  Project    Areas    Resources    Archives 
       
```

- _Projects_ are usually a specific task with a deadline, e.g., writing a
  thesis.
- _Areas_ are long terms responsibilities that you wish to maintain, e.g., be a
  better human.
- _Resources_. This is not very clearly defined by the PARA system. Most
  resources say they are topics of interests that you wish to keep for future
  use.
  - Interpretation: anything else that are not projects and areas.
- _Archives_ is literally the trash can.

## Relation to note-taking

- Your notes should be always maintained, so they should be within the "Area"
  category.
- Tagging notes with #project is useful in quickly finding you projects.
- I put #resources on content not produced by me, or collection of useful links.

notes.title: Packet Isolation
notes.lead:
NetBrick [@panda2016netbricks] discussed the property _packet isolation_ in the
context of network functions (NF) [[szlwwqsj]]. Ideally you would want to only
pass the pointer to the packet between the NFs to avoid copying. However, this
lead to a NF can modify the NF after it has been sent.
notes.body:
NetBrick [@panda2016netbricks] discussed the property _packet isolation_ in the
context of network functions (NF) [[szlwwqsj]]. Ideally you would want to only
pass the pointer to the packet between the NFs to avoid copying. However, this
lead to a NF can modify the NF after it has been sent.

In NetBrick, the property is enforced through Rust ownership model [[4ea8wn6r]],
where after the packet's is sent by the NF, Rust prevents further modifications
to it. RedLeaf [@narayanan2020redleaf] enforces similar property for zero-copy
data transfer.

notes.rawContent:
# Packet Isolation

NetBrick [@panda2016netbricks] discussed the property _packet isolation_ in the
context of network functions (NF) [[szlwwqsj]]. Ideally you would want to only
pass the pointer to the packet between the NFs to avoid copying. However, this
lead to a NF can modify the NF after it has been sent.

In NetBrick, the property is enforced through Rust ownership model [[4ea8wn6r]],
where after the packet's is sent by the NF, Rust prevents further modifications
to it. RedLeaf [@narayanan2020redleaf] enforces similar property for zero-copy
data transfer.

# Comparision critera

## Code & data

Some work provides protection to only data accesses, while other protect both
code and data accesses.

## Granularity

Perfect trace, Cache-line, Page-level.

# Obfuscated execution techniques

The first line of defense is obfuscated execution ([[n9bxzpge]]), which
guarantees that code and data accesses of a program looks the same, given a
sensitive input. They usually have high overheads and are considered
impractical.

# Detecting page faults

One class of defense is to treat all possible page fault triggered by the OS as
malicious. This requires that the enclave pages are statically determined and
mapped to enclave. Hence, demand paging is not possible in this model.

Most of these defenses uses Intel TSX [[dx7vz8d5]], due to its ability to
supress page faults. For more details, see [[fvom56lw]].

Since their introduction, there has been attacks that can leak secrets _without_
explicitly triggering page faults #cite-needed. Hence, these defenses are
incomplete to today's standard.

# Virtualizing Virtual Memory

Another category of defense is to replace all memory instructions of the enclave
(through compiler instrumentation) with requests to a reference monitor that
make the actual request indistinguishable to attackers (e.g., using ORAM
primitives). They have stronger guarantees than

For instance, the following LLVM IR could be instruments as follows:

```llvm
%0 = alloca 100
%1 = load ptr %arg1
%2 = add %1, 100
call foo()
store %2, ptr %0

---
%1 = call oblivious_load(%arg1)
%2 = add %1, 100
call obliviou_call(&foo)
call oblivious_store(%2, %1)
```

## Obfuscuro

## Klotski

## CosMIX

## Self-paging enclaves

Another way to hide page faults from the OS is to the enclave perform its own
paging. Though, in SGX, this model is not possible without hardware extensions
[@orenbach2020autarky], [@aga2019invisipage].

These defenses maintain a separated page table that is exclusively used to map
EPC pages. This page table can only be updated by the trusted code inside the
enclave.

notes.title: Paging in Unikraft (x86)
notes.body:
#unikraft #os

## Enabling paging

Paging is enabled with the configuration PAGING, enabled by setting Platform
Configuration  Platform Interface Option  Virtual memory API in
`make menuconfig`.

`PAGING` option affects `plat/kvm/x86/setup.c`, where `mem_init()` would call
`init_paging()`. Then, `ukplat_pt_init` is called to initialize the page table.

It calls `pgarch_init()` to initialize architectural-dependent info, such as
checking 1 GiB pages support, PAT support.

## Initializing paging

### `kernel_pt`

This global struct stores info for the initialization time kernel page table.

Later, a virtual address space (WAS) is created, which also points to this page
table.

### `ukplat_bootinfo`

At build time, the linker prepares a `boot_info` structure. Boot info contains a
list of _physical_ memory regions (kernel image, uninitialized memory, ...).

### `mem_init`

The function inserts the remaining memory from after the kernel image (after
`__END`) to the remaining physical memory to the list of memory regions. This
region flag is `UKPLAT_MEMRF_UNMAP`, which means that these pages are unmapped
from the kernel page table, and are only mapped on-demand.

```c
rc = ukplat_memregion_list_insert(&bi->mrds,
  &(struct ukplat_memregion_desc){
.vbase = PAGE_ALIGN_UP(__END), .pbase = 0,
    .len = PLATFORM_MAX_MEM_ADDR - PAGE_ALIGN_UP(__END), .type = 0,
    .flags = UKPLAT_MEMRF_UNMAP,
```

It then calls `paging_init`

### `paging_init`

The function initializes the kernel's page table. On Linux, there is also the
same function, but the process is a bit different ([[cn9u3d79]]).

First, it calls `ukplat_pt_init`, which initializes the page table facilities,
using a free memory region.

1. `pgarch_init()` setup the CPU features
2. `pgarch_pt_init` initialize the frame allocator and adds all physical memory
   to it.

After the page table

For every region with the flag `UKPLAT_MEMRF_UNMAP`, it unmaps them from the
page table. Finally, it maps regions with the flag `UKPLAT_MEMRF_MAP` to memory.

## `pgarch_pt_init`

Architectual-specific page table initialization is performed here. On X86, it
reserves space for the frame allocator (`struct uk_falloc`), initializes the
allocator, then adds the remaining physical memory to the frame allocator pool
of memory.

## Page fault handler

The page fault handler is defined separatedly as `do_page_fault` in
`common/x86/traps.c`. It calls
`rc = uk_raise_event(UKARCH_TRAP_PAGE_FAULT, &ctx);` (more details is in
event.h).

The handler for this event is found in `ukvmem/arch/x86_64/pagefault.c`,
registered as

```c
UK_EVENT_HANDLER_PRIO(UKARCH_TRAP_PAGE_FAULT, vmem_arch_pagefault,
                      CONFIG_LIBUKVMEM_PAGEFAULT_HANDLER_PRIO);
```

See [[1k9i1cr3]] for more about Unikraft's interrupt handling.

With `ukvmem`, different page fault handlers can be registered for different
VMAs. On a page fault. The VMA for the faulting address is looked up, then the
VMA's registered page fault handler is called.

## `ukvmem`

ukvmem enables APIs for virtual memory management. It creates Virtual Address
Spaces (VAS), which contains smaller regions called Virtual Memory Areas (VMAs).

There are APIs that are required for paging that are defined here. For example,
the page fault handler above `vmem_arch_pagefault` would call `vmem_pagefault`
defined in `vmem.c`.

`pg_page_mapx` (`paging.c`) performs the allocating of page table entries.

## Page table entry

`pg_page_mapx` sets the "template" as 0, which is set in the new PTE on a fault.

## Related notes

- [[cn9u3d79]]

notes.title: Paging new outline
notes.body:
# Memory randomization strategy

- Its distinct management strategy does not change the actual GVA of the
  program, but to reshuffle GPA and the page table mappings.
- Constraint memory access to to GPA region active region that is continuously
  rerandomized.
- Goal is to completely after a rerandomization, GPA memory layout is
  statistically independent from the new layout.
- ORAM enable pages brought into the active region to reveal no information.

- Thus, with just a simple full eviction, the new pages brought in becomes
  randomized.

notes.title: Paraverification
notes.body:
#virtualization

Paraverfication is discussed by the InkTag [@inktag] system. The goals is to
_ensure correct OS behavior_ with the least efforts. The approach is to let the
OS do the work, then verify them later.

The OS must also participate in the verification. Here it sends the intent to
hypervisor before doing the work.

Indeed thanks to paraverification, additional the hypervisor are able to enforce
additional security properties, for example:

- Additional access control on file systems
- Consistency

notes.title: Peephole trampoline optimization
notes.lead:
`e9patch` includes a "peephole" optimization for trampoline. It not only build
the trampoline with the target instruction, but also the surrounding
instructions up until the whole of the basic block from the entry until the next
control flow transfer is encountered. The instructions before the
instrumentation point are included in the prologue, and the instructions after
are included in the epilogue.
notes.body:
`e9patch` includes a "peephole" optimization for trampoline. It not only build
the trampoline with the target instruction, but also the surrounding
instructions up until the whole of the basic block from the entry until the next
control flow transfer is encountered. The instructions before the
instrumentation point are included in the prologue, and the instructions after
are included in the epilogue.

```asm
        other trampolines can jump directly here      
                                                         Trampoline prologue                           
                                     add   $0x70,%rsp                          
		    add    $0x70,%rsp                  ... (trampoline init)                     
Instrumented  mov    %rbx,%rdi           mov    %rbx,%rdi // hoisted inst              
target   	    pop    %rbx                              Trampoline epilogue:                          
	            jmp    20d0 <syscall+0x10d0>                 ... (trampoline deinit)                   
          	                     pop    %rbx                               
                                                                   jmp    {new offset} // jmp back is skipped
                                                               



```

This has two benefits.

1. Other trampolines may directly jump to the new prologue without return to the
   main code.
2. With the epilogue, we cut one extra jump instruction used to transfer control
   back to the main code.

notes.title: Polymorphism in C
Porting C programs with macros
notes.body:
#c #programming

Many times I have to port an existing C/C++ program from one platform/system. I
found C macros to be useful in such cases: you can replace APIs from one
platform to another, and also making change to the program behavior without
touching the code being ported (or just small modifications to the programs).

For example, you want to port the following function from Linux into Unikraft.
First, you need to bring along the definitions from Linux: `kprobe`, `pt_regs`,
`kprobe_ctlblk` and also all the called functions. Moving struct definition is
simple enough, just copying the files over.

```c
static int reenter_kprobe(struct kprobe *p, struct pt_regs *regs,
                          struct kprobe_ctlblk *kcb) {
  switch (kcb->kprobe_status) {
  case KPROBE_HIT_SSDONE:
  case KPROBE_HIT_ACTIVE:
  case KPROBE_HIT_SS:
    kprobes_inc_nmissed_count(p);
    setup_singlestep(p, regs, kcb, 1);
    break;
  case KPROBE_REENTER:
    pr_err("Unrecoverable kprobe detected.\n");
    dump_kprobe(p);
    BUG();
  default:
    /* impossible cases */
    WARN_ON(1);
    return 0;
  }
  return 1;
}
```

As there is no `pr_err`, `WARN_ON`, `BUG()` in Unikraft, one may (1) copy them
over, or (2) replacing the use with Unikraft-provided ones, e.g., `pr_err`
`uk_pr_err`. (2) is more desirable as it reduce the amount of ported code.

Now, while you can change the source code to achieve (2), a better way is to
just override certain function calls with macros.

```c
#define pr_err uk_pr_err
```

Also, it is useful to redefine integer types:

```c
#define u64 __u64
#define u32 __u32
#define u16 __u16
#define u8 __u8
```

You may also choose to completely ignore certain function / macro to avoid
porting. For example, `__ro_after_init` is a feature in Linux:

```c
extern __ro_after_init unsigned long poking_addr;
```

To ignore them:

```c
#define WARN_ON(x)
#define __force // Ignoring certain macro used in kernel
```

notes.title: Position map is a page table
notes.body:
#area #oram

The position map ($PosMap$) of ORAM and the page table are very similar conceptually. They are both structures that *map* the location of a *logical address* into a *real address*.
- The $PosMap$ maps an ORAM address $a$ to its corresponding leaf $l$  on the ORAM tree. To access $a$, the ORAM controller read the entire path root to leaf $l$ (for PathORAM) into the stash, and update $PosMap[a]$ to a random leaf.
- The page table maps an address $a$ to a physical frame $p$. To access $a$, the MMU has to translate $a$ into a real physical address $p$, before sending the request to DRAM for data.

*Hierarchy* is used in both cases to tackle the memory storage issue.
- PosMap: The $PosMap$ itself is stored in another ORAM ($ORAM_{PosMap}$), where each block contains the translation for $X$ contiguous addresses. $ORAM_{PosMap}$ now only requires its $PosMap$ to map $N/X$ addresses. This can repeat multiple times (i.e., recursion happens). See [[wex0mob4]].
	- $leaf_{PosMap_{i-1}} \gets ORAM_{PosMap_i}.access(leaf_{PosMap_i})$.
- Page Table: A higher level $PT$ is created that maps the $X$ $PT$s for the lower level. To translate an address $a_{virtual}$, $PT_i$ is looked up using $a_{virtual}$ as the index (only bits in $a_{virtual}$ to be exact) which yields the address of $PT_{i-1}$.
	- $a_{PT_{i-1}} \gets PT_i[a_{virtual}]$

PT does not map every address. Does recursive PosMap need to map every block?
- ORAM PosMap can also contain dummy blocks. So, if $a$ is not used by the ORAM, $ORAM_{data}[a]$ would contain a dummy block.

# Literature
The observation is first found in FreecursiveORAM @fletcher2015freecursive, where they found that similar to the TLB, a similar structure could be implemented to cache the $PosMap$ translation to speed up ORAM accesses.

Later works also make use of this similarity the other way around.
- InvisiPage [@aga2019invisipage] encodes the value of the $PosMap$ inside the page table, when the PTE does not contain the physical address mapping. This saves space to store the $PosMap$, and since the PT is already consulted at each translation, the leaf value for an address $a$ is obtained without extra costs.
- Klotski @zhang2020klotski implements a *virtual MMU* using a similar idea. The flat, virtual PT either contains a valid address within the cache (working memory) or encoding for ORAM access.

The observation is first found in FreecursiveORAM @fletcher2015freecursive, where they found that similar to the TLB, a similar structure could be implemented to cache the $PosMap$ translation to speed up ORAM accesses.

Later works also make use of this similarity the other way around.
- InvisiPage [@aga2019invisipage] encodes the value of the $PosMap$ inside the page table, when the PTE does not contain the physical address mapping. This saves space to store the $PosMap$, and since the PT is already consulted at each translation, the leaf value for an address $a$ is obtained without extra costs.
- Klotski @zhang2020klotski implements a *virtual MMU* using a similar idea. The flat, virtual PT either contains a valid address within the cache (working memory) or encoding for ORAM access.

notes.title: Practical Program Modularization with Type-Based Dependence Analysis
notes.body:
#literature #analysis #compartmentalization

[@lu2023practical]

## Main arguments

Data-flow-based dependence analyses are impractical on large programs due to
incorrect results and scalability issues, and A type-based dependence analysis
avoid data-flow analysis.

- See [[dgdvhu1e]]
- The proposed approach can handle multi-entry, multi-threaded programs, and
  does not rely on points-to analysis.

Module-aware type-based dependence analysis enables practical dependence
analysis.

- If only the module boundaries are analyzed (function arguments and global
  variables), the inner complexity of module is does not matter.
- The proposed analysis only analyses the two types of typed-based data-flow,
  through function arguments and through global variable.

Module-based analysis and type-based analysis are complementary.

- Module-aware analysis complement type-analysis:
  - Previous type-only approaches @lu2019where are imprecise because they
       scan the entire program for a particular type.
  - There are modules in programs that has contain same types, but not
       related at all
  - The approach can further refine the CFI targets by using dependent module
       information
- Type-aware analysis improves module-aware analysis:
  - A module-only analysis would be highly imprecise (only identifying if
       module A can write into B), using the Type of argument further restrict
       the data flow, making it an effective approach.

The proposed analysis is effective and sound (as a dependence analysis)

- It is effective (in restricting data-flow) because it is difficult to form the
  data flow between modules with a given type, and that there are also modules
  between a module.
- It is sound (as a dependence analysis), since the approach will catch all
  cross-module data-flow if there is one.

The analysis improve upon existing security applications.

- When used for indirect call target reduction, it have high reduction rate on
  large application (up to 70% on firefox).
- It identify 90% write instructions in linux as non-sensitive, which can be
  enforced with techniques such as DFI, WIT. (No enforcement were tested).

# Observation

There is only two type of data-flow between modules: through function
arguments/return values and through global variables

# Type-based dependence analysis

The key idea is to perform type-based dependence analysis between modules (i.e.,
compilation unit). A _type-based dependence analysis_ determine if modules of
the programs may propagate the object of a certain types to a particular module.

The following types of dependencies are detected:

Direct (through argument):

- If M1 pass argument of type T1 to M2, there is direct data flow M1->M2.

Indirect (through global)

- If M1 write to global g type T, M2 read global type T, then there is data flow
  M1->g->M2.

Transitive:

- There can be chaining of cross-module data flow, e.g., M1->M2->g->M3->M4

# The analysis

The analysis takes a pair of type and module <type,module>, and automatically
all dependent modules. There are three main steps.

- The first step collect castable types into a CastMap. This is to handle unsafe
  casting operations in C/C++, all possible casted types are also considered in
  the data flow.
- The second step find out the direction and type of the data flow between two
  particular modules and store it into a `FlowMap`. Finding out the direction
  possible data flow ([[#direction]]).
- The final step compute dependent modules and the dependent types.

It is also observe that type-based indirect calls can be further refined using
module-awareness. The author use an iterative method to refine the indirect call
targets:

- In first iteration, find dependent modules of an indirect call
- Next, limit the type-based call target matching to only using the dependent
  modules.
- Repeat until no more refinement is made

## Finding data flow direction

[]{#direction}

For two modules $M$, $V$, and a use $U$ of type $T$:

- If the use in $V$ is a _load_ LLVM instruction, then the direction is $M->V$.
- If it is a $store$ instruction, then the direction is $V->M$.
- If it is the GEP instruction, also analyze the use of the instruction
- Else, it is bidirectional.

On struct types and pointer types, the types of the field is also analyzed. This
is done through recursion on GEP instructions.

The result is stored in a structure called the $FlowMap$ that record Type,
Direction of data flow between two modules.

## Type elevation

_Type elevation_ is also proposed to improve the precision. The idea is that
instead of using the type of the use site, which might have many false
possitive, _elevate_ it to the type of the containing struct. For example, when
an indirect call type $T1$ in a struct $T2$ is called, we first find the set of
dependent modules using the type $T1$. Then, we find the dependent modules using
the struct type $T2$. Finally, we _intersect_ the two set to have a more refined
dependent module set for the type $T1$.

This approach is unsound for container types (_base type_) that can be created
from within the module, because cross-module data-flow will not find dependent
module for those types. The paper suggests a simple _externality analysis_: If
the base type is ever assigned (through `store` and initilizers), it cannot be
used for elevation.

Essentially, it is just following chain of GEP instructions to get the outermost
type as the _base type_ (section 5)

# Implementation notes

## Type comparison

The authors found that type comparison in LLVM poses challenges:

- Type may have different underlying memory objects so pointer comparison does
  not work
- The same struct type might have different variants, so string comparison may
  not work.
- Struct types may or may not have name.

## Unions

Union types is handled by using the union type itself, instead of the
instantiated type. This hurts precision but guarantee soundness.

notes.title: Preventing Kernel Hacks with HAKC
notes.body:
#literature #compartmentalization #os #pointer-authentication #mte

# Summary

The paper introduces a framework for complementing software called
Hardware-assisted Kernel Compartmentalization (HAKC). The goal is to divide code
and data into partitions and enforce access control on data access and control
flow between partitions. The hardware primitives assumed are PA and MTE.

The paper claims two main contributions, _Compartmentalization Policy_ and
_Enforcement_ strategy.

Regarding the Policy, a two-level partitioning scheme is proposed. At a high
level, there are Cliques and Compartments. One compartment contains several
Cliques (at most 15 -- MTE number of tags). Two types of policies must be
defined by the programmer: Clique Access Policy (CAP) and Compartment Transition
Policy (CTP).

CAP is defined per-Cliques. It define data and code from other Cliques, a clique
can access. The system enforce that a Clique's code and data accesses always
access memory (1) belong to its own compartment and (2) within its permissions.

CTP allows a clique to transfer its control flow outside of the compartment. It
specify which other compartment's clique, a clique is able to call. When a
clique transfer its control outside, data in the argument need to also be
recolored to the target.

The authors argue that such a two-level design enable several advantages:

- First, it overcome the limited number of MTE tags, since all control/data flow
  outside of the compartment must be explicitly validated.
- Second, it enable local data optimization. More particular, within a clique,
  the access control is more light-weight, while other heavy-weight checks and
  data copies are left to the cross-comartment transitions.
- Third, it allows fine-grained security boundaries, for performance-security
  trade-off.

## Enforcement

Using MTE, all pointer will be encoded with a tag (a.k.a., cojoined metadata
(CM)), indicating which clique owns the underlying memory. HAKC's strategy is to
check all pointer dereference, to enforce that the pointer access is in
accordance with the specified policies (the memory belong to the current
compartment, and the current clique has the permission to access this data).

At runtime, a _candidate_ CM is computed to be compared with a pointer's CM. The
candiate CM is basically what the CM should looks like, given the current
clique/compartment permissions.

PAC is used to ensure that p>nter is not tamperedwith.

More particularly, in PA and MTE terms, every pointers is tagged with the
clique's color. The pointer is then signed with a _signing token_ as the
modifier (which is the color of the owning clique _XOR_ the compartment ID).
I.e., $Tok_{sign} = CompartmantmentID XOR (Pointer's tag)$. Later, when the
pointer is used, an _authentication token_ is reconstructed the pointer's tag
and the permission bitmask $Tok_{acl}$. Or,
$Tok_{aut} = CompartmantmentID XOR (Pointer's tag AND Tok_{acl})$.

For instance, if a pointer's tag is 3, its bitmask is $100$. A $Tok_{acl}$ of
$111$ means that a clique is able to access cliques of color 1, 2 and 3.
Assuming compartment ID is 2. Then, $Tok_{sign} = $5 XOR 100$ At the use site,
$Tok_{aut} = $5 XOR (100 AND 111)$

Why is MTE/PAC is even needed?

notes.body:
#problem-solving

The concept of problem-solving by debugging the almost-right plan is used in the
field of artificial intelligence to model "skill learning" to solve complex
problems. It is first discussed in the thesis of Gerald Sussman
[@sussman1973computational] where an AI system called HACKER is proposed that
automatically improves its performance with practice, kind of similar to how
modern reinforcement learning works.

notes.title: Programmer Annotation is New Language Syntax
notes.body:
#programming #c #programming-language

Some research work for the C language requires the programmer's annotations
[@gudka2015clean]. Essentially, adding program annotation is no different from
creating new C syntaxes on the flight. With C rich macro system, some common
programming patterns may be defined in C, e.g., [[l56og3zt]].

Some recent paper goes further and claim to invent new language extension, but
in the end are just additional C macros [@khan2023ec].

Inventing new syntax is harder since it requires more considerations and have a
wide impact.

Designing new annotations for C is easy, because they are optional and cam be
enabled through a library.

However, the C syntax is so barebone that almost always you are required to
create some kind of language extensions though macros.

notes.title: Programming paradigms and note taking
notes.body:
#note-taking #programming

## Inheritance and hierarchical notes

Object-oriented programming revolve around inheritance, which inevitably leads
to hierarchies. E.g., `animal -> bird-like animals -> duck `.

Note-taking in this model maintain a note for each topic, where each new idea
becomes a sub-topic within this.

- Operating system
  - Process
  - File systems
  -

Similar to operating systems, where hierarchical layering limits flexibility
[[c4icaua4]], these notes lack flexibility. That is, new ideas are harder to
emerge.

## Composition and atomic notes

Another programming paradigm is to prioritize composition to inheritance. In
this model, reusable components are abstracted into reusable traits, where
complex objects would be composed of traits. E.g.,
`duck =  quackable + simmable `

Similarly, atomic notes follow this idea.

notes.title: Properties of Virtualization
notes.body:
#os #virtualization

Virtualization gives a subject (process, virtual machine) the illusion of having
access to physical resource (memory, CPU time).

Virtualization is characterized through two properties, _interposition_ and
_transparency_

## Interposition

While it is possible for the VMM to perform every operation of the virtualized
system (as seen in legacy emulators), this is not desirable due to the high
overheads. It is more reasonable to let certain performed execute natively (by
the CPU), while "intercepting" dangerous operations that overcome isolation.
This is the core principle in modern virtualization that enable fast and
efficient virtualization.

Interposition (aka, trap-and-emulate) let the reference monitor (OS/Hypervisor)
interject the control upon a certain action of the virtualized subject. For
instance, page faults allows the OS to interpose virtual to physical
translation, and add missing page mapping on-demand.

Interposition give the virtualized system the illusion of hardware access. The
hypervisor can interpose hardware interrupts, page faults, VM enter and exit,
and handle them in software (handling them in the actual hardware would affect
the entire system). This give the illusion to virtual machine have actual access
to those hardware resources. See [[d3nt6uix]].

Interposition is achieved commonly through three means.

- Binary translation interprets every executed instruction and interpose on the
  sensitive instructions (used in QEMU).
- Para-virtualization requires patching the guest OS to delegate a certain
  action to the hypervisor.
- Interposition through hardware events forward the interrupts from the VM to
  the hypervisor.

## Transparency

Transparency is another property that is desired, but not required, is
transparency. In a transparent virtualization, the virtualized subject does not
have knowledge it being virtualized.

This is beneficial in two aspects:

First, there need no special adaptation in the machine being virtualized. This
allows for quick migration of virtualized workloads between different machines.

Second, certain scenarios such as malware analysis, the program may use
anti-virtualization techniques to avoid being reverse-engineered.

notes.title: Pure functions in Rust
notes.body:
#rust #pure-function

Pure functions are a concept from functional programming languages that marks
that a function has no _side effect_. More concretely, in the D programming
language, Pure functions are functions that cannot access global variables, and
cannot make changes to their arguments.

[This issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/issues/1631) discusses the
possibility of adding pure function support in Rust a keyword (e.g.,
`pure fn foo()`). Pure functions were eventually deemed not useful:

- There are rarely any use cases for it, even in the D programming language.
- There is no agreed-upon definition for pure functions.
- Rust tried implementing this concept before but removed it.

# Pure functions in Rust

#rust #pure-function

Pure functions are a concept from functional programming languages that marks
that a function has no _side effect_. More concretely, in the D programming
language, Pure functions are functions that cannot access global variables, and
cannot make changes to their arguments.

[This issue](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/issues/1631) discusses the
possibility of adding pure function support in Rust a keyword (e.g.,
`pure fn foo()`). Pure functions were eventually deemed not useful:

- There are rarely any use cases for it, even in the D programming language.
- There is no agreed-upon definition for pure functions.
- Rust tried implementing this concept before but removed it.
- Rust already has something similar to this concept as `const fn`. Those
  functions can take runtime arguments, but cannot do anything related to
  runtime execution.

notes.title: RLBox Implementation
Rationale of descriptor table (virtio)
notes.body:
#virtualization #io

In virtio, the descriptor table contains information about buffers used for I/O,
is a separated entity from the available and used rings (split virtqueue
scenario). This is different from traditional NIC devices [@turtles], where the
descriptor is inlined within the rings themselves.

The answer from the original paper [@russell2008virtio] is not so "obvious" at
all:

> The separation of the descriptors from the available ring is due to the
> asynchronous nature of the virtqueue: the available ring may circle many times
> with fast-serviced descriptors while slow descriptors might still await
> completion. This is obviously useful for implementing block devices, but also
> turns out to be useful for zero-copy networking.

The above explanation contains two parts: (1) asynchronism is useful for
implementing block devices, and (2) useful for zero-copy networking.

## Asynchronous I/O for block devices

For block devices like hard drives, different I/O operations might have
different time to complete. For example, reading from a cached file is fast,
while reading from the disk would take much longer time.

Separating descriptor table (chaining of buffers) and the virtqueue (descriptor
chains to be processed) allow entries in the virtqueue to be asynchronously.

- Fast descriptors may be serviced immediately and move on the next, i.e.,
  circling the virtqueue
- Slow descriptors that require waiting, would not block other fast descriptors
- A descriptor may be immediately reused after their processing is done

Without descriptor table, slow descriptor would block the processing:

```txt
Available Ring:
[Desc1 -> Desc2 -> Desc3 -> Desc4]
```

Now with a separated descriptor table, requests are serviced asynchronously:

```txt
Available Ring: [Operation1, Operation2, Operation3, Operation4]
                                                   
Descriptors:    [Desc1]     [Desc2]     [Desc3]     [Desc4]
```

This is contrast to traditional NIC devices that inline the descriptor to the
data rings [@turtles], so packets are to be processed one-by-one by increasing
the ring buffer pointer.

## Zero-copy networking

The reason it may be useful for zero-copy networking _seems to be_ that when the
rings are filled up, the network buffer must be copied to another place.

notes.title: Reading in passes
notes.body:
#reading #learning #zettelkasten

An article/paper/book should be read in multiple passes. The point is to
maximize the time efficiency when reading. This is similar to how compiler
passes works.

## The three passes

Taken from [@keshav2007how]

### First pass

It is also important to remember the [[b740rhio]], so spend more time on the
beginning and the end of the section.

Checklist:

- [ ] What are the related papers
- [ ] Main contributions of this paper

### Second pass

Checklist:

- [ ] Summarize main technical details of the paper
- [ ] Understand the ideas
- [ ] Give evidences for the claims

### Synthesis

Checklist:

- [ ] With the same assumptions of the authors, recreate the work
- [ ] Reconstruct the structure of the paper from memory.
- [ ] Identify strong and weak points.
- [ ] Identify implicit assumptions.

notes.title: Real-time TEE
notes.body:
#realtime #tee

Availability is usually not the concern for current TEEs, whose focuses is on
confidentiality and integrity. However, in certain safety-critical system such
as drones, availability is also important.

Challenges in bringing availability into TEEs is to minimize the TCB-sizes.
Real-time OSes require complex scheduler designs that maintain real-time
constraints. Another issue is maintaining availability of I/O while there is
untrusted OS.

RT-TEE [@wang2022rttee] introduces a real-time-aware TEE on ARM trustzone that
aims to to minimize TCB.

notes.title: Recursion in ORAM
notes.body:
#area #oram

## Recursion

In ORAM, the recursion technique helps reduce the client storage for the
position map by storing them inside smaller ORAMs in hierarchical order. The
higher-level ORAM needs to store less data than the lower-level ones to fit the
highest-level ORAM into the client storage. ORAM at level $i$ would contain the
position map data for ORAM at level $i-1$, and ORAM at level 0 is the actual
data ORAM.

Let's say 1 level of recursion is used. The $PosMap$ itself is stored in another
ORAM ($ORAM_{PosMap}$), where each block contains the translation for $X$
contiguous addresses. $ORAM_{PosMap}$ now only requires its $PosMap$
($PosMap_{PosMap}$) to map $N/X$ addresses. Data is still stored in the original
ORAM ($ORAM_{Data}$).

To request the leaf of a block address $a_0$, the ORAM controller must look up
$PosMap_{PosMap}$ that is stored in the client. To put simply:
$leaf_{PosMap} \gets PosMap_{PosMap}[a_0]$
$block_{PosMap} \gets ORAM_{PosMap}.access(leaf_{PosMap})$
$leaf_{Data} \gets block_{PosMap}[a_0]$
$block_{ORAM} \gets ORAM_{Data}.access(leaf_{Data})$

## Ambiguity

Papers that mention recursion in Path ORAM often describe it very ambiguously
(e.g., described by previous works). They make it seems like only one pass of
access through the hierarchy is needed. E.g., you only need to get the leaf of
the current address through recursion. For example,
<https://people.csail.mit.edu/devadas/pubs/PathORam.pdf> says that you just have
to replace lines 1-2 with ORAM $access$. @fletcher2015freecursive mentioned
nothing of how to get the leafs of stash blocks.

However, actually, recursion must be performed on _all_ position map accesses
for any addresses. In ORAM, there are actually two places where position map is
accessed, at the start of the access to remap the current block (line 1-2), and
on eviction, when choosing for blocks to evict (line 11).

It is easier to see the "recursion" happening, by imagining position map as a
class that expose a `get` function
([see this](https://github.com/epsolute/path-oram/blob/master/path-oram/src/position-map-adapter.cpp)),
where all access must be done through this accessor. When recursion is active,
the map function is implemented as an ORAM access:

```cpp
int ORAM::access(int id){
 int leaf = this.PosMap.get(id);
}

int PosMap.get(int id){
 this.ORAM.access(int id); /* Goes on to call this.posmap.get */
}
```

With this in mind, it is easier to imagine the "recursion" happening,
`PosMap.get` calls `ORAM.access`, which would calls `PosMap.get` and so on.

_NOTE_: Another method to avoid performing an ORAM access on line 11 is to store
the path information _along_ with the data block. This way, where the block is
actually mapped to is known when it is fetched with the block. Maybe recursive
ORAM papers _assume_ this, so they don't consider eviction as a PosMap access.

notes.body:
#elf #linux

## LD_LIBRARY_PATH

To execute an ELF with custom-built libraries, you may overwrites environent
variables that will be used by the dynamic loader.

`LD_LIBRARY_PATH` will append your custom path in the search path when executing
the ELF file.

```bash
ls /your/libpath
a.so  b.so  c.so

LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/your/libpath ./youreflf
```

## LD_PRELOAD trick

`LD_PRELOAD` works similarly, but it forces certain dynamic libraries to be
loaded first. While it is intended "preloading", not for for overwriting
libraries, it achieves the intended results.

```bash
LD_PRELOAD=/path/to/mymalloc.so ./yourelf
```

## Dynamic loader

To run with custom dynamic loader is not as simple. You may directly invoke the

To execute an ELF with custom-built libraries, you may overwrites environent
variables that will be used by the dynamic loader.

a.so  b.so  c.so

notes.title: Safe and Fast Confidential IO Stack
notes.body:
#project

## Related work

### Fined-grained kernel comparmentalization

Multiple systems have been in proposed for fine-grained compartmentalization in
the kernel.

- LXD, LVD used virtualization to isolate driver code. They also deal with
  automatic data marshalling through IDL design. ksplit automate the process of
  IDL generation.
- More recent work, HAKC, BULKHEAD utilize fast isolation primities like PKU and
  ARM PAC/MTE to add lightweight compartments into the kernel.

Most focuses on the isolation of kernel modules from the core kernel. Virtio
driver is minimal (in LoC), so there is less incentive to isolate the driver.
Our focus of should be shifted to the transport layer.

Interface design is not the focus of these works, but the retrofitting of
isolation into existing kernel interfaces. While some do raise the interface
concerns, the validation logic is left to developers.

### Security and performance of CVM I/O

- [gramine-tdx] proposes extreme attack surface minimization by offloading much
  of the networking/fs stack into to the untrusted hypervisor and relying on
  payload-level encryption for confidentiality. For hardening the interfaces,
  - Limits the interfaces with the untrusted hypervisor (no. of virtqueues).
  - Still relies on manual sanitizations
  - Proposed some check for protocol adherence, a kind of interface ordering
    check.
- [bifrost] optimizes the I/O path of confidential I/O to reduce redundant
  copies and packet processing times. For security, it suggests a "one-time
  trusted read" hardening that only read the packet metadata once when receiving
  packets. Since payload is already encrypted by TLS, it is
  authenticity-protected.
- [bridge] optimize the I/O path for SR-IOV devices with in-CVM DPDK. It also
  had some security considerations, e.g., always copy packets into private
  memory before processing.
  - DPDK-specific
  - Assume SR-IOV

### Previous networking stacks for trusted execution

- SafeBrick, rktio, LightBox, ...
- We expect they will suffers from intervface vulnerabilities too.

## Motivations

### Existing efforts: Attack surface minimization

- Offloading most of the stack into the host ([gramine-tdx]) exposes
  fine-grained observability into in-CVM operations.
  - This leaks system call timing, ...
  - > Makes resource accounting tricky
- A patchset by Intel instead minimize TCB by limiting the features
  [virtio-hardening], e.g., only allowing split virtqueues.
  - Also, trying to limit the feature set leads to performance degradation (not
    quantified).

> - Related:
>   - Network stack as a service

> [!IMPORTANT]
>
> Our approach is to keep much of the stack within the CVM boundary, but instead
> establish multiple security domains with safety-first interfaces. This limit
> observability, while maintaining performance.

### Existing efforts: ad hoc hardening

- Hardening is error-prone
  - e.g., notification hardening is introduced in a patch, made an optional
    feature in another, and finally marked as broken.

> In the VirtIO case for example, over 40 commits, 12 either revert or amend
> previous hardening changes, some of them never to be re-applied.
> [confidential-io]

> [!IMPORTANT]
>
> We propose that the interface itself should be redesigned for future
> confidential computing workloads. We explore principles that enable secure
> interface design, and propose primitives that make hardening easier.

## Virtio for confidential computing: the good, the bad and the ugly

What do we want to keep/remove in the virtio interface?

### The good

#### Universality and generality

- This not only reduce the driver development efforts, but also reduce the TCB
  (remove the need for all kinds of drivers in the trusted guest).
- We want to retain this to support a wide range of deployment scenarios
- We also want existing driver to be easily ported to our new interfaces

#### Performance-oriented

- The design is optimized for high speed I/O.
- The new design should not significantly reduce I/O performance.

#### Descriptor table

- The descriptors are a kind of safety-aware resource handle that reduces
  programming mistakes. Its wrap-around index, combined with power-of-two
  virtqueue sizes, by design prevent out-of-bound accesses.
  - It's not fool-proof. The host can pass out-of-bound indexes in the rings.
- We want to keep this aspect

### The bad

#### Not built with mutual distrust in mind

- A large amount of control data / metadata is expected to be in shared memory,
  which open up attack vectors for double fetches.

#### Large configuration space

- Need to quantify how large is this space.

#### DMA quirk

- Due to the distinction between shared and private memory, allowing the device
  to access random memory does not make sense anymore, and also make virtio
  fundamentally difficult to harden.
- Bounce buffers is required for I/O in confidential VMs, making DMA less of a
  requirement.
- Instead of expecting unrestricted DMA accesses in the specification, a better
  design is to have reserved fixed size regions for data exchanges.
  - This also avoid overheads associated with I/O memory management

### The ugly

#### The large scope of the standard

- Need to support legacy devices and drivers, resulting in hardening breaks
  existing drivers and devices
- Need to support both hardware and para-virtual scenarios.

> Backward compatibility not that important, as drivers are relatively
> transparent to customer anyway

## Design space

### Interface re-architecting

These are just a draft of what I want in the interface.

- **Consistent a cross the stack** We want the validation/enforcement scheme, if
  existed, to be consistent across the networking stack.
  - For example, virtio core may perform some checks, while the driver may
    perform other checks
  - Interesting discussion:
    <https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/CACGkMEsW1+BFtMoLg4c_FyxYTZJcSVh4BoEdJ-Q9_WGg_DcReA@mail.gmail.com/>
  - > > Michael S. Tsirkin: I don't really understand. We already iterate when
    > > we unmap - all that is necessary is to subtract it from used length, if
    > > at the end of the process it is >0 then we know used length is too
    > > large.
    >
    > Jason Wang: Yes, but it is the job that is done in the driver level not
    > the virtio core. Validation in virtio core is still necessary since
    > they're working at different levels and it's hard to force the validation
    > in all drivers by codes. Last version introduces a
    >
    > > Why do we? If driver validates length virtio_ring does not need to
    > > validate. If driver does not use length virtio_ring does not need to
    > > validate. core can provide this service for the gazillion non
    > > performance critical drivers that just want to keep things simple, but
    > > the 4-5 critical ones can do their own validation if they want to.
    >
    > To be more safe, there's no guarantee that there's no bug in the driver.
- **Zero (re)negotiation**. Most negotiation should be performed at device
  startup.
  - This limit the control data exchanges into one place that is easy to harden.
- **Zero surprises**. All control data must be checked against valid value
  ranges according to the specification. This applies to both L2 and L5.
- **Avoid the need to decide whether to copy or not**.
  - Letting the developers making this decision is both error-prone and may
    introduce inefficiencies.
  - Ideally the decision should be made clear by the specification, and enforced
    automatically (continued in next point).
- **Read-once to control data & metadata**. L2) Virtio device configurations,
  control messages, descriptor table L5) packet headers.
  - More generally, we want to avoid double fetch vulnerabilities
  - For L2: A naive approach is copying the control data into the local stack
    before use [virtio-console2]. This may miss cross-function double fetches
    (if exist).
    - A more systematic approach can be achieved with page table permissions
      [midas], e.g., automatically ensuring the page is copied before being
      used,
  - L5: Previous papers suggests read-once the packet headers ([bifrost]), or
    copying the entire packets before use (bridging).
    - This does not apply to runtime metadata exchanges, e.g., `vring[idx].len`,
      `vring[idx].len`.
- **Avoid the need for (manual) pointer validations and bounds checking.**
  Preferably, all the check should be done ASAP, at the interface boundary.
  Pointer validation is extremely error-prone, and very easy to miss.
  - The use of some type of handles (file/virtqueue descriptors) may be useful
    here.
  - Now, existing L2, L5 interfaces are already (kinda) designed this way.
    - For L2, I/O are performed on vring indexes instead of direct pointers.
    - For L5, network IO are performed on socket file descriptors.
  - Even with bound checks, speculative execution
- **Separation of data and metadata**. I/O Data is always encrypted by software
  in confidential computing (TLS, other FS protocols), so it is better to keep
  them in-place to avoid copying ([bifrost]).
  - Because of this, it may be better to keep them separated, so that it is
    easier to enforce certain policy (e.g., zero-copy for data, read-once for
    metadata)
  - This may be difficult to do in the case of network packets due to packet
    encapsulation.

Other bits from HotOS'23 Paper.

- **Stateless interfaces & thread safety**. I don't fully get the implications
  of this. What are the states that can be removed?
- **Revocation**. [bifrost] mentioned that toggling the sharing state between
  Hypervisor and CVM at runtime is not possible due to memory encryption.
  However, it should be possible at the L2 boundary, but is it faster than
  copying?

### Trusted proxies & resource handles

One design is to force all cross-domain communication to go through trusted
proxies that perform data validation, bound checking, etc... ([redleaf]).

- Instead of passing pointers, handles are passed across the interfaces, which
  makes it less likely to make mistake.
- Design choices: Centralized monitor vs. inline monitor

### Capabilities

- The previous design point is what capabilities-based security achieves.
- Capabilities model is a valid consideration for security-first from-scratch
  designs, but can also be retrofitted into unexpected places.
- Challenge: deciding what to abstract into capabilities

### Mutual distrust

- While confidential computing threat models focuses on trusting only the
  protected application, in real world attacks may also come from the protected
  application.
- Ideally our interface design should account for this mutual distrust.

### Low-overhead isolation primitives

- AMD SEV-SNP provides 4 VMPL levels to enforce hierarchical in-CVM isolation of
  memory. A similar feature is also supported in TDX 1.5.
- Note, VMPL switching is costly due to the need of VMExits ([veil]), so
  asynchronous RPC communication should be considered across the domains.
- Exploiting this to build isolation boundaries is a source of novelty.

### Flexible data path

Aside from the traditional networking stack, we should ideally support other
data paths e.g., DPDK, or at least make it not so hard to port them to our
framework.

### Attack surface minimization with performance considerations

- **Minimizing TCB** Instead of minimizing attack surfaces, we should instead
  minimize the TCB that interacts with untrusted input.
  - E.g., [gramine-tdx] minimized the no. of virtqueues to be used that I don't
    think make sense. Each virtqueue is essentially accessed by the same code
    base.
- **No notification / Poll first** Notifications are fundamentally difficult to
  harden due to races, while does not contribute much to performance.
  - Are there cases where they are a must?
- **Performance** Other optimizations, e.g., packed virtqueues, indirection,
  that meaningfully impact performance, should still be compatible with this new
  interface.

### Speculative execution mitigations

- [speculative] mentioned hypervisor-given indexes in the vrings might be used
  for speculative execution.
- Ideally all indexes / pointers should be masked before use.
- May be Related: paper from David [secret-free-hypervisor]

### Fine-grained compartmentalization of the TCP stack

- The TCP stack is organized in layers, but there haven't been discussions to
  split it.

## Sketch design: I/O Monitor

[Src](https://excalidraw.com/#json=GHAbzT6Lub5UbvPPiHY7c,oxBzneS8cORp1zgLn8-jzQ)
![image](https://hackmd.io/_uploads/H1m8hNKNJg.png)

We introduce an entity called "I/O Monitor (IOMon)" that interposes all
communication between guest and host.

- The goal of IOMon is not to deprivilege the main kernel (e.g., NestedKernel),
  but to shepherd safe I/O:
  - Discouraging unsafe interactions (e.g., direct shared memory access).
  - Provide safe abstraction for the stacks to do their job.
  - We want to make hardening IOMon as simple as possible (minimizing TCB,
    automatic checks, safe-by-default primitives).
- Mutual distrust: IOMon has two ends, the in-CVM one that handle CVM-side I/O
  and in-hypervisor one that handle hypervisor-side I/O.
- CVM interfaces:
  - IO memory allocation. Enforce "trusted component allocate"
  - Metadata management. Enforce one-time read & sanitization
  - Feature negotiation and transaction
- Hypervisor interfaces. TBD.
- Capabilities. TBD.
  - Considering using capabilities.
  - Related: LXD, LVD used a microkernel architecture to manage asynchronous
    communication between isolated driver and core kernel.
  - Capabilities makes the verification for some operations simple, and
    minimizing TCB.
  - May be hard to retrofit into existing interfaces.

### Issues

- I expect cutting the networking stack from the kernel is not easy. But do we
  need to at all? An approach may be to run two versions of linux

- Need to support both hardware and para-virtual scenarios.

> Backward compatibility not that important, as drivers are relatively
> transparent to customer anyway

## Design space

### Interface re-architecting

These are just a draft of what I want in the interface.

- **Consistent a cross the stack** We want the validation/enforcement scheme, if
  existed, to be consistent across the networking stack.
  - For example, virtio core may perform some checks, while the driver may
    perform other checks
  - Interesting discussion:
    <https://lore.kernel.org/lkml/CACGkMEsW1+BFtMoLg4c_FyxYTZJcSVh4BoEdJ-Q9_WGg_DcReA@mail.gmail.com/>
  - > > Michael S. Tsirkin: I don't really understand. We already iterate when
    > > we unmap - all that is necessary is to subtract it from used length, if
    > > at the end of the process it is >0 then we know used length is too
    > > large.
    >
    > Jason Wang: Yes, but it is the job that is done in the driver level not
    > the virtio core. Validation in virtio core is still necessary since
    > they're working at different levels and it's hard to force the validation
    > in all drivers by codes. Last version introduces a
    >
    > > Why do we? If driver validates length virtio_ring does not need to
    > > validate. If driver does not use length virtio_ring does not need to
    > > validate. core can provide this service for the gazillion non
    > > performance critical drivers that just want to keep things simple, but
    > > the 4-5 critical ones can do their own validation if they want to.
    >
    > To be more safe, there's no guarantee that there's no bug in the driver.
- **Zero (re)negotiation**. Most negotiation should be performed at device
  startup.
  - This limit the control data exchanges into one place that is easy to harden.
- **Zero surprises**. All control data must be checked against valid value
  ranges according to the specification. This applies to both L2 and L5.
- **Avoid the need to decide whether to copy or not**.
  - Letting the developers making this decision is both error-prone and may
    introduce inefficiencies.
  - Ideally the decision should be made clear by the specification, and enforced
    automatically (continued in next point).
- **Read-once to control data & metadata**. L2) Virtio device configurations,
  control messages, descriptor table L5) packet headers.
  - More generally, we want to avoid double fetch vulnerabilities
  - For L2: A naive approach is copying the control data into the local stack
    before use [virtio-console2]. This may miss cross-function double fetches
    (if exist).
    - A more systematic approach can be achieved with page table permissions
      [midas], e.g., automatically ensuring the page is copied before being
      used,
  - L5: Previous papers suggests read-once the packet headers ([bifrost]), or
    copying the entire packets before use (bridging).
    - This does not apply to runtime metadata exchanges, e.g., `vring[idx].len`,
      `vring[idx].len`.
- **Avoid the need for (manual) pointer validations and bounds checking.**
  Preferably, all the check should be done ASAP, at the interface boundary.
  Pointer validation is extremely error-prone, and very easy to miss.
  - The use of some type of handles (file/virtqueue descriptors) may be useful
    here.
  - Now, existing L2, L5 interfaces are already (kinda) designed this way.
    - For L2, I/O are performed on vring indexes instead of direct pointers.
    - For L5, network IO are performed on socket file descriptors.
  - Even with bound checks, speculative execution
- **Separation of data and metadata**. I/O Data is always encrypted by software
  in confidential computing (TLS, other FS protocols), so it is better to keep
  them in-place to avoid copying ([bifrost]).
  - Because of this, it may be better to keep them separated, so that it is
    easier to enforce certain policy (e.g., zero-copy for data, read-once for
    metadata)
  - This may be difficult to do in the case of network packets due to packet
    encapsulation.

Other bits from HotOS'23 Paper.

- **Stateless interfaces & thread safety**. I don't fully get the implications
  of this. What are the states that can be removed?
- **Revocation**. [bifrost] mentioned that toggling the sharing state between
  Hypervisor and CVM at runtime is not possible due to memory encryption.
  However, it should be possible at the L2 boundary, but is it faster than
  copying?

### Trusted proxies & resource handles

One design is to force all cross-domain communication to go through trusted
proxies that perform data validation, bound checking, etc... ([redleaf]).

- Instead of passing pointers, handles are passed across the interfaces, which
  makes it less likely to make mistake.
- Design choices: Centralized monitor vs. inline monitor

### Capabilities

- The previous design point is what capabilities-based security achieves.
- Capabilities model is a valid consideration for security-first from-scratch
  designs, but can also be retrofitted into unexpected places.
- Challenge: deciding what to abstract into capabilities

### Mutual distrust

- While confidential computing threat models focuses on trusting only the
  protected application, in real world attacks may also come from the protected
  application.
- Ideally our interface design should account for this mutual distrust.

### Low-overhead isolation primitives

- AMD SEV-SNP provides 4 VMPL levels to enforce hierarchical in-CVM isolation of
  memory. A similar feature is also supported in TDX 1.5.
- Note, VMPL switching is costly due to the need of VMExits ([veil]), so
  asynchronous RPC communication should be considered across the domains.
- Exploiting this to build isolation boundaries is a source of novelty.

### Flexible data path

Aside from the traditional networking stack, we should ideally support other
data paths e.g., DPDK, or at least make it not so hard to port them to our
framework.

### Attack surface minimization with performance considerations

- **Minimizing TCB** Instead of minimizing attack surfaces, we should instead
  minimize the TCB that interacts with untrusted input.
  - E.g., [gramine-tdx] minimized the no. of virtqueues to be used that I don't
    think make sense. Each virtqueue is essentially accessed by the same code
    base.
- **No notification / Poll first** Notifications are fundamentally difficult to
  harden due to races, while does not contribute much to performance.
  - Are there cases where they are a must?
- **Performance** Other optimizations, e.g., packed virtqueues, indirection,
  that meaningfully impact performance, should still be compatible with this new
  interface.

### Speculative execution mitigations

- [speculative] mentioned hypervisor-given indexes in the vrings might be used
  for speculative execution.
- Ideally all indexes / pointers should be masked before use.
- May be Related: paper from David [secret-free-hypervisor]

### Fine-grained compartmentalization of the TCP stack

- The TCP stack is organized in layers, but there haven't been discussions to
  split it.

## Sketch design: I/O Monitor

[Src](https://excalidraw.com/#json=GHAbzT6Lub5UbvPPiHY7c,oxBzneS8cORp1zgLn8-jzQ)
![image](https://hackmd.io/_uploads/H1m8hNKNJg.png)

We introduce an entity called "I/O Monitor (IOMon)" that interposes all
communication between guest and host.

- The goal of IOMon is not to deprivilege the main kernel (e.g., NestedKernel),
  but to shepherd safe I/O:
  - Discouraging unsafe interactions (e.g., direct shared memory access).
  - Provide safe abstraction for the stacks to do their job.
  - We want to make hardening IOMon as simple as possible (minimizing TCB,
    automatic checks, safe-by-default primitives).
- Mutual distrust: IOMon has two ends, the in-CVM one that handle CVM-side I/O
  and in-hypervisor one that handle hypervisor-side I/O.
- CVM interfaces:
  - IO memory allocation. Enforce "trusted component allocate"
  - Metadata management. Enforce one-time read & sanitization
  - Feature negotiation and transaction
- Hypervisor interfaces. TBD.
- Capabilities. TBD.
  - Considering using capabilities.
  - Related: LXD, LVD used a microkernel architecture to manage asynchronous
    communication between isolated driver and core kernel.
  - Capabilities makes the verification for some operations simple, and
    minimizing TCB.
  - May be hard to retrofit into existing interfaces.

### Issues

- I expect cutting the networking stack from the kernel is not easy. But do we
  need to at all? An approach may be to run two versions of linux

notes.title: Safely Handle Interleaving Code and Data in Disassembly
notes.lead:
Most disassembly tool that use linear scan from the entries cannot handle data
in between code, due to the problem of unintended instruction [[njh7pnzn]].
notes.body:
Most disassembly tool that use linear scan from the entries cannot handle data
in between code, due to the problem of unintended instruction [[njh7pnzn]].

To take this, an approach is to treat every possible byte offset as potential
instruction boundary (superset disassembly [@bauman2018superset]). This is
combined with runtime address translation by looking at the target of control
transfer to determine the correct candidate. This may bloat the binary size of
up to 5 times [@priyadarshan2023safer], so some heuristics may be used to
optimize the process.

combined with runtime address translation by looking at the target of control
transfer to determine the correct candidate. This may bloat the binary size of
up to 5 times [@priyadarshan2023safer], so some heuristics may be used to
optimize the process.

notes.title: Saving status flags in x86
notes.lead:
When dealing with static instrumentation it is important to save the status
flags and restore them for correct execution.
notes.body:
When dealing with static instrumentation it is important to save the status
flags and restore them for correct execution.

`pushf`/`popf` [c9x](https://c9x.me/x86/html/file_module_x86_id_271.html) can be
used to push and pop the flag register, but they are very slow for some reason.

- <https://reverseengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/9348/why-are-pushf-and-popf-so-slow>
- <https://reviews.llvm.org/D6629>

The preferred way used in LLVM is `LAHF` and `SAHF` (Load status flags into AH
and store AH into status flags)

Note: These instructions do not deal with overflow flag `OF`, which much be
backed up somehow.

This procedure can be seen in binary instrumentation:

```asm
push %rax 	; Backup rax
lahf 		; Load flags into higher ax 8 bits (ah)
seto %al 	; set overflow flag to lower ax 8 bits (al)
push rax 	; backup rax
...
pop %rax
add 0x7f,%al 	; restore overflow flags by manually trigger an overflow
sahf 		; Restore ah -> flag register
pop %rax 	; Restore actual xrax

```

notes.title: Scaling Networking Stack
notes.lead: The main ideas to scaling networking
notes.body:
The main ideas to scaling networking

1. Packet from the same flow [[vbeb82fs]] must be processed together, e.g,.,
   aranged in the smame ring buffer. This avoid complexities with out-of-order
   packet reordering and also the need for looking for packets all over the
   places ([[vtn586yc]]).
2. Packets should be processed from start to finish by the same stack, e.g.,
   [[llh2ly47]], to reduce bottle necks with scheduling, kernel crossing
   [[471vf8vr]]
